content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												TLDR: Highly recommended, good fun in single player or multiplayer and ok for people who get motion sick from fps or moba style games.If you're thinking of getting this game, first thing I suggest you do is look at some gameplay on youtube. I have an indepth overview and review with gameplay here 


YouTube™ Video: Indepth Overview & Review with Gameplay of Gauntlet Slayer Edition | Mister Clash 

			Views: 123		

			Gauntlet Slayer Edition: Covering the basics of the characters, game play and review info as well. And where to get the game real cheap.		

 (hour long) and Zerohill has an awesome 20 video playlist you can see here https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLEg-yDRmLEZ1F0zYiE14ciggS71YnssXX The aim of the gameMorak the magician created the gauntlet for power & got trapped inside. Your job is to fight through hordes or mummies, walking dead, undead, skeletons, grunts, orcs, etc., to bring him 3 shards of a sword so he can escape the gauntlet. In return he promises riches & power.The Characters, their weapons & attacking skillsThor (Warrior): Carries a battle axe and does large sweeping slashes which lay waste to the enemy. Can also do a double handed vertical chop (think log splitting). And when in a bind, a spinning attack which decimates the hordes around him. And can do a charge to barge the enemy out of the way.Thyra (Valkyrie): Has a Shield, sword and speer. For close quarter combat she slashes with her sword. When the enemies are nearby she can throw her shield (Capt America style) and take out groups or lines of enemies. And she has a speer thrust which can also take out a line of enemy fast, as well as get her out of a swarming group. She also has a shield block which reflects projectiles back at the enemy who threw them at her and protects her from the slashes of sharp fingernailed attackers. She can move while she has the shield up, although slower.Questor (Elf): He has a bow and arrow and an elf bomb which he can drop on the ground or attach to his snipe arrows. His normal arrows are rapid fire and short range. His snipe shot is longer range and has more power but isn't as rapid. Use the snipe/bomb arrow to shoot into a Summoning stone from afar - or single enemy troop and the troops around will blow up. His elf bomb can also be dropped into the middle of a horde to blow them up. For quick escapes he has a tumble roll.Merlin (Wizard): He has 9 basic spells to choose from... Close quarter ice (freezes enemy in place), Ice beam (think laser beam) and Ice lob bomb (which creates a frozen circle which slows down the enemy. Fire balls (not as rapid as elf arrows but do more damage), fire lob bomb and can move quickly as a couple of snaking fireball things. Chain lightening, a force blast which knocks over the enemy and a force shield he and others can stand in.Lillith (Necromancer): An add on character which can be purchased seperately to the game itself, her stock standard weapons are a small skeleton which rises to swipe the enemy a distance from her and a large skeleton with a sledge hammer that bashes down on groups of enemy or large items. As she takes out an enemy she gains some of their Soul Energy which she can use to raise a small group of fighters to help her.Weapon AbilitiesEach character can change their main weapon to give it slightly different abilities. E.g. choose a different bow and the elf's bomb becomes a "keep enemy in place" bomb and allows you to then kill them while they stand still. His normal arrows are not changed when this bow is used. The warrior can change his axe so that the double handed log splitting chop wipes out all the enemies around him in one blow. Valkyrie and Wiz also have different abilities.TalismansThese change what happens when a potion is used. At the beginning the use of a potion simply blows it up and damages anything in the blast zone. Later they can be changed E.g. One use for the Valkyries becomes creating 3 valks to fight for her. Each character's Taslisman change is different. RelicsTheses are items you can buy in the game (with gold earned in the game) to enhance your character's abilties. Some enable you to move faster, others create a whirlwind around you. One creates illusions of your character which can attack the enemy along side you.Q&A - Answering unasked questions and bad review claimsBad review claim: The game lacks content.My take: Without any elaboration in what way it lacks content, the statement isn't helpful and says more about the reviewer than the game. The game has 30 missions in Campaign mode, which can be played on Easy, Normal or Hard, so it is kind of like 90 different missions. Each can be played with one of four main characters for a total possible 360 possible different mission experiences. Add to this the Endless option which has you go through an endless number of floors which are made up on the fly - and can be done solo or with others. The top players have reached floor 8,192!!! And then there is the Colleseum which pits you against waves of beasties in a one room arena - 6 waves completes the mission and each day there is a new mission with different gameplay in a new arena. I wouldn't call that "lack of content".Bad review claim: Only 6 to 8 hrs of game play.My take: At the time of this review I have over 140 hrs of game time. I only have 30 of 46 achievements, have not completed the campaign fully by myself in Normal or Hard mode in any single character. Have only managed to get to floor 79 in Endless mode with a team of people (only managed floor 8 by myself as elf) and have completed only two missions in the Colesseum. Makes me wonder if those who think "only 6 to 8 hours" actually tried or just rode along in easy mode multiplayer until the campaign was done and then called it quits, or just found the game too hard. Because with all the achievements, character upgrades and missions, there is no way it can all be done in only 6 to 8 hours.Bad review claim: Boring.Again, without elaboration the statement is meaninless. Boring compared to what? Would they find the classic games like Space Invaders or Pacman or Donkey Kong boring? Millions of people around the globe used to go out of their way to play those games in "pinball parlors". There is so much which can be done in this game, any claim it is boring, says more about the reviewer than the game itself.I have a sneaky feeling the "lacks content", "only a few hours game play" and "boring" reviewers are most likely young kids. Maybe it's boring because their mates won't play with them, because maybe their mates think fps is the shiznits and everything else is boring? And I can see "kids" completing a room in easy mode and considerig it "done" without going back there ever in any other character or harder mode. Or the game is too hard for them so instead of admitting they find it too hard, blame the game for lack of content, not long in hours or boring.Fact is, the graphics are good, the game play is progressively harder (something all good games have in common), it can be played in a mode that suits your skill level and is great for people who suffer video game motion sickness. It can be played on your own whenever you want to spend a few minutes playing, or played with friends or even strangers and can be played in a variety of characters.You do not Need to play it in multiplayer. You can play it by yourself in single player mode without interacting with the server and other players. Most of my gameplay is like this as I use the time to get better with the various characters (so I'll be a good asset to any multiplayer team I join) and when I don't have the time to complete the campaign or whatnot with others and want to spend 15 or 30 minutes playing, or just don't feel like playing with others. Playing solo means you can go at your own pace and fully explore each mission in the campaign.Sometimes, depending on the time of day, finding a stranger to play Campaign is difficult. But if you head into Endless more you will Always find someone in there to play with.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I'm sorry but I am actually disappointed at this game. I just completed the game on normal and I can't say I want to play it again. The 4 classes are somewhat similar to Legends and Dark Legacy, but the Wizard was way different than the other classes having 9 total spells. The other classes aren't that interesting in comparison. I thought the level design was too simple; it lacked the charm and puzzle solving like in Dark Legacy: hidden invisible walls, switches, boss weapons, mini bosses, cool itmes, gems, etc. Really though, there are a list of things I didn't like in this game. I didn't grow up with the 1985 version, I grew up with Legends and Dark Legacy; games of which had a decent hack and slash system with a good balance of magic and puzzles. Pros:Good graphicsFunny as hellMultiplayer was simple and straight forwardCons:Lack of class design between the charactersSimplistic level designRelics are expensive and can't be used enoughArmor doesn't do anything, cosmeticSHORT ~ 5 hours!Lack of items and elements from previous generationEnemies were boring after about an hourThe Elf couldn't auto attack the generators!!!The story was boring and anticlimaticCouldn't select the same class in multiplayer and couldn't customize muchMasteries didn't change the game much, couldn't even view them in game3/10I was really hoping for more in this game. It easily could have been $50 with more content, customization, and level design. I miss Dark Legacy so much, I expected more from this.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Gauntlet is an action adventure game from Arrowhead Game Studios and WB Games. Let’s get rocking.The GoodI don’t think I’ve ever played the original Gauntlet game, but I played the living hell out of the one on the Playstation. I’m pretty sure it was Gauntlet Legends. Anywho, this Gauntlet is still just as fun as the previous installments.Now, bearing in mind that I haven’t played a Gauntlet game since the days of the PS1, this Gauntlet let’s you change your character’s armor, helmet, and weapon. What’s more, you’re not just throwing your weapon at the enemies in an endless stream anymore. No, you’re actually attacking them with that giant warhammer you’ve got. Warrior class, I’m looking at you. But, in all seriousness, actually being able to hit someone with a battleaxe, instead of throwing one at them repeatedly (as awesome as that may sound) is so much more rewarding.While the game itself is shiny and improved, it still maintains that classic Gauntlet feel. You and your friends (or, in my case, just me) against teeming hordes of monsters and it’s up to you to reduce them all into greasy gore piles, snag the gold, and get out with your lives.The levels are pretty large for what they are. It’ll take you a good ten minutes or more per level, depending on how much of a completionist/explorer you are as a gamer. That being said, there are a ton of levels to play through. And, if you finish them all, there is also an arena mode where you can slaughter monsters to your heart’s content.The BadMaybe it was intended to be so, but the dialog is laughably bad. It doesn’t really detract from the experience, but you’ll wonder how some of it got past quality control.The MehThe game is a bit of a grind and, if you’re not playing with friends, it might start to get monotonous after a while. You’ve been warned.Verdict: YeaAt full price, I probably wouldn’t recommend getting this one. But, if you can get it on sale, I’d recommend adding it to your collection. If you can convince a friend or two to get it and play it as a team, even better.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												It's a fun multiplayer brawler with nice character variety, with two melee fighters, an agile archer, and a wizard who plays like a stripped down version of Magicka. Unfortunately it's kind of lacking in content right now, with only 9 exploration level + run-quickly level + spawner arena level sets and 3 boss levels, one after each trio of level sets. Except for replaying on harder difficulties or grinding out achievements for "mastery" rewards, some of which are obnoxious along the lines of "kill 50000 enemies" or "kill 8000/12000 monsters in one specific way", there's not much to do in the game, and it only took me about 5 hours (including some time playing the same levels again with different friends) before I completed the campaign. Probably it'd take about 3 if you just went from start to finish.Ultimately, though, for actually being an online multiplayer remake of Gauntlet I have to recommend Hammerwatch instead. It's pixel art instead of 3D, but if you can get over that I think it's by far the better game.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Super disapointing game. And somehow inferior to its previous versions. The game is very short to play through and after that it's just a boring, pointless grind that only rewards you with achievements and vanity gear that you can't really see in game that well anyway. Pros+ Can be fun to play (for a few hours anyway) with a group of friends+Some humorous aspects+The graphics are decentCons-Not fun to play alone.-Not fun in random groups (people can and will screw you over). -You share a screen with your whole group (which causes multiple issues)-Not possible to join a game in progress. If you get dc'd you cant rejoin your friends and they will have to finish without you. -Not much variation in difficulties. Except Unfair which is just stupid. -Most characters have only a couple attacks. Except the wizard which is a weird pain to switch between his spells on the keyboard. -Nothing good to spend your gold on. The gear is all vanity items which is so bad because it doesn't look that special. -You can beat this game in about 5-6 hours and then wish you hadn't bought the game. -Weird bugs where I would randomly fall through the floor or just spontaneously die with no enemies around. -The story is really basic and only really applies to the start and end of the game. All the middle bosses have no meaning. And then of course the ending was predictable and the last boss was easy. To reward you for finishing the game you get to see a slideshow of 3 paintings. Its a very short simple game and it isn't worth more than $5. I wouldn't recommend paying anything more than that for it.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
nukes-viewHi all, nukes here.Gauntlet is a top down, dungeon crawler, which will have you hacking and slashing your way through hordes of enemies. Which sold it for me, who doesn't love running through dark dungeons slaughtering everything you are faced with.Based off of the original 1985 Gauntlet, this version captures its magic beautifully. Still offering four player co-operative locally and online as well. Gauntlet offers a story mode, Endless mode and a Coliseum. Each can be played with friends or on your own.I love this game, as it is easy to pick up and play, playing with friends made my experience even more fun. Although the community is not massive people still do play this online. The Game PlayBefore you jump into raid the dungeons in search of glorious riches. You are able to choose from four playable characters, with a fifth as DLC.Each with very different abilities and play styles.Warrior, Valkyrie, Elf, Wizard and Necromancer (DLC content)Personally my two favourite are the Valkyrie for mirror shield and clone combo, and the Wizard for his awesome spell combinations. Don't get me wrong though all the classes are brilliant.Personally Barbarian felt a little dumb and clumsy to me, Elf well his accent was just to annoying which really put me off his character.DifficultyThe difficulty of this game comes in three flavours. Unfortunately for all you hardcore gamers, as of Slayer edition, the fourth Unfair mode has been removed. With each increase in difficulty monsters have more hit points and run faster. Although more gold for all you looters.Easy - Says it all. Normal - Pretty much default.Hard -Well I am sure you get the point by now.Keep in mind the Colosseum mode the difficulty is fixed.Endless mode gradually increases as you make your way through the levels. (Keep in mind you don't keep gold form this mode, it is specifically for lives etc..)Controls & InterfaceThe controls are simple and easy to pick up, on original release the campaign had a tutorial, this helped with the wizard class. With Slayer edition release this has been removed. It is now in the form of a How to Play page on the main menu, which has controls laid out for each class.This game can be played with keyboard and mouse or a controller making sure you activate the controller before starting the game.Personally I found this game is more suited for controller use, especially with the wizard class.AchievementsThis game has achievements, some of them a fairly straight forward but even now I still haven't got to wave 50 on Endless or killed 15000 Orks.... Hurray for me.Unfortunately some of them are a grind.StoryThe campaign is based on going deeper through a series dungeons to challenge yourself, looting as you go. To find three pieces of sword for a sketchy wizard, on this Gauntlet journey you will encounter many deaths.Once you have completed a map (challenge) you are able to freely navigate to old and new missions plus bonus ones.Combat System, Skills & TraitsThe combat is fairly straight forward, swing here swing there, heads fall off Good ol mash the A button for best results. Least from a Barbarian or Valkyrie's point of view or for Wizard and Elf you use the right analogue to fire your bow or burn, zap and freeze.This game can be fast paced and chaotic at times, keep yourself moving or knowing your choke points will keep you alive. It is easy to lose your character in the commotion. Especially playing with others.Since Slayer edition release the skills and abilities have changed, now equipment you buy will determine what moves and skills you have.Personally why they decided to change it is beyond me, I loved that the items were more cosmetic based.They also removed the perk system for masteries, which again is beyond me completely. As masteries, other than boasting rights are pretty much useless now.Sounds & EffectsSounds decent and fitting for dungeon scene. Although very loud on start up so remove your headset or be deafened.Some of the voice acting can be a bit much.GraphicsThe graphics settings are straight forward, this game is not to demanding although later levels on Endless mode could cause issues for lower spec'd machines.Gore can be turned off for the younger audiences.Humour & TriviaDefinitely a love hate relationship with the voice acting on this game, although humorous to a degree I cannot stand the Elf's strong accent.MultiplayerThis multiplayer on this game works well, as mentioned before can be done locally on a decent sized screen or you will lose your character a lot. Or can be done online with friends or strangers.I have never had problems finding a Story or Endless mode game, although keep in mind if you are joining someone else's game you may not have choice of your favourite character. Multiplayer is stable and I have never had connection issues unless host is in a distant country. If you are unsure just host your own.Story mode progress is saved whether you do it multi or single player.Bugs - ImportantI don't think I came across any game breaking bugs. Only annoyance is I mentioned before, is about starting the game after you turn on or connect your controller as sometimes Gauntlet may not pick it up.ConclusionOverall I found this game very fun to play, par some of the changes to Slayer Edition if you are buying it now you will never know what you have missed so this won't affect you. Although don't get me wrong the additions were great as well.I still play to get last achievements to this day, but I have had many hours of dying to hordes of enemies with friends and strangers.I personally hope they make another Gauntlet down the line sometime with even more content.I felt this game did do the originals games justice and I hope you will feel the same way.Because who doesn't like throwing explosive crates/barrels at their friends.Hope I helped.ηυĸєΜ266

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												If you've played past Gauntlet games you'll come to realize shortly after starting the tutorial stage that this is almost  NOTHING  like past games of the series. The only things that I found similar are:4 Player Co-Op   The announcer exclaims things like. "Your health is getting low!"Oh you shot the food? It's gone now.Secret passagesRUN FROM DEATHThings missing from past Gauntlet games:Persistant Stats. The armor from the shop? Yeah it's cosmetic.Buying benificial shop items. Besides the stat boosts which is obviously gone. You also can't buy magic potions, halos, that little Phoenix that would follow you around and add projectiles on top of your own attacks. Yeah none of that exists. You can only buy 'relics' now.No shield button. That's gone too. One class has a shield. The others have different abilities like charge or a dodge roll. Wizard doesn't have any of those. But he does have a spell shield he can cast that breaks after a short duration.Things that are largely different from past Gauntlet games:Characters have a skill that goes on cooldown and a couple benificial abilities instead of a basic attack that would automatically choose a ranged or melee attack.Magic potions don't damage things on the screen. Now they're used to power 'relic' items you purchase with gold from the shop. Not necessarily as great or had the same powerful impact as dropping a lightning potion on the screen and frying things to a crisp.TL;DRIf you have never played a Gauntlet game. You might actually find this game is eh, alright. Not terrible. But not great either.But if you're a past Gauntlet fan. Look elsewhere. Holy crap. They just plastered the title "Gauntlet" on this. I bought into it like a fool. Don't make the same mistake I did.

number of helpful: 26 of 46 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The developers put to much of their own game "Magicka" into this new Gauntlet game. Those whom were huge fans of the previous games likely wont enjoy this much. However if you were into Magicka you will likely have a great time. The wizard is basically magicka lite. The story is there but you kind of have to look for it which really pulls you out of the game. So this game should be avoided if your looking for a story. As for a party game , or a game to be played with friends or even on stream with friends this game will hold its own. It's not a 40-60$ game and therefore you get your monies worth. However it is not the Gauntlet that we all deserve. It is still however better than that "Thing" we call Sacred 3. However Sacred 3 is  more of an rpg than this. You do no character building. There is no loot. Super limited on upgrades and most of which requires high difficulty play to even unlock. There are 4 characters / classes in the game. Warrior, Archer, Valkyrie, Wizard. The Wizard is a combo based spell caster. Adding different elements creates a different spell. It has more playstyle than anyone else and was very obviously inspired by Magicka, hence the Magicka LITE comment earlier.  The Archer is the most mobile class and seemed to do a decent amount of aoe. The biggest thing you noticed is that you can actually move and attack which is extremely important when playing on higher difficulties. However as an archer you have a harder time destroying the monster spawners. The Warrior is a barbarian. Wielding an axe you chop like the best of em. Pretty generic, Decent survivablity but playing on harder difficulties ... is well... Hard as a melee oriented class.  This is definitely the class that at best is meant for killing monster spawners. Then there is the Valkyrie. The tank. The Paladin... The avenger.... Yea , thats right. I said Avenger. She throws her shield like Captain America. She is pretty beefy, Can do a decent amount of aoe at melee and at range.  Most importantly. She has a block. She is the best at survival. Can fight at melee or ranged.   She is kind of a tank anyway. She has a shield and can block but takes a lot of damage. Use of all of the tools is required to play her. I stuck with the Archer while my co-op partner played a Valkyrie and then later swapped to Wizard. We played through the first door with no issues. However on the first floor of the second door we encountered a game HALTERING bug. Where the key we picked up did not actually acknwledge that we picked it up. However it was no longer in the game world and we could no longer progress. That was the stopping point for me. Once you hit a game breaking bug that rings bells. The Drastik Measure gives this game a 6/10

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I played it in Co-op (4 players). Some reasons i don't recommend Gauntlet:- Short, 12 chapters (3 of those are just boss battles). About 5 hours.- Can't buy Relics (expensive items that require you to use a potion) inside the chapters, only between them- the bonus from achievements are stupid (like +1% damage)- Relic system is stupid, they are expensive and require you to find potions (those are rare). If you are playing coop with 4 people, don't expect to use relics more than once a chapter. The abilities itself are pretty stupid or worthless, like some seconds of invulnerability (but you cant attack as well) or a gargoyle summon (with an AI programmed to suicide as soon as possible).- Food and potion system is stupid, especially because you can destroy them with abilities if you do so before you pick them up- Lacks character progress- stages and enemies are very similar to Diablo 2, lacking personality- The Wizard class is a copy of Invoker from Dota2 or Magicka- Shallow story- pointless stages with "Death" following you around, forcing a time trial- Difficulty is not well implemented. Easy is too easy, anything other than that is too hard. Game over is frustrating as it starts from the beginning of the chapter.- Easy puzzles

												Y'know I really don't like AAA-ish titles, but this one is well done. It takes me back. They captured the old-school feel of Gauntlet very well.They kept it simple, and the core gameplay is alot of fun. Multiplayer is obviously best (I played 3 players), but single player is also fun. I wouldn't buy it for singleplayer, though.Pros:+Fun hack-n-slash gameplay+Classic classes that have very noticable differences between them+Music is really good+Graphics are crisp enough+Controller support is top-notch+Seems like alot of gameplay with several modes and daily challenges!Cons:-Twenty bones is expensive, but it goes on sale frequently (I got it for five, so I picked up the DLC for a buck, too)-DLC worth is debatable - maybe play the core game first and see if its worth it for you, personallyFor local co-op, this is quite fun!

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												There's something wrong with this game - and I'm still not sure what it is.Is it well-balanced, fun? YepNow that's out of the way - there's a few very odd design decisions.In putting in the ubiquitous levelling up, story, background and achievements, they've missed something of the original and the sequels - its "open world" feel. All of the dungeons are built to a very specific standard and focus you tightly down the next "surprise". Even if that's not explained to you what the surprise is - three times I had to return to the hub purely because I'd not done what the designer expected me to.It feels very much like a 2010 game in that all of your choices are made for you and drilled in from the start. There's no discovery curve as sort, just a line of achievements that act as little red ticks from the teacher.Saying that, it's still fun - all of the characters have a different style, the key sound is there - but it's definitely lost some of its charm. DEATH is now an enviromental hazard, Ghosts are now missiles of a sort; and it's set around Boss Monsters rather than Hordes - like every other game.7/10 - Treading the same old path rather than creating a new style. minus another point until they fix issues like swapping characters between games, swapping screen size and swapping keyboard controls. It will get a recommended when that's fixed.

number of helpful: 21 of 37 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I have played my fair share of Gauntlet games in my day. Originally in the arcades, every death meant I had to pump more quarters into the machine. Now, with the series hitting multiple consoles spanning different generations, Gauntlet is back after a rather long hiatus. Is it back to the feelings we all know and love, or was that really just me looking back with rose-tinted glasses? After playing this, I may be going with the latter.In a very arcadey fashion, Gauntlet puts players in the role of one of four classes. In a top-down view, they will hack and slash (or shoot arrows and fireballs depending on the class) at hoards of enemies while they try to make it through the dungeons while gathering as much gold as they can. Don’t forget getting chased by death himself in some of the more frantic levels.Progression is done not through leveling up, but through masteries. There are even death masteries that will allow characters to not take as much damage from certain traps if they die enough from them. Basically, doing normal stuff throughout the game will allow players to get better at that certain skill. It’s not groundbreaking in any way, but it at least let me improve my characters.The classic classes are all back, and each plays very differently from one another. The Warrior is a brutal melee fighter, the Valkyrie utilizes her shield to both block and attack from afar, the Elf uses bows and bombs and the Wizard combines elements to fire off magical attacks. Each has their own play style and really changes up how the player will handle situations, but in the end, most of it is pretty mindless.The standout here is the co-op play. Online multiplayer with three other people was a frantic, hack n slash mess, but in a good way. Since it didn’t take much thought to play, we ended up have a fun time just hacking away at enemies while talking. Also, fighting for the crown when someone would get hit quickly became the meta-game of it all, even though the crown does nothing except increase points at the end of the level.The story is minimal at best, but the voice acting that is there, along with the comedic overtones are well done and even made me laugh a few times. Sure, there is no “Sexy pants!” being screamed like in Sacred 3, but the dialog that is there never takes itself seriously and gives off a bit of charm that I enjoyed.Gauntlet isn’t much of a thinking man’s game. Find a class you like and have at it. The Wizard will be the one most people avoid, but even then, with a few other buddies along for the ride, it can be a rather fun time. Single player can get a bit more monotonous, but it is the same for the multiplayer; just having some others to share in the mindless action helps out a lot.For $20, players get a rather fun game. Yeah, I still feel more love for the older versions of the game, but I think that’s just the nostalgia in me. Even in single player, I didn’t mind taking on the hoards of enemies with my shield throwing Valkyrie. Jumping online is where the game gets hectic, but way more fun, and the tongue-in-cheek nature of the dialog and story offer up a few laughs at times. I would say pick it up, but if you do, try to at least convince one or two friends to pick it up with you. You’ll all have a more enjoyable time together.Recommended

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												This review is a toss-up between recommend or not.  It's not a great game, but it isn't awful either.  This is simply a mediocre twin stick shooter that does nothing to set itself apart from other games in the genre.  There is no story, no intrigue, and hardly any funny humor (there's plenty of bad humor).  You merely walk through level after level, killing whatever enemies you encounter along the way.  Sometimes you don't even have to kill the enemies and can merely run past them.  The game is fun for a few hours with friends, and that is why I chose the Thumbs Up instead of Thumbs Down review.  I don't recommend it if you're going to play alone or hop in with random people online.Here are my main points of discontent:The characters attack too slowly, making it easy to get swarmed on all sides and unable to move or do anything, causing you to die.  There is not nearly enough gold available so you can't upgrade enough of your equipment.  The game forces you to g rind for hours in endless mode just to get enough gold to upgrade a single character to the best equipment.  Hopefully you never ever want to try out one of the other characters, else you'll have to start the grind all over again.There are hardly any useful items for you to purchase, and most of the upgrades you can get are just for appearance.  None of the choices for the combat equipment (weapon, potion power, and relic power) really provide any meaningful help for you fight better.  Oh, they are certainly necessary and you'll want them upgraded fully, but they cost ridiculous sums of gold for the most minor of benefits.  I honestly found that most of my character's default equipment was better than any of the items I purchased, and that's just dumb.The game also has a silly mechanic that allows you to accidentally (or intentionally) destroy food, taking away the ability for you to heal. This is supposed to be funny, but in practice it's just annoying, especially on the levels that are so dark you can't even see where anything is.  Food is also often placed behind objects you have to destroy, making it likely you'll accidentally destroy your meal instead of eating it for the health you desperately need.The final boss is nearly impossible on Normal difficulty yet ridiculously easy on Easy difficulty.  I made no less than 40 attempts on Normal with various friends.  We could get to the final wave of enemies before killing the boss, but we always ended up dying.  I hate when games make the final boss stupidly difficult just to increase play time.  It's a dumb practice that just makes players resent the game.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This game is incredibly fun if you play it with a group of friends. The gameplay has just enough to it to keep it interesting in ways other than just a simple 8-way shooter, while remaining comfortably familiar to anyone that's ever played the classic Gauntlet games.  With friends, it's a fabulous romp that's well worth the admission fee.However... How did anyone miss the glaring obvious "Elf can run AND shoot" imbalance?  The usual "the other classes have different strengths" argument will come out, which might be true, but the elf can run, attack AND still be picking up all the gold while every other class has to choose between fighting and looting.   Unfortunately, with the end level 'scores' active, it is a poor thing to have as wildly an imbalancing play option as that.  Hopefully it will improve, because right now I'm not pleased with the open multiplayer balance.  Any competent Elf (that plays selfishly, as the game seems to intend) will make every other player feel like their time spent playing was wasted.  That's a real shame on this otherwise good game.If you play solo, or with a group of cool people on regular occasions, then consider this a recommended game. Otherwise... I cannot recommend this game simply because of this imbalance issues.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I've played the Gauntlet games since I had an NES as a kid.  Between the original and Gauntlet: Dark Legacy I put many many cherished hours into these games.  They were difficult and intricate.  The one thing they lacked was a significant difference between the characters.  This game has that--which I like--I never understood why every character had ranged attacks in previous installments.  That's all it has over the older Gauntlets.  The warrior is purely melee (and the worst class), the Valkyre is primarily melee with limited ranged attacks (and is the second worst class), and the wizard and archer are ranged powerhouses.It took just a few hours to beat the game solo on normal difficulty.There's no real leveling system, just gold to be spent on either gear (whose availability is dependant on what levels you've beaten on what difficulty, plus you have to pay for them) or Relics (which are not unique to your character).  It's kind of fun, and I'm still waiting for my friends to install their copies so I can try three or four player mode, but it's not worth the price tag of $15 or $20.

												I bought this when the Steam Summer 2016 sale was on however I had it in my wishlist for quite some time expecting to pay full price when things got calmer irl.I bought it so my fiancee and I could play together and because I remember playing the arcade version and falling in love with it.My fiancee doesn't play games at all other than a few Match-3s on her phone. The difficulty pushes the casual player to want to continue and kick some♥♥♥♥♥ The outcome from playing that impressed me the most is the drive from my fiancee to beat a failed stage even though we got our asses handed to us. This is often not the case with casual gamers who will generally quit once thing seem too difficult. She was determined to continue to finish a dungeon.The graphics are amazing although if you're playing on a TV (Steam Link, as we were), it's incredibly easy to lose sight of your character. Your character is incredibly small when not playing solo in front of a PC screen which does unfortunately cause us to sit uncomfortably close to the TV screen and even then it is naturally hard to see where you character is in the midst of combat. Unfortunately changing the resolution of the game does not remedy this and will only scale down the entire image and not 'expand' like most games will.If you are looking for a game you can play with someone sitting on your couch, this is most definately one of the best you'll ever find. They have done the Gauntlet title well with the release of this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												This is a great adaptation of the arcade classic, I'd actually go as far as to say it's the best incarnation of Gauntlet yet. Great fun with three friends, Gauntlet boasts a ton of replayability, there's a nice variation of useful weapons and items to unlock for each character as well as a whole bunch of aesthetic goodies including a daily challenge to unlock new cloaks. The combat is surprisingly deep, both the valkyrie and warrior play in a typically hack and slash style with the warrior boasting more health and brutal offensive capabilities while the valkyrie has a slightly more tactical, defensive style. The elf plays completely differently to both however, utilising twin stick shooter style controls and a nice array of tricks and traps, but it's the wizard that steals the show for me. Three of his attack buttons represent three elements that can be mixed and matched to create nine different spell effects similar to the spell system in Magicka (another great Arrowhead game) to begin with this spell system seems complex but once you master the intricacies of how to cast on the fly the wizard becomes incredibly powerful, utilising both crowd control and damage dealing to the party's benefit. My only gripe with the game and it is a very small one is that the campaign is somewhat short, however thanks to Gauntlet's pick up and play nature it boasts a ton of replayability, especially if you have three friends who are interested in some arcade, dungeon delving.Definitely worth a purchase, don't overlook this arcade gem and if you enjoy it then it's worth looking into Arrowhead's online co-op twin stick shooter Helldivers as they're both quite similar and definitely well worth owning.

												This doesn't even FEEL like Gauntlet. They changed way too much and it has this Torchlight II rip off kind of vibe. Torchlight II is actually way better compared to this. The voiceovers are HORRIBLE. The style is just strange. Not what I was expecting at all!! I feel like it was a waste of my money. Wasn't worth the price at all! It's barely worth $1 in my eyes because it's just not anything like old school Gauntlet. Someone really allowed Gauntlet to be butchered! They need to look back at like Gauntlet Dark Legacy and bring something like that back with a bit of a more modern twist if they'd like and online co-op compatibilities with that. Not this garbage. Within the first few minutes I found out that they basically rigged it where you need others so you can get through it or so you can destroy everything that is breakable OR you have to repeat the same level over and over and over and over and rely on gold. They could have done SOOOO much with this!!! 1) Death should be the original death that was scared away with potions and took away EXP and health.. Not this instant death crap. 2) Potions should be useable right away as welllll magic potions! 3) Loot should only be visible to the player in front of the screen so there isn't any fighting between actual people. 4) There should be an in game chat for it. I've heard plenty of people complaining about this and I haven't found out for myself yet but I don't think I will anyways. 5) The coins thing to revive yourself is a neat idea but I think when in co-op mode other players should be able to run over and revive you no matter what even if it's just a small amount of health and when you're playing alone it should more of the coin based thing or else each person should have their own coins but NOOO! They have to share coins to revive... Lame. 6) They should have gotten better voice actors and actresses!!! 7) The weapons.. Oh come on... With hoards. I miss the old style Gauntlet where they threw the weapons! Now they don't throw the weapons! Not this buy your gear bs. It's not even worth it. 9) There should be more customization to the characters!!!!! The woman looks like a darn tank who had her eye shoveled out. -.- Anddd there's a whole lot more I could go on about but I figure this is enough for one review...I am not pleased. Severely disappointed!!!! I hope my friends don't waste their money.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												All of us growing up in the golden age of standup arcade games remember the beast of a machine Gauntlet was. 4 player coop was unheard of at the time and boy did we like it. So this new rendition of Gauntlet takes that basic formula and steps it up a notch by giving each hero some new skills that gives it a much more modern hack 'n slash feel. And it works. It manages to hold a nostalgic presence while still feeling refreshingly new. They've added some character level ups to keep it interesting and there is even a difficulty setting if you feel like adding a little more challenge.The biggest shortcoming with Gauntlet is the disproportionate skill set when it comes to the Wizard. He has way too many abilities and other cool effects than anyone else, so playing anyone else feels kind of under whelming. The other significant blemish is its short campaign length. The first playthrough is fun and exciting, but it quickly loses luster on subsequent playthroughs.The new Gauntlet is indeed fun and best experienced in a full 4-player cooperative, but the game eventually gets stale due to it's short levels and repetitive game play--kind of like the original.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												Bought a 4-pack and wish I could refund it. The multiplayer is awful, you all share the same screen like in Broforce, made sense for 1985, not in 2016. To make it worse all your progression is tied to your gold, which people can use the screen to kill you for and take when you die. Mix that with most of the classes dying in 1-2 hits and it's just not fun. There's absolutely no excuse as to why any modern game should make you share the same camera over the internet. Add in the fact that there's a necromancer add-on that focuses around using dead enemies to summon friendly skeletons, but there's a charm that everyone else can use to do the same thing and make your necromancer abilities worthless, and you've got a lot of head scratching in a game that should be a blast.All of that said, the single player is quite fun, just don't plan on having any sort of fun online with 4 players. Everyone just skips the monsters and pulls the camera ahead so you can't see and collects gold since there's 0 incentive to kill anything in this game, another huge flaw. It needs some sort of exp system to punish players for just skipping to the end of each floor.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												It's not just marketing talk when they say this Gauntlet is a completely new experience. I've put hundreds of hours into Gauntlet Legends on the N64, and quite a few into Dark Legacy on the gamecube. I had expectations going into this game.This is a very different game.Is it fun? Yes. It's a good game, and it's fun. We'll get that out of the way first. However, it's nothing like classic Gauntlet games. Each of the classes play very differently; they're not just different allocations of stats. As a matter of fact, there really is no notion of "stats" in this game: there's no leveling, no character progression.The only difference in a start-game and end-game character is what gear you have equipped - most of which is only for aesthetic purposes. You have 3 important pieces of gear: Your weapon, an accessory that changes what your potions do, and a relic that gives you an extra cooldown-based ability. The only mechanical difference in your weapons is what your special ability does (in the case of the wizard it seems like ability sets rather than a single ability). More expensive weapons don't mean more damage, more range, or anything like that.Levels in this game vary widely in how long they take. Some only take a couple minutes. Others take up to 10. There also aren't too many levels in the game, and there are only 3 bosses, but all the bosses have very different mechanics.The bottom line is that it's a short but sweet game. I have trouble finishing 4 player co-op games with friends due to conflicting schedules and waning interests, but we had no problem sticking this one out. You can easily get through it your first time in 3 to 6 hours.

number of helpful: 29 of 54 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I had never played any of the Gauntlet series in the past but my friend was a BIG TIME fan of the series and convinced me to buy this game on release. We started playing and at first nostalgia struck for my friend, but after that it just became the same thing over and over again. To start we ended up beating the entire game on hard difficulty in only a few hours. Every level was pretty much the same design with the same type of monsters with just graphical differences. It was almost like they imported the same monsters same soul stones and just made them look different. The bosses on the other hands were sometimes buggy and not very challenging at all. We found that the first boss we fought was significantly harder than the last one. So far you would think this is a decent game with a few repetetive things that might be a little too easy. But that's not the worst of it. After you build up all yours coins you can buy a few "relics" that really don't do much to help you and usually you forget all about them anyways, but the worst part is that you can spend all your hard earned coins on "Armor and weapons" WHICH ARE PURELY COSMETIC! If they actually had a bonus or made you better. With all that said let's go over the pros and cons once again.CONS-Way too easy unless you're playing the hardest difficultyFound some graphical bugs that made me have to restart mid-gameHardly any puzzles non of which are challengingNothing of value to spend your coins on making collecting them kind of pointlessLazy level design with more of the same things you've already seen with a graphical revampPROS-A decent co-op experince even if it's too easyPretty good graphics all aroundVery Diverse characters and abilities- CONCLUSIONI wouldn't recommend buying this game because it does not nearly live up to the hype, but if you are a hardcore Gauntlent fan and really must have it I'd say wait for it to go on sale.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I was pleasantly suprised by this game when I discovered it was a significant improvment on its predecessors. I enjoyed playing both the original arcade version of Gauntlet Legends and the PS 2 Gauntlet Dark Legacy. Pros: Fantastic and fairly well balanced multiplayer.Each character actually has unique abilities/skills (for once) which make them better in different combat situations.Can be challenging at times, instead of everyone blowing up everything instantly.Fair voice acting and dialogueMoody atmosphere as opposed to really cheesy music blaring constantly.Secret areas require some thought and perception instead of firing weapons randomly and hoping to hit something.Boss fights more innovative and less hit-until-dead.Cons: Sometimes a bit laggy, even with computers that have good specs.Fairly short compared to Dark Legacy, but not a terribly short game overall.All in all, I would give this game a 9.5/10 for its significant gameplay and graphical improvements while still holding true to the feeling of the original games. A solid and well-rounded game with a hint of the childhood classic we remember.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												To those looking for an experience reminiscent of the old-school Gauntlet: Legends, reconsider your purchase. Legends is one of the first quarter-feed games I ever devoted myself to, so when I saw Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, I bought the game without hesitation. Not the best $20 I ever spent. Bearing in mind I wasn't expecting an exact replica of GL, other than the four base characters and the famous "don't shoot the food" rule (though it is incessently drilled into your head every time it happens), I did not find much connection to the classic.The game mechanics are simple and easy, which makes for great playability, and the multiplayer factor is has not been lost in this edition; the more, the merrier. Single player is actually quite difficult on its hardest setting due to limited control input and the room to room top-down action (which reminded me more of SmashTV rather than Gauntlet) makes thinning the horde a bit more difficult without the ability to efficiently bottle-neck as you could in GL. Character upgrades are limited only to item purchases (NO LEVEL UP?? IS THIS GAUNTLET??) and is rather unexciting.An okay dungeon crawler. Finding a better one to enjoy with friends is not difficult.Devoted Gauntlet: Legends fans; walk away.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Gauntlet 2014 is a couch co-op action-adventure game with competitive elements. Before I start this review, I have to say that I am not a fan of the original series. Sure, I played a couple of games way back when, then I played games influenced by them, then I got this. I put the game on "Hard" because I'm a real man and played it from start to finish with two friends. All I have to say is, don't buy this game.It's competitive aspect falls flat on it's face purely because gold is useless in this game. Players are encouraged to steal relic potions because they are scarce, steal the crown because it effectively doubles your earnings and to generally perform better than their friends in order to get a larger cut of your earnings. With gold you can upgrade your relics, except you don't have to - most of a relic's potential is already available to you from the get-go, besides, you barely get to use relics anyway. You can also spend gold on cosmetic pieces, a grand total of ten per character, excluding pre-order content, that you can barely see because you lose track of your character so often.This game is badly optimized, a staple of Arrowhead games since Magicka, even though it's not graphically impressive. There isn't much difference between low and high settings anyway, aside for VSync and FXAA. Because of a generally drab, boring and sterile aesthetic you lose track of your character easily. It's also severely lacking in enemy variety, averaging in five enemy types per zone.There are three zones in total, three chapters plus boss each. A chapter typically takes around twenty minutes to complete, and even that is generous. As long as you are not terrible or don't lose time quarelling, you can breeze through the game. There is a separate survival mode, Colosseum, but it's short and it's rewards, three cloaks, aren't very tempting.As you can see, I haven't said anything positive yet, because that is of little importance. Sure, the characters were nice, the dialogue was fun, the passive mastery learning system was somewhat interesting, but having all that robbed us of actual ♥♥♥♥ing progression and strategy development. If you are looking for a Gauntlet comeback, I suggest you try Hammerwatch. If you are looking for some co-op action, I suggest you try Hammerwatch, no, I implore you to try Hammerwatch. Not this, please. It does not get better.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												To those looking for an experience reminiscent of the old-school Gauntlet: Legends, reconsider your purchase. Legends is one of the first quarter-feed games I ever devoted myself to, so when I saw Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, I bought the game without hesitation. Not the best $20 I ever spent. Bearing in mind I wasn't expecting an exact replica of GL, other than the four base characters and the famous "don't shoot the food" rule (though it is incessently drilled into your head every time it happens), I did not find much connection to the classic.The game mechanics are simple and easy, which makes for great playability, and the multiplayer factor is has not been lost in this edition; the more, the merrier. Single player is actually quite difficult on its hardest setting due to limited control input and the room to room top-down action (which reminded me more of SmashTV rather than Gauntlet) makes thinning the horde a bit more difficult without the ability to efficiently bottle-neck as you could in GL. Character upgrades are limited only to item purchases (NO LEVEL UP?? IS THIS GAUNTLET??) and is rather unexciting.An okay dungeon crawler. Finding a better one to enjoy with friends is not difficult.Devoted Gauntlet: Legends fans; walk away.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												As someone who never played the original Gauntlet titles I was curious to see what made it such a popular series. With 9 titles exisiting dating way back to 1985 I felt I needed to experience this title which dated back through the decades. Now this iteration of the game, as is customary with the other 9 games in the series (or so the wikipedia page tells me), is a hack'n'slash, dungeon crawler. A formula that I somewhat enjoy, having played things like Torchlight as well as Path of Exile, alongside several other games.In this title there are a four different classes to choose from, including a warrior (bashy bashy type class), a valkyrie (sort of like the warrior but with a Captain America-like shield which can be thrown), an Elf (who can shoot stuff and throw bombs) and finally a wizard (who has a range of spells and I've also spent most the time playing). Their skills sets are all fairly versatile ranging from the mere axe swinging antics of the warrior to room clearing fireballs with the wizard. You can also buy upgrades for each class by collecting enough gold in each dungeon level. These upgrades range from several relics, which all classes can use, and vary from radial freezing abilities to summoning gargoyles to fight with you. Alongside the relics you can also buy new weapons which grant your character different abilities, class dependant of course. And of course you can buy cosmetic items to change the look of your class. Do you feel the wizard isn't Gandalf-y enough for you? Buy him a pointy hat. Or is the warrior too scantily clad for your tastes? Then buy him some armour. Each class has about three different cosmetic options for both the head and the body. Armours, hoods, capes and hats. Take your pick. You can also unlock capes by beating numerous waves of enemies in the colosseum, which I tell you now is no easy feat.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall I'd say this latest iteration of Gauntlet has many of the elements that dungeon crawling, hack'n'slash titles have and need. If you've played the other Gauntlet titles or have played titles such as Torchlight or Diablo etc this is definitley worth a look. Good day!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I load up gauntlet, expecting the fun and exciting adventure I had when my brother and I played on the nintendo 64 and Playstation 2. I wanted the exciting inventory items, the new powers and skills that came with levelling up, magical artifacts, powers, shopping and super attacks. Instead I got a slighlty upgraded version of the original nintendo. It...was fun at first, but it got so boring, so repetitive. The tiny character models, the uninspired levels, the boring enemies, bosses that left no real feeling of accomplishment and the "store" carries objects that cost a fortune to buy and barely offer anything to modify or alter gameplay or your character.If you own gauntlet on the nintendo 64 or on the playstation then just stick to that and pass this one over. It is a retro game, but you lose alot when you strip away all the updates and ideas that came with the incredibly addictive modern gauntlet games. Let this game sit with gauntlet seven sorrows as it is just as dull and bland.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												A solid and Fun game.A solid little game. I bought it for the nostalgia as I loved the multi-player mayhem in the 80's(?) on the commodore 64. Unfortunately as I'm in the wrong time zone from all my old pals I only managed to complete the solo campaign here. Unusually for me I ended up sticking with the wizard. I completed it on normal so I'm sure with 2 layers of toughness above and one layer easier, there is a challenge here for everyone.Nice look and good fun game. It did not feel like a chore going back to this game as I played it over a couple of weeks. The major problem I had was (I think) the saves were pretty far apart and you had to complete all the (3) floors in a chapter to "save" the chapter and keep it open/completed for next time. If you have kids or demanding partners that can be quite a problem unless you are happy to game through the wee hours to guarantee not being disturbed. I'd say I took a point off for this.I enjoyed the Collosseum challenges too.As I said, I only did the solo on this game and I am sure the multi-player would be even more fun. As I recall you could have friendly fire on in the old version or at least block your "friends" in a part of the same screen where they were screwed.Saying that, it's 6.5/10 from me :)NB I picked this up for $5 so for the hours and Fun I got for $5 I'd reccommend it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												A polished, modern version of an arcade classic, Gauntlet is pretty much what you expect. If you ever played the free game "Dead Nation" for the PS - it's that, but with swords & magic.Enemies swarm you in groups, some are tougher & pose more of a challenge to kill so you need to move around a lot and control the flow of encounters. Timing when to pop your potion, relic or ability can be crucial to not losing control and key-bashing in a panic.Pretty linear design, with a few basic puzzles. There are also a few very dark levels & this is where the game shines, shrouding rooms & hallways in black, as well as any monsters & obstacles. Choose different characters when you get bored because it can be a bit grindy. They all have varied abilities & play styles, and can suit different roles in the battlefield depending how you deck them out. If boredom persists, nudge up the difficulty. For me, I never really feel like I have 'mastered' any one character, so I guess the challenge (& game longevity) is whatever you make it.Great multiplayer support & even has a shared-screen LAN co-op mode from the PS port.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I picked up the 2014 version of Gauntlet. I've given the game 15 hours so far since its release so I believe I can make an honest assessment of game from both the nostalgic (I put at least $300 into the original arcade version) and modern game design and playing perspectives. Keep in mind I play this with a keyboard and mouse (Razer Naga).The Good1. The game play and design are polished with a few exceptions. The game feels like Gauntlet in 2014 and that is a good thing. The same run around, find keys, open doors, get potions, and the characters and narrator are all there from the original. What has changed is the fun factor and a much shorter game. The characters do more, they are flashier and more unique, and they feel solid when played. Questor the Elf definitely has the easiest playstyle, followed by Thyra the Valkyrie, Thor the Warrior, and finally Merlin the Wizard who is definitely the hardest to play.2. I found myself enjoying Thyra for the best balance of defense and offense. Thyra has great movement, can block any attack (yes any, even the end boss), and has a great offense as well. I suggest for starting players if you want to get into the fray, choose Thyra first.3. The mastery levels are nice touch and I really like how they build your character up. You have to choose before you go in whether you are going for no deaths or to dying a million times on purpose.4. $20 is about the perfect price for the game. I can honestly say I am glad I bought it.The (Somewhat) Bad1. Numerous bugs still exist in the game (crashes at times, sound cuts out, visual bugs). Luckily these aren't game-breaking.2. The camera tries hard to be there for you but currently it leads to more deaths than to give you a clear view of the game. In reality I wish each player had their own screen to look at (e.g. Diablo 3) versus the 3/4-view that traps players.3. Not being able to check your mastery progression at any time in the game is very annoying. A key to do this needs to be added.4. Merlin plays too much like Magicka (another Arrowhead product). I programmed my Razer Naga to switch between the nine spells he has and it then became much easier to play. My guess is a lot of other people are going to do the same thing.5. Cosmetic items are essentially worthless. I'd rather see that you have to buy new gear with better attributes after finishing a difficulty to do better in the harder difficulties than have just a look that nobody cares about.6. Mastery progression is way too high of a curve at times - it's a ploy for replay value. I do not want to go from 2,000 to 8,000 just for 5% more of an attribute.7. The game is too short. Normal is completed within 5 hours with a halfway decent team of players. Hopefully Arrowhead now that they have our money have a plan for future content.8. You are forced into being only one of the four characters. While this mimics the original arcade, in this day and age I shouldn't be forced to play Merlin if I don't want to. Again, this needs to be changed to allow multiple people to live out their Legolas dreams if they wish.The Ugly1. The game has no way to chat with other players so you spend a lot of your time in public games using the emotes to try and cajole other players to go the way they need to go, or for you to move due to the camera getting you stuck.2. The world leader-board was hacked within one hour of release. Currently there are players hacking to over 1.9 trillion points in single player mode. Arrowhead has yet as of this review to respond to a plan to either secure the boards or (as I've suggested on the Steam forums) remove them entirely until they have a way to fix them.ConclusionIf you are looking for a game that can help you pass some time and is casual, then Gauntlet is definitely the kind of game to lead to a night of fun. If you are looking for something more robust and long-term then this is not the game you are looking for; I would suggest another Action RPG such as Path of Exile or Diablo 3.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												"Where am I? Oh right, Gauntlet."I tend to say that quite a lot, but I wish there were more options than "Yes" and "No" to judge on a game.But alas, that'll have to do. Let's begin with the fact that I believe that one deserves a "Yes" rather than the other choice.Now as you probably know if you read some reviews, people tend to be a bit mixed about Gauntlet. I actually hesitated to get it myself due to that fact, but in the end, I don't regret it at all.Let's get to the actual game before explaining why the feedback is so mixed about Gauntlet Slayer Edition, and why it's justified.Graphics: The game looks fine, and it's not very demanding. There's nothing spectacular about it as you can judge from the screenshots, but it does its work just fine, for an isometric 3D game. I also highly recommend you to remove the Bloom.Gameplay: that is where the game really shines. In Gauntlet, you progress in dungeons either on your own or with some people, killing skeletons, orcs, demons, whatever. The game also features 3 bosses, which actually end up in a gameplay change and feel refreshing within Gauntlet. They aren't just meatshields. Also the variability in gameplay makes it so that you just end up switching classes every now and then. The game features 4 classes and another one from a DLC. These classes are Warrior, Elf, Valkyrie, Wizard and Necromancer. Pretty much self explanatory, but it's pretty hard to talk about the gameplay without explaining how the classes work a bit further.- Warrior: the muscles of the group. He's tanky, uses either a two handed hammer or a two handed axe, he's quite good at dispatching groups of enemies and can make himself invincible for a few seconds with some of his abilities. Useful for destroying those summoning towers, but I'll talk about those later.- Elf: this one ain't specialized in strength. He's full on dexterity. Well there are no stats, but you probably get the idea. The elf is a fast moving, ever dodging bow user. He's also able to drop bombs while dodging, which is fantastic to clean up the trash railing up on screen. He's quite feeble though, so you better pay attention.- Valkyrie: my personnal favorite. The Valkyrie, despite her name, isn't really made with the use of spears in mind. She's more of a paladin than anything, able to block pretty much everything. You can actually use spears though, but if you want the character to shine, you'll prefer the other sets of weapons. She can either make some huge, single-target damage with her skill, or clean-up everything around her in a 360 degree radius.- Wizard: now, that one is quite complex. If you played Magicka, the idea behind the wizard is pretty much the same: using a combination of two elements (either the same of different ones), you can "create" spells. Whatever the case may be, you are limited to 9 spells. Once you have activated a spell, you're "stuck" casting that one until you enter a new combination. Some people are amazing with it, I'm personnaly terrible. Luckilly, there's a weapon that gives a simple spell with a long range that makes him playable even if you don't feel like switching spells.- Necromancer: DLC locked, so I wouldn't know but from what I gathered, she's able to summon minions or spirits after charging her ability, which is done by killing mobs.Now, there's a bit more to it. Which brings us to... items!Items / personnalization:Whatever you do in Gauntlet, you'll want that damn gold. Also food to restore your health, and potions to... nope. Not restore your health.The potions are used to trigger special abilities for each class. Said abilities you can choose for each class, yet you are limited in your choices in a set of three, unique abilities for each character. Some of them are brilliant like the warrior one who makes him grow huge and unkillable, or the wizard with his huge, undestroyable shield that the whole group can benefit from.But yeah, to choose these abilities, you'll need gold. Luckilly, there's some everywhere in Gauntlet. Once you bought the item, it's yours forevers. But it ain't the only thing. You also get a third skill that you can choose in a more varied list, some of which can summon illusions of yourself that actually do some great damage, or others that charms monsters to fight at your side for a few seconds.You can also choose your armor, helmet and weapon, but you'll still need gold for that. It's not an issue at all, and pretty much makes the reason you're playing the game in the first place.I could go on and on, but you probably get the idea. The game is quite fun, there's a sense of progression and it plays pretty much like your typical ARPG, although the goal is totally not the same since Gauntlet revolves around arenas.So why am I saying the mixed views are justified? Well, every now and then, you'll probably wonder why you're doing so terrible with a class or cannot beat that boss. Such thinking can bring you to Google quite quickly, and that's the entire problem.If you aren't aware, Gauntlet was a quite different game in the first place. You unlocked "masteries" that were pretty much perks, could personnalize your character a tad more and there was also an "Unfair" difficulty mode after the Hard one.For some obscure reason, the devs suddenly decided to remove like 50% of the game and call it "Slayer Edition". As you probably guessed, the Unfair mode was removed.So whenever you search for something, make sure the item you're looking at is right from the Slayer Edition and not "Gauntlet 2014". After progressing in the game so much, I gotta admit, I for one am ♥♥♥♥ing disappointed by the fact they removed the unfair mode. That actually explains the mixed reviews. Gauntlet Slayer Edition is in no way a bad game. It's just a game constructed on a grave, if that makes any sense to you. Wherever you look, all you see are ghosts of its former glory. Most people were quite♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off by the decision of the devs, which ended up in negative reviews.So yeah. If you feel like the game is gonna please you, go on, play it. But try to ignore the ghosts... I couldn't, which is why I feel so mixed about this game. Alas, I wasn't able to try the "first" version of the game but I still feel like something is missing. The devs also stopped development so don't bother making a ticket if you have any issue with it. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I picked up the 2014 version of Gauntlet. I've given the game 15 hours so far since its release so I believe I can make an honest assessment of game from both the nostalgic (I put at least $300 into the original arcade version) and modern game design and playing perspectives. Keep in mind I play this with a keyboard and mouse (Razer Naga).The Good1. The game play and design are polished with a few exceptions. The game feels like Gauntlet in 2014 and that is a good thing. The same run around, find keys, open doors, get potions, and the characters and narrator are all there from the original. What has changed is the fun factor and a much shorter game. The characters do more, they are flashier and more unique, and they feel solid when played. Questor the Elf definitely has the easiest playstyle, followed by Thyra the Valkyrie, Thor the Warrior, and finally Merlin the Wizard who is definitely the hardest to play.2. I found myself enjoying Thyra for the best balance of defense and offense. Thyra has great movement, can block any attack (yes any, even the end boss), and has a great offense as well. I suggest for starting players if you want to get into the fray, choose Thyra first.3. The mastery levels are nice touch and I really like how they build your character up. You have to choose before you go in whether you are going for no deaths or to dying a million times on purpose.4. $20 is about the perfect price for the game. I can honestly say I am glad I bought it.The (Somewhat) Bad1. Numerous bugs still exist in the game (crashes at times, sound cuts out, visual bugs). Luckily these aren't game-breaking.2. The camera tries hard to be there for you but currently it leads to more deaths than to give you a clear view of the game. In reality I wish each player had their own screen to look at (e.g. Diablo 3) versus the 3/4-view that traps players.3. Not being able to check your mastery progression at any time in the game is very annoying. A key to do this needs to be added.4. Merlin plays too much like Magicka (another Arrowhead product). I programmed my Razer Naga to switch between the nine spells he has and it then became much easier to play. My guess is a lot of other people are going to do the same thing.5. Cosmetic items are essentially worthless. I'd rather see that you have to buy new gear with better attributes after finishing a difficulty to do better in the harder difficulties than have just a look that nobody cares about.6. Mastery progression is way too high of a curve at times - it's a ploy for replay value. I do not want to go from 2,000 to 8,000 just for 5% more of an attribute.7. The game is too short. Normal is completed within 5 hours with a halfway decent team of players. Hopefully Arrowhead now that they have our money have a plan for future content.8. You are forced into being only one of the four characters. While this mimics the original arcade, in this day and age I shouldn't be forced to play Merlin if I don't want to. Again, this needs to be changed to allow multiple people to live out their Legolas dreams if they wish.The Ugly1. The game has no way to chat with other players so you spend a lot of your time in public games using the emotes to try and cajole other players to go the way they need to go, or for you to move due to the camera getting you stuck.2. The world leader-board was hacked within one hour of release. Currently there are players hacking to over 1.9 trillion points in single player mode. Arrowhead has yet as of this review to respond to a plan to either secure the boards or (as I've suggested on the Steam forums) remove them entirely until they have a way to fix them.ConclusionIf you are looking for a game that can help you pass some time and is casual, then Gauntlet is definitely the kind of game to lead to a night of fun. If you are looking for something more robust and long-term then this is not the game you are looking for; I would suggest another Action RPG such as Path of Exile or Diablo 3.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Completed the game in a four player group.It's Gauntlet. Monster spawners well... spawn monsters and you kill those monsters while using keys to open doors and collecting treasure. It does that aspect of Gauntlet very well and the game is pleasing visually, although the enemies lack variety in terms of design.The individual classes themselves are interesting and while it feels a bit odd not allowing more than one person per class, they make the game interesting. Each of the characters has a focus; the warrior has strong single and arched melee damage output and can take a few more hits than the others, the ranger has high mobility and very high single target damage output at range, the wizard has a variety of AoE's and utility spells and the valkyrie is a well rounded class with tanking tendancies.Aside from the cosmetic costume pieces, the only way to customize your character is through "relics", which require potions found while exploring the level in order to use. However every character gets access to the same relics, which reduces a bit of the impact that your choices make. The variety of effects available is interesting, but with short durations, or low damage output, they don't really have as much weight in gameplay as you might expect. The worst decision as far as I'm concerned in regards to relics is that while it takes a substantial amount of gold to fully upgrade a relic, you do not get potions (the items needed to actually USE the relics) during boss fights, at least not on normal difficulty. That would be one time that you would definetely want to bring out all of your character's potential, only to find them somewhat crippled.It's not a bad game by any means, and there are far worse titles that you could spend 15-20 dollars on. You just might not find anything that really wow's you.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Looking for a fun, multiplayer arena brawler for friends?  Then move along.  There are far better ones out there.Gauntlet was about frantically running around a maze, fighting off the oncoming hoard of enemies, and trying to seek an exit.  Gauntlet Legends was about exploring stages, over the top attacks, huge bosses, and playing as a chicken.New Gauntlet is about walking around muddy-brown areas that all look the same, getting into one locked arena after another until you reach the end.  Occassionally you have to run from Death and his wonky hit box.  Seriously, though.. all previous Gauntlets are bright, gaudy affairs.  This one is all browns and greys.Most egregious to me, though, is that the game can't detect my PS2 Dual Shock 2 controller.  That's not that it detects it and won't let me remap buttons, but that the game says "is this a 360 controller? No? Then there is no controller".  Which is a load of crap in the modern world of PC gaming.And while spell slinging as the Wizard can be fun, there's a game out there that can do it better (Magicka).  In fact, any good point I can think of about Gauntlet is done better by another game.
