												This game is definitely fun to play with people. I'm glad they remade the game because sometimes its nice to just co op a dungeon crawler with a friend. I wasn't fortunate enough to play the original Gauntlet but this one is pretty solid. The controls are comfortable to get use to. I have not tried playing with an actual controller for any character yet so I can't speak for that. The graphics are great. I've only come across a glitch once. A friend and I were doing a run and we cleared the room but the door didn't unlock so we inevitably had to restart but I've only encountered that once. I don't see much point in spending the money on armor but the items used can come in handy, preferably better to hold off on using them till the final dungeons.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Gauntlet is a reboot of the 1985 classic arcade game. The 1985 version was memorable for having four characters: Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf. Many people pour quarter after quarter to play this game since it was so addictive. The four characters are back with the same abilities that will remind Gauntlet veterans of what it was like back in the day.This game offers modes in single player, multiplayer, and four player co-op. You will have to complete three floors of dungeons in each coliseum to unlock new group of floors. The dungeons are diverse enough and you can accidentally shoot foods like in the original. It does get tedious going through the same dungeons after dying and using up skull coins to get a new life. Once you run out of skull coins you will have to start from the first floor regardless of the floor you were in when you died. So, there are no save points on any floor.Gauntlet also tries to be a little RPG by including Masteries. The Masteries represent the progression of the character you have chosen to play. Believe it or not, dying many times is considered an achievement. Other achievements include taking a lot of damage and using specific moves more than others. It looks to me like the character progression turns out not to be that important since the game is about shooting your way through the dungeons.The gameplay is interesting when playing co-op or multiplayer. You can shoot each other by accident with friendly fire and that can cause some interesting friction between the players. The layout of the dungeons contains many cranks that you can turn to be able to advance to other parts of the dungeon. It is necessary to get used to being attacked by packs of monsters. In many cases you will have to destroy shacks that summon the monsters since destroying the shacks is the only way to keep more monsters from coming. Sometimes the sorcerers add to the challenge by regenerating the health of a shack with their staves and it will be up to you to kill the sorcerer before destroying the shack.The controls are easy enough to understand: they are as simple as WASD and the mouse. Playing with ranged characters such as the Elf and the Wizard take more practice than playing with characters that fight in close quarters. I think Gauntlet is more fun when playing either multiplayer or co-op than single player.The people who experience the original Gauntlet will find this reboot entertaining because of the classic characters and the diverse dungeons. However, if you are a diehard RPG fan looking for deep character customization and progression, you may not like Gauntlet as much as the Gauntlet fans. I think that it is best experienced with other players in multiplayer and co-op modes. The single player mode feels a little boring. This reboot looks better than previous iterations of Gauntlet games that were made after that 1985 original.My Score: 7/10

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												This should have been a hit and full of nostalgia for me, I played the original arcade game back in high school and enjoyed later iterations both in the arcade and on consoles but this version is not very good.To start with, why on Earth can you not use a native resolution of 1920x1080? In this day and age it's inexcusable to not let us do so. LCD monitors are not meant to be played in sizes other than native, it makes the screen slightly blurry and if you have a monitor like mine it will tell you that every time you start the game. The lack of resolution options alone is enough to kill this game but it also has poor voice acting, the close-up models and especially the Valkyrie look terrible (one can argue that she does not need to be the 'uberbabe' she was in previous versions but at least make the close-ups look decent), the keys cannot be rebound which is another bone-headed move, and as you can see I did not play all that much but the dungeon design is limited and uninspired. Gauntlet was one of the best coop games ever made, and the newer versions like legacy were amazing and despite the simple controls and mechanics were a lot of fun and the dungeons were well done and exciting, this game's only real positive is that at least the various abilites you can use are varied by class, although the wizard can be fiddly and he is much like playing magicka. Unless they patch the resolution at the very least, don't waste your money on this major disappointment.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Gauntlet and Gauntlet legends were some of my fav games as a child much like many of the other players on here. The community in gauntlet is great, the game is pretty fun and can be played local, online and local/online mixed co-op which gives it a thumbs up from me, and the endless mode is great fun. It's ultimately the greatest nostalgia party game in my opinion for 20-40 year olds (even older or younger it doesn't discriminate). I remommend getting a party of your friends who enjoyed it as children with you and doing a local co-op game together for the best experience.I do have some cons however, nothing that can really be helped though. The Story mode is fun however not incredibly replayable and quite short, the game is quite buggy and wb will not be updating the game and/or making a sequel ever as production has finished according to forums I have been on regarding it. Add to this playing by yourself is actually terrible for some strange reason (perhaps the loneliness) I would reccomend 2-4 players.Despite this I have had an enjoyable time playing and would rate the game an 8.5 out of 10. I have played many revamps of gauntlet and this is gauntlet how I most fondly remember it. Thanks WB

												เกมนี้ออกแนว Shooting Zombie มากกว่าแนว Diablo เพราะยืนจั่วไม่ค่อยได้ เพราะตัวเราบาง ศัตรูตีเราไม่กี่ทีตาย ต้องพยายามไม่ให้โดนเลย ไม่มีระบบ Dodge ที่ศัตรูอัดแล้วสุ่มวืดเกมสนุกสำหรับคนชอบแนวนี้ แต่ละตัวละครมีสไตล์การเล่นไม่เหมือนกัน เล่นตัวอื่นก็สนุกคนละแบบชุดที่ให้เปลี่ยน แค่เปลี่ยนลุคตัวละครที่เล็กเท่ามด แทบแยกไม่ออกว่าเปลี่ยนชุดแล้ว ชุดไม่มี status อะไรด้วย ใส่เท่ๆเฉยๆเกมนี้ไม่มีระบบ level แค่ทำ Archievement ได้ก็จะได้อัพสเตตัสบางส่วน สิ่งที่จำเป็นคือเงิน และราคาสกิลและชุดก็ราคาสูง ทำมาเพื่อให้เล่นซ้ำหลายรอบกว่าจะซื้อทุกอย่างได้ครบระบบออนไลน์ร้างมาก เหมือนไม่มีคนซื้อเล่น เพราะ search ไม่เคยเจอ ใครไม่มีเพื่อนก็คิดเผื่อเรื่องเล่นคนเดียวด้วย

												A fantastic revamp of a fantastic classic.Gauntlet is quite possibly the most fun I have had killing skeletons, orcs, deamons and the like.With four (five with dlc) characters to play, who all play differently, you can enjoy hours of slaying.Or, better yet, hop in with your friends and really start harming bodies.With the Slayer Edition, this game has gotten even better. number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Gauntlet (Slayer edition) is a modern remake of the classic hack and slash game many people played in arcades and home systems. Besides being 3d, characters now have gear and special abilities that can be purchased with the gold you find in each dungeon. There are also boss fights and “death” makes a return as a nag character in several levels. Multiplayer is pretty much the reason to own this game and they managed to carry forward the absolutely ruthless competition from the original. You will be sprinting to steal gold and deny food to other players all the while prioritizing your own survival as Gauntlet is more of a competitive co-op game than a friendly one. It’s kind of like playing Monopoly where all your friends end up hating each other by the end of the game.The game itself is pretty short and can be completed on normal difficulty in less than 5 hours, leaving the only reason for playing it further to grind for gold to buy all the abilities and cosmetic items. Most useful abilities are very, very expensive which means that during a single playthrough you will be stuck only using a few of them. The dungeons are randomly generated, though, meaning there is at least some replayability to be found. I recommend waiting until the game drops back to it's sale price of around $5 to really get your money's worth.

												Game is great.Don't get me wrong it has flaws and if you were a fan of the original or the remakes and updates you will find enough similar things in this game to make you smile but not enough to feel like a carbon copy of what came before it.Netcode is great as well.As far as leaderboards go, WB have wiped it once but if you are used to steam you know that any non-vac leader board has been hacked...Except for Sanctum. Maybe that game was too obscure but it is the only game (and I own a lot!) that I have seen with a non hacked leaderboard but I digress. If you want to have fun with you and some friends, this is the game! Be catious when joining randoms though as you can grief in this game pretty easily I'm afraid.Sound, music, controls, they are all good or great and the fact that each class plays radically different is amazing! I was skeptical at first but it really works well giving true variety rather than palette swapping.Hope you enjoy."I've not seen such bravery!"Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

												I have played Gauntlet since nintendo. I wouldnt exactly call this remake nostalgic.    This is fun for a little bit if you have friends that own the game who are cooperative. alone its not fun, and quick match is really bad in just about every way imaginable. my gf and i beat this game in 6 hours while lollygagging. content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of the Action/Adventure Classic, Gauntlet. Gauntlet was released onto Steam on September 23, 2015 by Developer Arrowhead Game Studios and Publisher WB Games. The current version is the final version known as, Gauntlet: Slayer Edition(NOTE: This game was NOT reviewed using a key provided by the Developer and/or Publisher, it was a game I purchased for my own account)Video Review:


YouTube™ Video: Gauntlet: Slayer Edition Review - Steam 

			Views: 127		

			Join the Echo Army ► http://bit.ly/1KD1iv3 Twitter ► http://bit.ly/1LiIQ59 Facebook ► http://on.fb.me/1M0Comd Buy Gauntlet: Slayer Edition on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/258970/...		

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:Oldie but goodie brought to the new era. GREAT Multiplayer fun. Pricey at $20, but often on sale. 4/5The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:Chances are, you may be familiar with Gauntlet and don't really need me to run it down. It is at it's best as a 4-player experience, combating waves of enemies as you make your way through the Gauntlet. Classic 80's gaming. Frankly, when this was originally released onto Steam, some people didn't like it. I did, but then I am kind of an old gamer. The Developers worked long and hard and took into consideration a lot of community feedback, and this shows. This is why I wanted to touch on it now. I have been asked quite a few times, recently, about this game. Really, they knocked it out of the park! What we have in the final "Slayer Edition" is a really solid game that would be tough to improve further upon. The solo is the only relatviely "meh" part of the game. Really, it's a fantastic Multiplayer experience. My friends and I play this often, it's one of our go-to's. Pick your lass, and take on the mobs of enemies swarming after you as you make your way through the dungeon. Our favorite is the new Endless mode, where you simply keep going level after level after level until your party falls. the graphics are awesome, and the sounds superb. The voices for the players are a great touch, as is the snarky narration. This is a plus all the way around if you have some buds to play with. It is often available for VERY cheap around the web, particularily Bundle Stars. This is easily a 4/5 with the solo campaign being the only real drag on the overall score. Grab this one on sale, get a 4-pack for you and your friends. You will not regret it. Happy Gaming!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of HearingOverall Rating: 8/10Gameplay Rating: 8/10Accessibility Rating: 9/10NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).  If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!General GameplayGauntlet is a single player or co-op experience!  This tribute to the older games in its lineage reawakens the fun, top-down dungeon crawling, horde-destroying genius of the original games.Though a bit linear and slightly redundant, Gauntlet is still entertaining in both single and co-op modes.  The Colosseum mode brings together 4 players in classic arcade fashion.The achievements in Gauntlet come for both good and bad events, such as collecting gold or dying, and all make your character just a little better.ReplayabilityAs a co-op game with friends, however, Gauntlet's outstanding history shines through and the game becomes fun, amusing, and challenging.Additional replayability comes from trying to complete the game and all achievements with all of the character types.  If you're a completionist, you may enjoy trying to get this one done.  Just bring a friend!General AccessibilityAccessibility OptionsGauntlet has sound settings controls for master volume, music, effects, and dialogue, as well as captions (subtitles).When you start the game, it goes straight to the main menu, so you can set captions on before any events happen.For gamers with mobility issues, Gauntlet's primary controls are game controller, but it works with keyboard and mouse just as well.  All keys can be rebound to suit your needs.Subtitles & CaptionsCaptions in Gauntlet are great!  Gauntlet is not a very dialogue-rich game, so most of what is said is flavor text, but it all seems to be there.Pros:- Captions for characters are colored according to that character's color (green for elf, for example), and captions from the evil mastermind leading the gauntlet are white.- Captions are easy to read in large font across the bottom of the screen.Cons:- Captions do not indicate who is speaking by name.  Only a *minor* problem because they are colored.Chatting/CommunicatingGauntlet supports in-game chat and colors text according to which character you're playing.---Visit Games Reviews for the Deaf/HoHhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/gamereviewsforthedeaf

content:

												I remember playing Gauntlet Legends on the Dreamcast like it was yesterday. Vibrant colors, outdoorsy environments and good ole' local multiplayer options.Years later and we get this game, it takes a more darker approach with more features - underground dungeons, caves, with a more matured art style. Add some upgrade components and online multiplayer. However, it keeps that same fun-factor by engaging us in addictive gameplay and dark/sarcastic humor.I feel like I could play this game forever and not get tired. There are 4 characters (5 if you purchase the Necromancer dlc) and each character feels totally different changing the experience.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												My previous review for this (Not Recommended) listed it's many faults and was 59% agreed with so I can't be entirely wrong about it!!Much of it's criticisms are addressed in the 'Slayer Update' but are they successful??Good NewsThey removed the need to do 3 levels at-a-time - that was pretty-much universally hated so it's no surprise it's gone and that's a good thing.  They also reworked the progress system to be less linear - it's now easier to avoid the obvious 'junk upgrades' and you can customise your character to your preferences, sooner.Bad NewsNone of that really changes the fact that the game isn't really that great and isn't really that much fun to play - or that you'll run out of content pretty quickly.Single Player remains mostly horrid (the Elf is still the only class which feels like it was intended to be soloed) Multiplayer remains a mixed bag because the variability of the classes is still there - you still need people playing certain classes - and playing them well - to get anywhere.  This isn't a game you can just 'have a laugh' with (ironic when it's coming from Magicka's developers!!)They also messed around with the camera for some reason - it's 'lazy' in the way it follows you now - it's also harder to see which way to progress in the 'chased by Death' levels (and harder to make-out some secrets) - no idea why they did that, it just feels broken - maybe it IS broken?SummaryIf you player it before and didn't like it - you MIGHT like it more now - but don't expect a miracleIt remains a flawed game tho - it just lacks fun factor, lacks a hook to make you want to progress and lacks much content to progress INTOHey ho - top marks for trying to fix it - maybe the next game will do better again, certainly this is a better foundation.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Between the original on Sega and this one, there hasn't been a great leap in game play development. There will be those who argue with me on this but I feel a lot more could have been done with the environment to make it a more inclusive game for the player. I'm personally not recommending this game but you may find a perks that suit you.Gauntlet is a story of four brave heroes that go into dungeons searching for treasure. They undertake a great task of the gauntlet (onslaught of enemies) in order to achieve their richest of dreams. As players progress through levels, some enemies may simply be hiding behind doors or will keep spawning when obelisks appear. When these obelisks appear, they must be destroyed in order to stop enemies from spawning. There are four classes to choose from. The first is warrior (Thor) who is an up close melee personal type. He has a run charging ability (RT), very effective in close combat with his basic attack (X), heavy attack (Y) and his special (that needs to charge every time after use) attack can be triggered with (B). He has fourth bars of health and can take the most damage of any class. The Valkyrie (Thyra) class has the same controls (less brute force, more speed) but her special launches her shield at opponents. Additionally, the player can use her shield with the right stick to block attacks. Her health consists of only three bars. The wizard class (Merlin) has a vast amount of abilities to choose from (nine to be exact). By combining ice, fire and electricity the player can go nuts with a wide range of attacks. Some include ice "kamehameha", fireball bomb drops and a big electrical ball thing that can shock a bunch of opponents. Some spells will take some time to charge up but other spells can be used in the mean time. The archer (Questor) is able to fire multiple arrows at one time. He is also able to roll through enemies without harm and it's recharge time is a lot quicker compared to other class abilities. Questor has a charge shot available that will deal more damage as his attacks do not do a significant amount. There is also a DLC character available but I really think it should have been included in the original game. I find it ridiculous they are charging for an extra character (especially for the games price). The classes are given a decent amount of varying attacks but I find a lot more could have been done to make the player more excited to play those classes. In other words, more attack variances would have been appreciated as it would combat repetitiveness of the game. The variety of enemies is decent at best as some enemies will have you on your toes trying to defeat them. Loot in game shows up in reasonable amounts but if your low on life, it's sometimes hard to get back into the game. You'll be playing a lot more defensive (especially with more players) as health isn't a significant resource in the game. Not only that, your fighting with 3 other people to get it. There are barrels of explosives available to displace or destroy in order to defeat enemies but the game doesn't go over and above that when it comes to breakable objects. Sure you can break a vase and even break your own food. Unfortunately, no walls or rails can be broken with force. The maps themselves are alright and they really try to keep the player engaged with floor traps or jump beacons. Sooner or later though, you'll find yourself struggling to keep playing.The graphics are decent to say the least and the sounds are alright. Players may taunt in game and use some dialogue to communicate to their fellow player to hurry up. Dialogue isn't exactly diverse but you'll hear the players pipe in once in a while. The head guy in charge of the Gauntlet will also chime in once a while with his corny jokes.Overall, if you're a hardcore Gauntlet fan you may like it (or may like it for the fact you played in on Sega). I personally find this game too much of a grind and if I'm not playing with friends, it isn't exactly fun. Even when I do play with friends, we don't often play past a level.RATING : 6.95/10Gameplay C+ Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface C+ Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability B- Overall  C+ScreenShots : Merlin is using his ice beam while the necromancer is reviving dead enemies

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Nothing like the original game and hardly what is advertised. Gameplay consists entirely of moving from room to room, being locked in and then fighting waves of enemies before proceeding to repeat the cycle. Bosses are annoying puzzles and gimmicks. Weapons and armor are purely cosmetic. Potions are now used solely to power relics. What little 'upgrades' there are come from "perks," which are small bonuses awarded for grinding for hours. Which is what this game is. A mediocre grind. Relics are a waste of gold. Some don't even work properly. Armor is cosmetic. There isn't anything worth spending that hard earned gold on.-Boring, repetitive gameplay-Bad boss design-Bugs that will mess with your game-Lack of items or worthwhile character progressionThe only thing this game has in common with the classic Gauntlet is the name and the four character archetypes.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												Pros: +Great co-op game, fun to play with just one other person+Nostalgic feel of old Gauntlet games (not perfect, but still)+Easy to pick up, and there are some complex combos you can pull off as wizard+Runs smoothlyCons:-Really short campaign (<8 hours)-Poor story in campaign (plz hire storytellers I had no attachment to the story at all)Overall: Gauntlet is a fun game in terms of gameplay as long as you're with a friend. I never felt like I was grinding and I genuinely looked forward to playing it every night with my bud. However, the campaign was very short, and the story itself could have been told better by a 4-year old. Nothing about the story was interesting, and it was just a very "next dungeon, kill, next dungeon, kill, wash, rinse, repeat" kind of experience. Great for passing time with friends, not great as a campaign-based adventure.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Gauntlet is a special game series to millions of people, stretching across several generations.  But this isn’t a history lesson or a trip down memory game; it’s a review of the newest incarnation of Gauntlet. Let us start off with the FACT that it is $20.00, a lot of the hate this game gets for being too small or not enough content. For the price this games give a very good amount of content and with the newest update giving us a free arena mode is just icing.Gauntlet is made to be played with friends, and not just randoms you find when looking for an online match through match making, but with real friends, friends you can grind with, friends that are just as likely to act on their vendetta as they are to just let it go, friends you can curse at one second and give grats to 5 seconds later. If you play Gauntlet with friends you’re going to be hard pressed not to have one hell of a good time. It begs to be played like 1996 start on easy play all the dungeon’s rooms on easy and work your way up to unfair, because that’s where the fun is had. Gauntlet is fun plain and simple... well as long as your group accepts the rolls of their chosen character because they are unbalanced as hell. It would be a complete waste to describe what the issues are as the developers are still changing things around, but it bares saying that you’re not going to complete the game on unfair without an Elf & Wizard. The Dungeon’s are fun and quirky especially the when diving around in the dark looking for treasure , dodging fireballs flung from angry volcano or just running from the grim reaper. The games looks nice and has a clever retro option in the menu to let you crank up the nostalgia. Issues with the HUD getting in the way have been addressed in the v1.1 update. The games play is solid but the Valkyrie, Warrior & Elf play best with a controller, and the Wizard is a powerhouse monster when played on a keyboard with macros set up.In the end Gauntlet is a grind fest and that’s okay, on unfair it will take a full cooperation of your entire party to finish the game and it’s a killer great challenging good time. And definitely worth your $20 and if you have friends go ahead and get the 4 pack. Gauntlet just don’t go paying $5.00 for the necromancer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												This review is aimed at older players of the Gauntlet games.While this game resembles Gauntlet games in a superficial way, it doesn't really play like a classic Gauntlet game.  At best, this is either a game inspired by Gauntlet, or a clone of Gauntlet, but in my opinion isn't truly worthy of the name.  I cannot recommend this game to anyone familiar with older versions of Gauntlet (especially the arcade versions) for the reasons which follow.Building on the clone-of-Gauntlet idea, in my opinion, there are games older than this one that play better and look better.  Either of the Torchlight games, and by extension the second Diablo game (which is the only one of those that I played, TBH), are good examples for making this point.  Also, any of the Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale games, as well as Temple of Elemental Evil and Pool of Radiance, would work, and the latter two were panned pretty badly.  Even the older versions of Gauntlet are better and even more immersive than this.On a related and not-so-minor note, the game is choppy even at the lowest graphic settings.  This is simply unacceptable, when I consider both all the clones of clones of games coming out these days (especally on the pay-to-win platforms like Android), and the fact that so many games seem to emphasize graphics over gameplay and content these days.  The game really doesn't bring much in terms of graphics as it is--I addressed that already, and I won't belabor that point any further--so I can't imagine why this problem would have gone unnoticed.The keyboard controls are goofy and inconsistent among the characters.  I could probably get used to using WSAD-style controls on this game, except that having only four directions to move (yes, dear reader, you read that right) really takes away from the experience.  It gets worse, though.  The wizard has a completely different set of controls to get used to (except for movement), compared to the others.  I have no problems learning controls, but couldn't the wizard have been made to play closer to the other character types, rather than awkwardly fumbling through different spell schools?  Worse yet, the controls are not customizable.  If I could have modified the controls, I wouldn't even be griping about it.  To be fair, I didn't try using my controller to see if the experience is better; on the other hand, considering that I lost interest in the game content and graphics, I didn't see any point in bothering with the controller.In conclusion, while there are people who might enjoy this game as is, it cannot be rightly considered a true Gauntlet game.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I'm going to be honest. I bought this expecting Guantlet Dark Legacy. What I got was Guantlet: Magika Edition.Honestly, I don't have any problem with Magika but the fact that this game has absolutely no stat system just ruins it. It's sad attempt at creating some sort of replay value or reward system is just a ridiculously long grind. For example, as a Barbarian I need to kill 20,000 mummies in order to do +10% more damage to mummies. Or I need to take 200,000 points of damage to have an increased HP regen when dropped below 30%. This is not leveling. If I wanted to play a grindy game, there are hundreds of others. If I wanted to play Magika, I would play Magika. Literally every room you enter follows the following formula:1. Kill 3 or 4 mobs.2. Tomb spawns.3. 2nd Tomb spawns.4. Kill both Tombs.5. Get key6. Open up wall.7. Rinse and Repeat.Additionally, there is a "death" level every 2nd act where all you do is constantly run away from a being that will instantly slay you. If they wanted to make a game that was similar to Guantlet, why not just remake the damned Guantly Dark Legacy on the n64? I'm almost certain that is what "most" of us wanted. Overall, I wouldn't say that the game is not fun, however, I will say it was not what I expected, nor what I wanted. This game has a total of 7 maybe 8 hours of gameplay with a friend or two. It had the potential to be so much more but it isn't.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I played this game by myself.  It's entertaining, but not satisfying.  Playing with just 2 people magnified this games fun, and the more you have the more of a blast it is.  For people like me who favored Gauntlet: Dark Legacy or Legends, this game is missing the RPG elements.  There's no boosting your base stats, no increasing your health, and magic isn't so consistent.  This game is more dependent on each class playing differently, so picking who you like and their skills is much more vital.Overall, it's fun with friends.  Don't got friends?  Skip this one, LAN and online are both good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I was really excited about this game when I first heard it was coming out. I finally picked it up and played for about 2 hours and was done. This is the EXACT same game that sacred 3 is. We shunned Sacred 3 for being boring and dropping no loot and the like but this game gets a pass!? I can't wait until developers stop catering to peoples nostalgia and actually make something new. You can take an old franchise and breath new life into it, look at Tomb Raider.    This game starts off assuming you've played the older games and has the whole " I'm not gonna tell you what this does. " mentality that plagues a lot of games lately so they can say they're not holding your hand. I remember just having a good time when I played the older ones, nothing was rocket science it was just good ol hack and slash. Then I played the wizard for a smash and was just like Why!? Why does his mechanics have to be so wierd and complicated!? Also I get that the co-op is the shining force of the game, but that doesn't mean people don't ever play single player. If you do play single player the game does not scale for single player it just throws huge waves at you until they can get one hit( which translates to about 3-4 hits because you get bounced around like a ping pong ball) while your trying to take down these shrines, almost mocking you and laughing because your friends were'nt around at the time.    Your character is not very nimble either as the move I thought was supposed to atleast get you out of sticky situations has a second and a half start up and goes about six feet in front of you (I'm looking at you Valkyrie) so what's the point? I got tired of the reaper mechanic after the first time I saw it. It's not a very hard mechanic to deal with it's just an annoyance like someone sticking the tip of a feather in your ear every couple of seconds. Another negative is the fact that EVERYTHING DOES NOT HAVE TO BE A COMPETITION! The game goes out of it's way to not let you play who want in a multiplayer game with starngers, which I could over look I guess if it fits the story and all. So why am I fighting everyone for gold and food? This is not fun at all. I want to fight with you not against you, if I wanted to fight against you I would play STREET FIGHTER!    This game does have some good things about. The sound is top notch and makes the combat feel good and hefty. The characters all play very different which is very good. Also...That's all I got. You can't get 1080p either. Basically this game falls victim to the same ol crap. Developers made a game to tickle your nostalgia, thought to themselves that frustration means challenge and does absolutley nothing new. If your one of those gamers that think everything was better way back when and has a nice thick pair of rose-tinted glasses on your night stand then this game is for you, but if you were looking for a rebooted game from the past that was going to BUILD from the the classic itself then no..no I can't reccomend this game at all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Honestly, the game delivers exactly what I expected from it with what I've seen in the trailers and various other gameplay videos.It is a bit short, having only 27 levels and 3 bosses (3 levels per door, 3 doors per 'world', and 3 worlds.. + 1 door each world that is strictly a boss fight). An endless mode somewhat in vein with the original game that this one is meant to reboot would've been awesome... but for the price, I still think it's a pretty good old-school arcade dungeon crawler that harkens back to a more innocent time in my life.It might have played it a little safe when compared to the original 1985 arcade game, and I can understand why... but I liked it for what it is.I'll admit, so far I've only played solo. I imagine it's best played with friends... and I don't mean a PUG. With any luck maybe I can talk my brother and a few others into giving it a spin.EDIT: As of April 2015 I'm finding it hard to recommend this. I still stand by my claim that the game is really fun for what it is, but the utter lack of content leaves it downright forgettable in the long run. There are only so many times you can play through the same thing before it starts feeling both tedious and monotonous. For me, that ended with about 3 times.. granted, all solo plays, but still.So yea.. changing my recommendation because I'm not seeing a future for this at all content-wise. And that's a real shame to me.EDIT 8-12-2015: Well, they released a free update for the PC version of the game to coincide with a PS4 release. I played it for a few hours.. and I can't explain it, but from what I remember before, it feels like it plays much better than it used to. I'm still not used to relics being separate from potions, and having a completely separate potion ability.. but that will probably come in time. I also haven't really tried any of the new weapons and their attacks.I also don't remember the updated take on the Gauntlet II theme being there in the previous version, so when I first heard that... man, I was taken back a couple decades or more.However, the big thing for me is that endless mode is now a thing. The stages are a bit simple and linear, and every few of them is a 'Death chase'.. which is a mode I'm not exactly crazy about, but endless is still nice to have.The stages of the campaign itself have received changes in numerous areas, so it's actually kinda fresh to even play through that again.. which was surprising to me. It's also nice that the 'arena' type levels are optional (at least that first one anyway.. that's as far as I made it really before quitting).The hub area is gone, however, replaced with a rudimentary map style system. It's nice because it allows you to access stages on their own instead of in sets of three.. but the look and feel of the map system is very basic.The devs have acknowledged the sort of lackluster camera in this version, so hopefully that will get fixed soon. It's somewhat annoying living on the edge of the screen until you get to one of those 'encounter areas' where it pans out and more or less centers itself.Anyway, it still plays like a modern arcade game at its core.. and it was pretty much meant to, given the title and game it was meant to reboot. It's a fun hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler, and now that it has an endless mode.. it's very hard to not recommend if you're into that kind of thing.

												Really nice reward system. Gives you rewards for doing well by, for example, blocking a specific number of projectiles to give your shield the ability to reflect ranged attacks. But also gives you rewards for stuffing something up, for example, dying more than 3 times in one level reduces your loss of gold on death by 6%. AND these rewards are permanant, which is always nice.I recommend this if you have people you can play it with or you don't mind dropping in mid-level with some randoms.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												BUY IT ON SALE! This is NOT a straight "NOT recommended", but it's very hard to recommend to anyone with the content that's in the game as of this writing.Gauntlet, at the time of this writing, reminds me a lot of what Payday 2 was like at launch. A great concept but very lackluster in content and as a result it's very grindy in its gameplay. Gauntlet is fun enough, but extremely repetitive, has very little variety in weapons, skills, enemy types and situations - walk into room, get locked in, enter monster-closets, kill the same monsters from last room, destroy monster closet, move on, rinse and repeat - and there are a few bugs and other issues that need looking after too.Overall a decent game if you have some Co-Op buddies to play with. Just don't expect anything other than a very monotonous and somewhat imbalanced hackfest with rather miniscule amounts of actually meaningful loot. But I can't help but feel that it could've been priced a bit lower considering what you actually get in the game.Personally, I'd rather recommend Lara Croft And The Guardian Of Light. It has more gameplay variety overall and you can get it dirt cheap nowadays. Of course, it only has 2-player Co-Op (the upcoming sequel offers 4).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												So here's my review SO FAR.I'm an old time fan of Gauntlet Legends, having dumped some small portion of my childhood into the game... Hours of replaying challenge levels to unlock new heroes, finding all the secrets. Owning that bloody dragon with your beasted out mage... Unlocking the wizard dude who had full stats and not beleving your eyes.... With that said every Gauntlet game since then has lacked everything that was good about Legends. Slayer Edition finally creates a decent rendition thus far of Gauntlet Legends. Pro's - Classic Gauntlet/Dungeon Crawl view. - Seems to be more "mechanics" to more battles than previous gauntlet games.- Improved combat mechanics. Takes away the "hold X" concept of the came.- Equipment/Upgrades give it a more RPG feel rather than just level progression (like the old ones).- Easy to play with friends, online and offline (local co-op).- Each character is pretty diverse in their contribution to the field. Con's- Only 4-5 Characters - Hard to get a random online game that is immediatly enjoyable. - Lacking on customization for characters. Progression could be more substantial. I feel as though a game that has made a name for itself like Gauntlets, could have taken just a little more time to add a lot more to this game. Accommodate the casual and the casual pro.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												If you remember the good ol' days of Arcade Gauntlet then you'll be right at home here. It plays fantastically when either by yourself or with up to 3 other friends. Though the multiplayer team aspect is where the game really shines through. Each class is distinguished with a different and unique skill set that works well both independently and when combined with others.Graphics and soundwise, this game is typica 3Dl top-down goodness with sometimes commical, sometimes cringy voice acting.All in all, Gauntlet is well worth picking up, be it on sale or full price. The ability to link up other friends with 360 controllers to sit and play on the couch gives it the edge over many multiplayer titles that confine you to your own machine these days.Pick it up and mindlessly have fun, but remember... Don't shoot the food.

content:

												This review is aimed at older players of the Gauntlet games.While this game resembles Gauntlet games in a superficial way, it doesn't really play like a classic Gauntlet game.  At best, this is either a game inspired by Gauntlet, or a clone of Gauntlet, but in my opinion isn't truly worthy of the name.  I cannot recommend this game to anyone familiar with older versions of Gauntlet (especially the arcade versions) for the reasons which follow.Building on the clone-of-Gauntlet idea, in my opinion, there are games older than this one that play better and look better.  Either of the Torchlight games, and by extension the second Diablo game (which is the only one of those that I played, TBH), are good examples for making this point.  Also, any of the Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale games, as well as Temple of Elemental Evil and Pool of Radiance, would work, and the latter two were panned pretty badly.  Even the older versions of Gauntlet are better and even more immersive than this.On a related and not-so-minor note, the game is choppy even at the lowest graphic settings.  This is simply unacceptable, when I consider both all the clones of clones of games coming out these days (especally on the pay-to-win platforms like Android), and the fact that so many games seem to emphasize graphics over gameplay and content these days.  The game really doesn't bring much in terms of graphics as it is--I addressed that already, and I won't belabor that point any further--so I can't imagine why this problem would have gone unnoticed.The keyboard controls are goofy and inconsistent among the characters.  I could probably get used to using WSAD-style controls on this game, except that having only four directions to move (yes, dear reader, you read that right) really takes away from the experience.  It gets worse, though.  The wizard has a completely different set of controls to get used to (except for movement), compared to the others.  I have no problems learning controls, but couldn't the wizard have been made to play closer to the other character types, rather than awkwardly fumbling through different spell schools?  Worse yet, the controls are not customizable.  If I could have modified the controls, I wouldn't even be griping about it.  To be fair, I didn't try using my controller to see if the experience is better; on the other hand, considering that I lost interest in the game content and graphics, I didn't see any point in bothering with the controller.In conclusion, while there are people who might enjoy this game as is, it cannot be rightly considered a true Gauntlet game.

It's somewhat annoying living on the edge of the screen until you get to one of those 'encounter areas' where it pans out and more or less centers itself.Anyway, it still plays like a modern arcade game at its core.. and it was pretty much meant to, given the title and game it was meant to reboot. It's a fun hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler, and now that it has an endless mode.. it's very hard to not recommend if you're into that kind of thing.

												Pros: +Great co-op game, fun to play with just one other person+Nostalgic feel of old Gauntlet games (not perfect, but still)+Easy to pick up, and there are some complex combos you can pull off as wizard+Runs smoothlyCons:-Really short campaign (<8 hours)-Poor story in campaign (plz hire storytellers I had no attachment to the story at all)Overall: Gauntlet is a fun game in terms of gameplay as long as you're with a friend. Nothing about the story was interesting, and it was just a very "next dungeon, kill, next dungeon, kill, wash, rinse, repeat" kind of experience. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Gauntlet is a special game series to millions of people, stretching across several generations.  But this isn’t a history lesson or a trip down memory game; it’s a review of the newest incarnation of Gauntlet. Let us start off with the FACT that it is $20.00, a lot of the hate this game gets for being too small or not enough content. For the price this games give a very good amount of content and with the newest update giving us a free arena mode is just icing.Gauntlet is made to be played with friends, and not just randoms you find when looking for an online match through match making, but with real friends, friends you can grind with, friends that are just as likely to act on their vendetta as they are to just let it go, friends you can curse at one second and give grats to 5 seconds later. If you play Gauntlet with friends you’re going to be hard pressed not to have one hell of a good time. It begs to be played like 1996 start on easy play all the dungeon’s rooms on easy and work your way up to unfair, because that’s where the fun is had. Gauntlet is fun plain and simple... well as long as your group accepts the rolls of their chosen character because they are unbalanced as hell. It would be a complete waste to describe what the issues are as the developers are still changing things around, but it bares saying that you’re not going to complete the game on unfair without an Elf & Wizard. The Dungeon’s are fun and quirky especially the when diving around in the dark looking for treasure , dodging fireballs flung from angry volcano or just running from the grim reaper. The games looks nice and has a clever retro option in the menu to let you crank up the nostalgia. Issues with the HUD getting in the way have been addressed in the v1.1 update. The games play is solid but the Valkyrie, Warrior & Elf play best with a controller, and the Wizard is a powerhouse monster when played on a keyboard with macros set up.In the end Gauntlet is a grind fest and that’s okay, on unfair it will take a full cooperation of your entire party to finish the game and it’s a killer great challenging good time. And definitely worth your $20 and if you have friends go ahead and get the 4 pack. Gauntlet just don’t go paying $5.00 for the necromancer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												This review is aimed at older players of the Gauntlet games.While this game resembles Gauntlet games in a superficial way, it doesn't really play like a classic Gauntlet game.  At best, this is either a game inspired by Gauntlet, or a clone of Gauntlet, but in my opinion isn't truly worthy of the name.  I cannot recommend this game to anyone familiar with older versions of Gauntlet (especially the arcade versions) for the reasons which follow.Building on the clone-of-Gauntlet idea, in my opinion, there are games older than this one that play better and look better.  Either of the Torchlight games, and by extension the second Diablo game (which is the only one of those that I played, TBH), are good examples for making this point.  Also, any of the Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale games, as well as Temple of Elemental Evil and Pool of Radiance, would work, and the latter two were panned pretty badly.  Even the older versions of Gauntlet are better and even more immersive than this.On a related and not-so-minor note, the game is choppy even at the lowest graphic settings.  This is simply unacceptable, when I consider both all the clones of clones of games coming out these days (especally on the pay-to-win platforms like Android), and the fact that so many games seem to emphasize graphics over gameplay and content these days.  The game really doesn't bring much in terms of graphics as it is--I addressed that already, and I won't belabor that point any further--so I can't imagine why this problem would have gone unnoticed.The keyboard controls are goofy and inconsistent among the characters.  I could probably get used to using WSAD-style controls on this game, except that having only four directions to move (yes, dear reader, you read that right) really takes away from the experience.  It gets worse, though.  The wizard has a completely different set of controls to get used to (except for movement), compared to the others.  I have no problems learning controls, but couldn't the wizard have been made to play closer to the other character types, rather than awkwardly fumbling through different spell schools?  Worse yet, the controls are not customizable.  If I could have modified the controls, I wouldn't even be griping about it.  To be fair, I didn't try using my controller to see if the experience is better; on the other hand, considering that I lost interest in the game content and graphics, I didn't see any point in bothering with the controller.In conclusion, while there are people who might enjoy this game as is, it cannot be rightly considered a true Gauntlet game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Honestly, the game delivers exactly what I expected from it with what I've seen in the trailers and various other gameplay videos.It is a bit short, having only 27 levels and 3 bosses (3 levels per door, 3 doors per 'world', and 3 worlds.. + 1 door each world that is strictly a boss fight). An endless mode somewhat in vein with the original game that this one is meant to reboot would've been awesome... but for the price, I still think it's a pretty good old-school arcade dungeon crawler that harkens back to a more innocent time in my life.It might have played it a little safe when compared to the original 1985 arcade game, and I can understand why... but I liked it for what it is.I'll admit, so far I've only played solo. I imagine it's best played with friends... and I don't mean a PUG. With any luck maybe I can talk my brother and a few others into giving it a spin.EDIT: As of April 2015 I'm finding it hard to recommend this. I still stand by my claim that the game is really fun for what it is, but the utter lack of content leaves it downright forgettable in the long run. There are only so many times you can play through the same thing before it starts feeling both tedious and monotonous. For me, that ended with about 3 times.. granted, all solo plays, but still.So yea.. changing my recommendation because I'm not seeing a future for this at all content-wise. And that's a real shame to me.EDIT 8-12-2015: Well, they released a free update for the PC version of the game to coincide with a PS4 release. I played it for a few hours.. and I can't explain it, but from what I remember before, it feels like it plays much better than it used to. I'm still not used to relics being separate from potions, and having a completely separate potion ability.. but that will probably come in time. I also haven't really tried any of the new weapons and their attacks.I also don't remember the updated take on the Gauntlet II theme being there in the previous version, so when I first heard that... man, I was taken back a couple decades or more.However, the big thing for me is that endless mode is now a thing. The stages are a bit simple and linear, and every few of them is a 'Death chase'.. which is a mode I'm not exactly crazy about, but endless is still nice to have.The stages of the campaign itself have received changes in numerous areas, so it's actually kinda fresh to even play through that again.. which was surprising to me. It's also nice that the 'arena' type levels are optional (at least that first one anyway.. that's as far as I made it really before quitting).The hub area is gone, however, replaced with a rudimentary map style system. It's nice because it allows you to access stages on their own instead of in sets of three.. but the look and feel of the map system is very basic.The devs have acknowledged the sort of lackluster camera in this version, so hopefully that will get fixed soon. It's somewhat annoying living on the edge of the screen until you get to one of those 'encounter areas' where it pans out and more or less centers itself.Anyway, it still plays like a modern arcade game at its core.. and it was pretty much meant to, given the title and game it was meant to reboot. It's a fun hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler, and now that it has an endless mode.. it's very hard to not recommend if you're into that kind of thing.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I'm going to be honest. I bought this expecting Guantlet Dark Legacy. What I got was Guantlet: Magika Edition.Honestly, I don't have any problem with Magika but the fact that this game has absolutely no stat system just ruins it. It's sad attempt at creating some sort of replay value or reward system is just a ridiculously long grind. For example, as a Barbarian I need to kill 20,000 mummies in order to do +10% more damage to mummies. Or I need to take 200,000 points of damage to have an increased HP regen when dropped below 30%. This is not leveling. If I wanted to play a grindy game, there are hundreds of others. If I wanted to play Magika, I would play Magika. Literally every room you enter follows the following formula:1. Kill 3 or 4 mobs.2. Tomb spawns.3. 2nd Tomb spawns.4. Kill both Tombs.5. Get key6. Open up wall.7. Rinse and Repeat.Additionally, there is a "death" level every 2nd act where all you do is constantly run away from a being that will instantly slay you. If they wanted to make a game that was similar to Guantlet, why not just remake the damned Guantly Dark Legacy on the n64? I'm almost certain that is what "most" of us wanted. Overall, I wouldn't say that the game is not fun, however, I will say it was not what I expected, nor what I wanted. This game has a total of 7 maybe 8 hours of gameplay with a friend or two. It had the potential to be so much more but it isn't.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Background: I remember playing Gauntlet on the Arcade Box in "Random Shopping Mall my parents took me to in the 90s."Combat Mechanics: Level based Top-down enemy killing mayhem!  Classic Arcade Class choices, from Wizard, to Barbarian, to Elf. All Direct ports from previous installments of the Gauntlet Series, but with some extras!  Classes have special abilities and can equipment different equipment pieces to give them extra flair and combat options.  Fast paced gameplay with a Susvival Tower mode for those inclined. Necromancer with DLC is balanced and can hold her own just like the other Base Character options.Party Banter is a nice addition and the Dungeon Master Voiceover really sets a great mood for the game.Comparison to the MAME Arcade version: Obvious grapihcal improvements, fluidity of controls, and 4 play Co-op on the Steam network makes finding companions easy.Final Thoughts: It's a great blast from the past party game. It goes on sale in 4 Packs every once and a while.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												I'd give 2 thumbs up if I was able here. This game is fantastic and true to it's heritage.You do "level" slightly but it's slight. The weapons and armor you have are only for vanity to show your level of completeion to the random groups you set out into. The PUGs can be great and they can be devistating, but such is the internet. You never know who you are going to run into. Is it a clever elf or some wizard stroking his wand? The first floor of any area will tell you, and sometimes even the first room.I highly recomend this game to any one who was a fan of the original, or anyone who likes fun Co-Op play. Normal is, well, pretty easy. Not easyenough to through in your peggle champ and have them excell but if they ever touched a Nintendo or Arcade machine when younger they'll do just fine. Hard is a good challenge and Unfair is brutal but rewarding when you finally take down the level or boss. Each room can feel like an acheavement in Unfair mode. The bad, you can't join in while game is in progress, and if you DC, then you are just out unless the group wants to start that set over to invite you back.Match making, you can't do it by character so if you want to be something specific odds are you'll have to host, and if we all host then no-one is going to join heh. Playing with friends is the best way to go but you can still find some fun with the random pick up groups from the match making system.Each character is unique. In their strengths and weaknesses. They are completely different play styles as well.I sugest trying them all out at least for a little while. I've been on a hard Warrior rampage but I'm going to switch over to the Elf next.Have fun and enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												For all those who have played the co-op of the original Gauntlet late into the afternoon or evening at a buddy's house, this game isn't going to invoke that feeling of nostalgia; it's just not the same game. It feels shorter than its predecessor and there's just not as much going on. The "floors" or levels of each chapter are very formulaic in their design with nearly identical enemies each time; first there's a classic dungeon crawl, then there's a "race to the finish" and then you have a brawl to kill the enemy spawners. And the final floor is always a boss fight. A lot of the replay value will be from increasing the difficulty and challenging yourself and your friends.This review may make the game sound unappealing, but it's pretty fantastic for what it is, which is a $20 reboot of a classic game. It has its flaws, but it also has its own charms which shouldn't be overlooked. For those of you who just want a way to spend some time online with friends and have a good time killing monsters, it's a relatively cheap pick-up and worth its price.

												When I first saw this game come to Steam I thought "It's another Magicka." I like Magicka, but it was so wrist intense. I was happy to find that this is not like Magicka, my wrists were pleased. You can play as 4 different characters, 5 if you feel like spending 5 bucks on one of them (not worth it). You have to collect 3 shards from 3 different 4 section gauntlets, which you will see when you enter the main area. The game has good graphics, runs smoothly, but can get a bit repetitive afterwhile. By the end of the game I found myself wanting to slap the voice actor for the ranger and the almighty BAIN (Payday 2 reference) voice that popped in all the time as we played. Overall, it was worth the price we paid for it, which was under 10 bucks. I would wait for a sale if it's over that.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												I'd give 2 thumbs up if I was able here. This game is fantastic and true to it's heritage.You do "level" slightly but it's slight. The weapons and armor you have are only for vanity to show your level of completeion to the random groups you set out into. The PUGs can be great and they can be devistating, but such is the internet. You never know who you are going to run into. Is it a clever elf or some wizard stroking his wand? The first floor of any area will tell you, and sometimes even the first room.I highly recomend this game to any one who was a fan of the original, or anyone who likes fun Co-Op play. Normal is, well, pretty easy. Not easyenough to through in your peggle champ and have them excell but if they ever touched a Nintendo or Arcade machine when younger they'll do just fine. Hard is a good challenge and Unfair is brutal but rewarding when you finally take down the level or boss. Each room can feel like an acheavement in Unfair mode. The bad, you can't join in while game is in progress, and if you DC, then you are just out unless the group wants to start that set over to invite you back.Match making, you can't do it by character so if you want to be something specific odds are you'll have to host, and if we all host then no-one is going to join heh. Playing with friends is the best way to go but you can still find some fun with the random pick up groups from the match making system.Each character is unique. In their strengths and weaknesses. They are completely different play styles as well.I sugest trying them all out at least for a little while. I've been on a hard Warrior rampage but I'm going to switch over to the Elf next.Have fun and enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												first of all, this game has a whole lot of undeniable flaws.shared camera makes sure you'll lose yourself and/or break your aim in a sea of mobs and projectiles regularly. the fact that your character isn't highlighted in any way compared to your teammates doen't help much. UX part of graphic design was not a priority apparently - a lot of objects do not suggest their interactivity, like some explosives.the shared loot system works as long as you play with your friends only.the title screen suggest Gauntlet is best played with gamepad. however, playing with gamepad is somewhat handicapped since there's no crosshair in this mode.finally, the "story" is rudimentary, the music is boring and the voice acting is unremarkable.however, I still recommend to play this game, as it features really fast-paced thought-out gameplay, with a number of diverse classes for any spinal cord reaction level. the only thing is that class system doesn't offer big rewards for your skill. you could faceroll as a warrior with much less buttons to achieve twice the wizard's result. necromancer is also very strong, since it's a dlc character.there is a room and possibilites for teamwork, however it's not required to complete the campaign on normal.each class features an upgrade system, which potentially can offer a wide range of gameplay styles along with high replayability.tl;dr a few fun hours of gameplay to spend with your friends.

Posted: September 18, 2015
												Its "ok". I feel that this would be a great game to buy while its on sale and play with some friends. There is no "level up during gameplay" you don't increase attack speed agility or health by leveling up through each stage kinda a bummer. The warriors seem at an unbalanced disadvantage since they are always up close in the fight and constantly draining health, and when you die, your gold is up for grabs by the other players. Ranged characters can kite from a distance without too much trouble. The customization is minimal at best, yes you can buy a total of maby 20 items right now per character.  These characters arn't as dark as the previous gauntlet, and I was hoping for simply a darker game. I'm playing it on hard and it is certainly that and not a bad game but unless your playing with people you know I think Diablo 3 would be a better investment. And whats this you have to "purchase" the necromancer? Eh..  I kinda feel like all the characters in this game should be unlockable. Not sure if the edge of having a necro is worth it even on sale.

												This game is a lot of fun and really stands out in small-scale multiplayer. There are some fun call-backs to the original, but nothing relies on having played them. My nephews, who weren't even around for the originals, have a blast playing this with me. It's fun to get a group of four together to take on the hordes of monsters thrown your way. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												[edit]8 September 2015 - changed recommendation from yes to NO!I am extremely disappointed in the direction the dev team has taken with this game.  What was at first an emminently playable, fairly true to the original (in a modern, developed sort of way), fun game has become, at best, a copycat cartoon dungeon game.Desperate attempts to repair damage done by past changes (that didn't need to be made) have ended with a Frankenstein game whose playability is limited by walls that can't be seen around and a foppish feel to the enemy caricatures that used to at least have the potential to evoke apprehension upon first meeting them.  Changes to Masteries mean that current achievements have little to no meaning, other than "did you grind or not" and "are you still grinding?"The single up point to a game with a literally invincible Death character who spawns and de-spawns at intervals on every other level of the campaign adventure, is the endless mode, where you fight until you die in an arena-like setting.At present, I'd pick up the game for $5 or so and maybe you'll like it, maybe not - but at least you're only risking $5.  To be fair, I have friends that like the endless levels, but to a man, they all think low of the campaign anymore.If you're an achievement hound and you're willing to spend less than 50-75 hours on this game, this title is not for you.  If you're a Diablo-type fan who wants the screen centered on your character, this game will outright infuriate you.  If you're an oldschool Gaunlet fan from back in the days of actual video arcades, maybe you'll like it... but don't go in looking for the game it's titled after.I'm sad to say this game has declined on my list to a NO recommendation.  Below this edit is my original review, which was rated 3/7 helpful votes before I changed the recommendation.[/edit]This game is FUN from teh start - an old-school hack-and-slash, that is - to me - a modern-day combnation of the feel standing in the arcade almost 20 years ago, and sitting in front of Diablo for the first time.Low level casting monsters can kill you...Low level swarms can kill you...Generators can spawn both......and you can beat the crap out of them right back.A word to the wise on two points:1.) Look for the guide by Hastur on casting Merlin's spells (there are three spells per setting, and it's hard to figure out without a guide, or at least it was for me)2.) Conserve your keys!  Before facing a door and swinging at the destructible pot or box right in front of it, remember that your swing will carry you forward into the door if you're not careful, thus wasting a key!HAVE FUN!

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I played Gauntlet Legends on the N64, and if you've played any other Gauntlet game, you'll enjoy this reboot.Gauntlet's mechanics, in terms of fighting enemies, attack styles, and movement are fantastic. It doesn't feel clunky, and enemies are predictable but not boring. Each class is bound to fit your playstyle in some way. Even though when compared to Gauntlet Legends, each character doesn't have quite the array of abilities and items to use, this version of Gauntlet makes it work.As far as the story goes, don't expect much. The story of Gauntlet isn't really one that matters all too much to the game, and there isn't much there. The character's personalities come out a bit in the banter between them at level starts, which is entertaining.Gauntlet's worth picking up, and dropping a 4-pack for you and your friends. It's bound to bring a lot of fun and tense moments (especially on unfair mode).

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Awful.  Just awful.  I can not recall the last time I have played such a shallow game.  As soon as you start the game you can see that from the starting hub area there are three areas to pick from that open up over the course of the game.  Three. That's it.  This was almost like having the developers at Arrowhead Games slap me in the face, bend me over the original Guantlet™ arcade cabnet, and start brutally♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥my♥♥♥♥♥ spiting on me when done and then emptying my wallet which contained $20.00 and running off into the night.  Seeing this beginning hub room was as like having the developers say "LOOK YOU♥♥♥♥♥♥ LOOK HOW SHORT THIS GAME IS! AND THAT IT! THATS ALL THE CONTENT.  ITS LIKE 5 HOURS LONG AND YOU PAYED FOR THIS! AHAHAHAH".  This game made me feel like a prisoner at times, only playing the game so I could get steam trading cards and acheivements and basically just be done with it since it was short.  This game made me feel like I was being held in a concentration camp and the Nazis where Arrow Head games.  Thats right Arrowhead games are basically Nazis and Gauntlet is Auschwitz.  By the way when you beat the game the final boss is shown in a shity concept art painting screaming "ARRRGGGGGG!" and thats it. Credits roll and the game ends.  As a quick side note its worth noting that I fatal error-ed once right at the end of a level, got stuck on collision boxes and one of my friends fell below a level and died, never to re-spawn again until we got to the next level.  Great game!  What a god awful Diablo, tryhard, short, uninteresting, unreplayable, bad looking, glitchy, unfunny, badly voice acted, piece of ape♥♥♥♥♥♥  In short this is a game, and you can play it, most of the time, I pushed keys on my keyboard which created actions, movements, animations and attacks my character in the game would preform, so at its basic level it functioned, but so did Auschwitz.  In conclusion, seriously don't buy this game, you will thank me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												The game really lives up to its expectations and appeal for Gauntlet fans without over complicating things.  I'll keep my review short and objective.  The pros and cons I've found below:Pros:- No level grinding trying to find better gear if you just want to jump in a game and not wonder if you are the right level and geared up.  Those games are great but sometimes we just want a quick session of fun!- Game sticks to its roots with all four original classes.  I've found the Elf the easiest to use and stay alive.  Merlin is cool too but my reflexes are not fast enough to dish out those nice spells.  So whatever your playstyle is whether it be magic, ranged combat, or melee it's all here!- Level design is neatly layed out so you don't get lost.- Graphics are surprisingly great.- Plenty of achievements to invest in mastery of each of the four classes.- Nice spells with the potions.  You can carry max of 5 potions so you can equip two pieces of gear before entering dungeons.- Great local co-op fun too.  My mom and I connected two conrollers and had a blast.  She is new to games so she fought melee while I covered her with my Elf.  It is quite a blast if you have other local players to with.  Brings back memories of 4 player co-op at the arcade!Cons:- Tried quick match for multiplayer and was unable to join a match.  I also opened my game to public but during entire session no one joined my game.  This might be a glitch.  I'm sure this will be fixed soon.  This is really my only con so far.Great hack'n'slash fun for everyone whether you are playing for 10-15 minutes or several hours!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I think I picked up this game for just under $6 USD. For that price, it was worth it.The controls are very tight. The graphics are very well done. Multiplayer 'just works'. There aren't a ton of people playing, but enough to find most game types at any hour of the day.There is a bit of a grind...when you beat levels you get to keep the gold you picked up. This also drives competitive gold stealing between players which, surprisingly, adds to the game instead of makes it more frustrating. With your gold you can buy and upgrade a few basic items. Those items do not do anything other than some special power which can only be used if you have potions -- which only exist for the stage you collect them on (stages consist of several levels, four stages to each major act, three major acts make up the entire story of the game). For that reason, the items are very useful -- but not everyone even needs them. One guy with a highly upgraded lute can use all the potions you find as effectively as splitting it up between the players.There are also some 'level ups' you get which seem more like achievements than levels. They are different for each of the five characters. They consist of things like, kill x number of creatures with a certain attack, die x number of times, lose x amount of health, collect x gold, etc. They grant that specific character special passive abilities such as doing more damage, having shorter cooldowns, etc. However -- the benefits are slight...2% here 5% there...what makes a player able to handle the hardest difficulty mode is more to do with player skill than anything else. All said and done, the game feels much shorter and less grindy than previous Gauntlet titles -- but the controls are WAY nicer and the graphics and animations are of a much higher quality than any prior gauntlet I've ever played.It makes for a fun 'pick up and play' casual arcade game that is fun for shorter periods of time. It has more replayability than I expected for having so few levels, but even so, there really are very few levels.Thankfully, the replayability comes from trying to perfect your handling of your character. And each of the five characters do seem to play rather differently and are pretty well balanced.The Elf is good at sniping, bombing large groups of mobs and roll dodging. The Valkyrie has a powerful shield and some dash and shield throw abilities that make her good at quick skirmish attacks.The Barbarian is able to charge and do some larger AOE attacks and kick more butt with melee.The Wizard is challenging, as you have to memorize 9 different key combinations to switch to the appropriate spell at any given moment. If you screw up, he can die very quickly as he doesn't have a 'basic attack.' That being said, he's incredibly powerful if played correctly. And Lilith (some kind of necromancer) can only be played if you bought the expansion which costs about as much as the base game. She seems to have some fantastic abilities that seem poached from the other 4 classes along with the ability to summon a bunch of undead as meat shields. One tactic I found very useful is with Lilith and the Wizard. Lilith gets into a corner near a monster spawner and summons undead. The mage teleports behind the undead wall and then casts frost beam at the spawner. Frost beam does more damage the longer it is active and since you won't have to run away because you've got a nice meat shield you knock down spawners very quickly. For ~$6 this game is worth it. The lack of levels and content is a big negative. No user created levels was a mistake as Gauntlet is supposed to have a billion levels...and this would have been a way to do it. This is a shame because the graphics, and fluid controls of the game means it has a very solid base to build from.

content:

												I was worried that this remake would not live up to the classics... Many hours I put into Gauntlet 1 and 2 on the arcade machines down at the fish-and-chip shop as a child, so when I saw they were doing a remake I was skeptical, but I have to say - despite certain changes they've made, this game is pretty damn fun.It CAN be played as a single-player experience which ends up being a very arcade-themed version of Diablo, really. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Let me begin by stating that I have never played any of the original Gauntlet games. Now, with that out of the way let me begin:I freaking LOVE this game! I am so glad I've found this beautiful little gem. I simply adore this style of game and takes me right back to my youth. The choice of classes (of which there are 5 at time of writing) are simple yet diverse and upgradable. It has everything a dungeon crawler should have: Monsters, boss's, xp gain and loot. The graphics are nicely done and the soundtrack adds to the atmosphere.One highlight of this game is its replayability. Each difficulty adds to the game and the more you do the more chance of acquiring those all important achievements.If you're a fan of Isometric, hack 'n' slash ARPG games then you simply MUST buy this game! You owe it to the developers but more than that you owe it to yourself.To think that Gauntlet came out a little over four months ago the devs have been busy, adding a new class to the game and a Colosseum mode which pitches you against wave after wave of enemies. This is a game that will keep on giving. If this new iteration of Gauntlet eventually includes all content from previous Gauntlet games then the future of our modern Gauntlet looks very promising indeed. I can't wait to see what happens next.8/10
