content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												It's the rare good reboot of a classic arcade game. There is a lot which reminds one of Diablo, but that's probably because Diablo owes a lot to the original version of this game. The upgrades in detail, character differences, lite-RPG features, gameplay, etc. are all very nice. Probably the best part. though, is the local multiplayer (which I'd like to see on more games like this). There are no negative points that I have seen so far. For the price, it's a must-have if you want a local co-op game for your PC.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												This game is good, but with a few improvements it could have been great.  The biggest issue seems to be a terrible lack of content, the game can be completed in just a few hours if you really stretch it and take your time.  The problem is the lack of levels, there are 3 types of arenas each with 3 floors and a boss floor, this gives you just 9 levels and 3 boss fights.  This issue was sort of addressed in the last update adding a colosseum mode where you can battle waves of enemies for new rewards. They also added a new character which cost 5$ to unlock, now this seems like a slap in the face, that's 1/4 of the games price for an extra character.  For a game with such a small amount of cntent it should have been free but I could have justified paying 1-2$ for it but not 5$.  Cons aside this game does provide a good time especially if you have friends to play it with.  This game is all about co-op, it even has couch co-op which was a huge plus for me.  Each character has unique abilities and masteries which makes playing as each character fun and different in some way.  The masteries for each character are what give this game it's replayability factor.  Completing the masteries make your character stronger which make earning the rewards from higher difficulties that much easier.  If your expecting something like Gauntlet Legacy you will be disappointed, but if your looking for a classic arcade style Gauntlet to play with friends then this is the game for you.  I personally don't think that it's worth the 20$ price tag, so I would recommend waiting for a sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												I really like Guantlet. I remember cursing at the original, and couldn't resist getting this. I'm really on the fence about the thumbs up/down rating...and I'm going to give it thumbs down because some basic changes are needed to make this game what it should be. The intro is a tutorial that cycles through each character with steps that must be completed to progress. This intro foreshadows the faults in the game to come. There is a clear lack of direction in the tutorial, and this is underscored by a madness-enducing introduction to the Wizard's controls. Don't give up; there are guides that explain Merlin...yeah...The controls are wonky at best. The game claims to be best while played with a controller. I agree that it felt best with the controller, but I would have preferred the option to set my own keybindings. I know there are workarounds for this, but this is a basic option for PC games and when it's not there it makes games feel like a lazy port. Thankfully keybindings can be set with a keyboard/mouse, but auto-aim mucks controls up a fair amount at harder difficulties and cannot be turned off.Merlin's controls are hilarious. I had to fight the urge to spin in my chair to change a spell as I felt I was doing everything but that. I'm sure practice makes perfect, or macros would bridge the gap...but like controller emulation...beyond what I want to do. Why, oh why, not utilize the mouse wheel to switch between spells, or lcontrol, tab, etc.? The problem is the controls are too limited. Limiting all actions to 4 keys (basic combat actions) on a keyboard really sucks.I wish the loadout equipment was beyond cosmetic...I really do. Thankfully the relics are quite usefull, and the masteries prove to be alot more useful than regular achievments of most games. It's like a limited skill tree that I wish was a little more than kill 80, then 8000; there could be more inbetween to make the grind between mastery levels seem less arduous.I always struggled with Guantlet and even just at the hard difficulty this game does not dissapoint. There is minor grind for gold, cosmetics (if your into that) and a decent grind for masteries...but none of those are really required. The game is fun, but the controls make the game too frustrating to endure for anything but short bouts, which wasn't the case for the original that this game hopes to compare to.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Thinking of buying Gauntlet? I have been playing it with 2 RL friends, and i have a few online friends i havent played yet with, and it has been a blast so far, completely worth the 20$. Do not buy this game to be a lone wolf, or play by yourself. Do not play this game if you are going to use the matchmaking system. Its decent, the system works ish. But there is no Communication  chat/voice at all in this game. Which is sorta cool feeling, but doesnt work out.If you play with some friends LAN style, or over a Voice chat, you will have endless fun. I have been setting World records with me 2 friends non-stop, feel free to check out some of my screenshots if you need to.The characters dont feel very deep at first, but the way the leveling up works...is weird but feels ok in the long run. You get some talents by playing naturally that add just the right amount of depth to make it feel balanced. Characters feel sorta balanced, Warrior might be a little subpar. Either way, if you're playing with friends you will have fun. Wizard is Hard but good. Valk seems great. I play archer, i love it. Mastery level you get just by dieing or killing. They are like ingame achievements that .... give you bonus's. It feels backwards to get a bonus to die less,... by getting killed but it works.Stats/records make things fun. The game feels a little short. probably 10 hours if you play normal. The difficulties are fun though, and the replay does feel fun.The relic system is ....alright? It could be tweeked. The game is exactly what you think it is though. And its a lot of fun. 9/10 if you have friends to play with. I'd like to see some additions and patches though.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I think I picked up this game for just under $6 USD. For that price, it was worth it.The controls are very tight. The graphics are very well done. Multiplayer 'just works'. There aren't a ton of people playing, but enough to find most game types at any hour of the day.There is a bit of a grind...when you beat levels you get to keep the gold you picked up. This also drives competitive gold stealing between players which, surprisingly, adds to the game instead of makes it more frustrating. With your gold you can buy and upgrade a few basic items. Those items do not do anything other than some special power which can only be used if you have potions -- which only exist for the stage you collect them on (stages consist of several levels, four stages to each major act, three major acts make up the entire story of the game). For that reason, the items are very useful -- but not everyone even needs them. One guy with a highly upgraded lute can use all the potions you find as effectively as splitting it up between the players.There are also some 'level ups' you get which seem more like achievements than levels. They are different for each of the five characters. They consist of things like, kill x number of creatures with a certain attack, die x number of times, lose x amount of health, collect x gold, etc. They grant that specific character special passive abilities such as doing more damage, having shorter cooldowns, etc. However -- the benefits are slight...2% here 5% there...what makes a player able to handle the hardest difficulty mode is more to do with player skill than anything else. All said and done, the game feels much shorter and less grindy than previous Gauntlet titles -- but the controls are WAY nicer and the graphics and animations are of a much higher quality than any prior gauntlet I've ever played.It makes for a fun 'pick up and play' casual arcade game that is fun for shorter periods of time. It has more replayability than I expected for having so few levels, but even so, there really are very few levels.Thankfully, the replayability comes from trying to perfect your handling of your character. And each of the five characters do seem to play rather differently and are pretty well balanced.The Elf is good at sniping, bombing large groups of mobs and roll dodging. The Valkyrie has a powerful shield and some dash and shield throw abilities that make her good at quick skirmish attacks.The Barbarian is able to charge and do some larger AOE attacks and kick more butt with melee.The Wizard is challenging, as you have to memorize 9 different key combinations to switch to the appropriate spell at any given moment. If you screw up, he can die very quickly as he doesn't have a 'basic attack.' That being said, he's incredibly powerful if played correctly. And Lilith (some kind of necromancer) can only be played if you bought the expansion which costs about as much as the base game. She seems to have some fantastic abilities that seem poached from the other 4 classes along with the ability to summon a bunch of undead as meat shields. One tactic I found very useful is with Lilith and the Wizard. Lilith gets into a corner near a monster spawner and summons undead. The mage teleports behind the undead wall and then casts frost beam at the spawner. Frost beam does more damage the longer it is active and since you won't have to run away because you've got a nice meat shield you knock down spawners very quickly. For ~$6 this game is worth it. The lack of levels and content is a big negative. No user created levels was a mistake as Gauntlet is supposed to have a billion levels...and this would have been a way to do it. This is a shame because the graphics, and fluid controls of the game means it has a very solid base to build from.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												It's Gauntlet, and Gauntlet is always best played with friends.Pros:-great multiplayer game, expect competition over who gets the most gold-easy to control and play-gorgeous environments-entertaining voice acting/well-written and fun dialog-really neat weapon options and unlockables for changing up/customizing gameplayCons:-color system of the past is gone/no multi-classes (in other words, no RED WIZARD and BLUE WIZARD, etc., just one class per team)-enemy variety is cool but missing classic monsters like lobbers and super sorcerers-clicky hack-'n-slash gameplay is arcadey and can ultimately feel shallow to people who aren't expecting it, or are playing aloneAll in all tho it's loads of fun with friends and definitely worth it, in my opinion. I spent hours upon hours playing Gauntlet II with my cousin when we were both little so I'm kind of a sucker for this stuff tho. Also, what I wouldn't give for a classic "digitized" announcer voice option. ﻿"Ｔｒａｐｓ  ｍａｋｅ  ｗａｌｌｓ  ｄｉｓａｐｐｅａｒ！"

												Gauntlet in the 80's arcade was fantastic fun.  There were usually lots of people around to join in on the fun, but for whatever reason this one just didn't hold the nostalgic trip I was looking for.  Don't get me wrong though.  If you're into gauntlet you definitely need to check this title out.  GREAT fun for some couch co-op when you have friends over.  There's LOTS of in game achievements to grab for each of the characters it provides.  There's bosses throughout and an end game boss too.  I found the Elf to be the easiest character to play as.  He's quick and ranged which helps with the mass amount of enemies charging your direction.  I only played the Slayer Edition so I can't comment on pre-2.0, but I've heard version 1.0 was a lot better and many people miss it.There's 30ish stages to play through and it does have online mp and couch coop.  It'll take roughly 6 hours to beat solo with one play through, but once again the coop is where it's at.  Grab it on sale.  Fun for a limited time.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Gauntlet: Slayer Edition is a remake of a classic arcade game by Atari from 1985 and was developed by Arrowhead during 2014. Basically a dungeon clawler, hack and slash videogame, Gauntlet's (extremely scarce) premise is about a group of heroes being summoned by a powerful wizard to overcome the challenges of the titular gauntlet to gain acess to a great treasure.Gauntlet can be played either by a single player or up to four, with each controlling a single hero. The main objective of the game, regardless of the mode chosen, is about to advance through the current dungeon till its end while destroying the enemies thrown at you and dodging the various hazards. The player can choose between five different heroes, each with his/her own strong suit and weaknesses, gear and abilities of choice:- The warrior is a heavy-hitter melee character capable of a great damage output, but he spots a worse mobility than the other heroes (althought his charge/evade move can knock enemies over)- The elf is a fast character who specializes into striking enemies from afar with his arrows and has the best evading manuver: his main weakness is however being extremely fragile if the enemies manage to catch up with him- The valkyrie, much like the warrior, is a melee-oriented character, but she's most effective in defence than in sheer attack power: her shield can block incoming damage and withstand enemy pressure while the other heroes do the damaging- The wizard is arguably the hardest hero to master properly: he can use a grand total of nine spells by mixing up his three elements. You can use one spell at a time and each has a single purpose: one spell is able to freeze foes in a cone in front of the wizard, while another will help him teleport out of harm's reach. As such, the wizard can bring to the party a lot of utility, but will be a load if misused, given he has poor speed and damage reduction- The necromancer (which is the content of a paid DLC and not available in the base game) is a hero capable to use both offensive spells and summoned minions to divert enemy attentionWhile riding Gauntlet's dungeons is important for each hero to watch out for food, which is the only way to replenish one's health. Should a character die, he/she can be brought back with a skull coin: such coins are available after a certain number of enemies has been killed by the party. If there are no coins available, the game is over and the dungeon must be repeated from the very beginning. Another important resource for heroes is gold, which can be used between levels to purchase additional gear for the heroes. Aside from the purely cosmetics purchases (which, truth be told, costs far too much gold each), a hero can purchase a relic (which gives him/her an useful activated ability), a talisman (which holds a specific passive ability) or a new weapon (since different weapons carry different activated abilities).The game has three modes. The story mode, which is somehow brief, is made of several mandatory dungeons plus some optional arena-like levels the players can run to gain more gold: the mode also spots unique but few boss characters who can be best described as puzzle bosses and are fairly challenging in their own right. The colosseum mode pits the players against waves after waves of enemies in a single arena map and is fairly challenging (to the point that even playing on normal difficulty will see your hero die in short order if you are not careful). The endless mode is instead, as the name implies, a mode where the heroes can navigate an endless stream of dungeons without any clear objective or end in sight: the challenge is about clearing as many dungeon's floors as possible. The dungeons and enemies you get to meet in this mode are basically entirely recycled from the story mode plain and simple.Gauntlet: Slayer Edition is, by any means, a nice hack and slash game which is extremely enjoyable if played with friends, but it suffers somehow by a very brief story mode, a basically pointless and redundant endless mode and an incredibly hard and not that anjoyable arena mode

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I loved the Gauntlet games when i was a young boy.We always played this game with a few people in the local arcadehall.I remember that the person who played the elf just had to die.So funny back then (and even now, hahaha)After some years the Gauntlet was revived in a 3D version on the first xbox and PS2 consoles.The games still are very fun and addictive to play but never (in my opinion) got the attention it deserves.Now, years later there is finally a new Gauntlet game.When this game was released it was riddled with bugs and the controls where a bit unresponsive at times so after some frustrating moments i quickly decided i was stopping and moving to other game horizons.After a few months and loads of patches and updates i tried Gauntlet again and now most real problems where finally solved.The best way to play is with some friends. Players can join in using internet and local couch co-op.Graphics are functional but for this day of age, nothing special.Sound is pretty decent and never get's annoying.Storywise there is not much there but that's not what makes this a timeless gameseries.The gameplay is good and fun. Just play this a while in multiplayer and if you have not played a Gauntlet game yet, you'll probably be hooked for a long time.I can honestly say that this is a game that i will never really get bored of.A few weeks ago a revamped Gauntlet Slayer edition was released that updates the game with loads of extra's.People who already owned Gauntlet got this updated version FREE.I would rate this an 6,5 out of 10 in singleplayer and in multiplayer about 8,6 out of 10.If you want a solid (multi)player game that is worth every penny it costs,There is no excuse not to try and buy this game.ps: Let the Elf die!! That should teach him/her to select the Elf. (older gamers will remember why.)

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I never played the original gauntlet but with that said growing up me and my friends would always play gauntlet legends on the n64 or at the arcade and we would later move onto gauntlet dark legacy on the gamecube. For me my favorite still after playing gauntlet 2014 is gauntlet dark legacy. The shear amount of characters that dark legacy had and the numerous levels that you could go thru were a treat and i still havent played as all the characters to this day. With that said i was setting my hopes for this game to be somewhat like that and well it isnt at all they feel completely different. Gauntlet 2014 is still a blast to play with friends. The problems being not that many levels but you get what you paid for here there is definitly 20$ worth of value in this game. Back in 2002 i believe i bought dark legacy for 39.99$ and if u compare the games they were worth the price tenfold. Gauntlet 2014 brings a new feature where you can choose your armor and runes which kinda act like skills but serve a better use for the potions then in previous gauntlets. The biggest problem i have with this game is only having four characters and having them color locked like why cant i be a red wizard or a green warrior that was one corner that shouldnt and didnt have to been cut. After spending about 5 hours with gauntlet 2014 i found myself and my friends wanting to go play dark legacy more than what was right in front of our face. Gauntlet 2014 is still a treat with freinds and if uve never played gauntlet before than this is a great buy but if you have fond memories of the older gauntlets u might be better having your friends over and enjoying whats been with us for the last 15 years. In the end Gauntlet 2014 is its own game and is fun with friends. if you and your friends are looking for a game to play that is cheap you cant go wrong and thats why i give this game a 7/10

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												People seem upset by the fact that this game is a "grinder," but I think that is what keeps part of the appeal of the game.  The main questline can be completed in probably 5-8 hours with friends playing on normal difficulty but the real fun of the game is in trying to do it an higher difficulties or solo.  The "grind" is related to the fact that each character has separate money, separate "masteries", and separate achievements for the colosseum.   The masteries being separated is somewhat of a pain because many of them involve killing several thousand enemies of different types but it makes the game feel more like an arcade game where youre simply trying to beat your previous scores and for completionists, these time consuming achievements give the game replay value.  My only real issues with the game are that WBplay, an optional feature, will not allow me to link my account nomatter what i try; this does not affect game play at all but prevents me from getting some free skins for the characters.  The colosseum provides more levels to test yourself against either alone or with friends, my only gripe with the colosseum is that they are established as "seasons" and once you miss a season you cannot try those levels again nor can you get the rewards.  I dont think there is a need for the season system to exist since this is not a competitive game and having the colosseum levels set up as a repository of challenges would probably mae more sense in the future.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Two very hun...<ELF NEEDS FOOD!>...gry thumbs-up! Oh, nostalgia. Brings back memories of ditching Ritchie Ponderosa's roller-skating party to waste $10 in quarters at the arcade there in the 80's. Boy was my mom♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Great evolution of the franchise makes the additions a welcome advancement to the series since inception./* generic 11/10_lulz review */Shot food, died of hunger. Came back to life on top of spikes and died again instantly. 11/10/* generic journal_lulz review */\\Day 1://Woke up in a dungeon. Some dude tried to sell me stuff but I had no money. I see a door illuminated with light. I step inside. \\Day 2://Stepped into a bigger dungeon. Found lots of gold. What's that? I hear shuffling coming from behind that locked door.  Oh good, I have a key.  Oh, no a swarm of mummies attack.  I kill them all and loot their corpses.  I sure can carry a lot of heavily-weighted gold for one man.  I find a turkey sitting in the old, musty dungeon.  I have no idea how long it has been sitting there.  I say f*** it and eat the turkey anyway.  What's the worst that could happen? I find a doorway that looks like the devil's mouth, so I do what any normal person would do and step inside.\\Day 3://The turkey is not sitting well at all.  I've pooped my pants and it is running down my leg.  The mummies won't stop and now there are spiders everywhere.  I really don't think I should have eaten that turkey.  I think I'm hallucinating.  I see an apparition appear before me. It is Death, and he is here for me.  I run my♥♥♥♥♥off trying to get away, but the trail of foul-smelling fecal matter makes it impossible to shake Death. He vanishes from time to time when the smell becomes too much even for him, but he is close on my stinky tail.  I finally manage to find another demon mouth and plunge myself inside of it.It couldn't get any worse now, could it?\\Day 4://Stuck in a room with never-ending ghouls, ghosts, and other assortments of the creatures of the underworld.  They seem to be coming from some kind of portal. So I blow it up.  When I do, two more take its place.  So I blow them up too.  Pretty soon, all of the creatures fall before my unwielding power and stenchiness. Gold appears from out of nowhere so I pick it all up. I must have over a ton of gold stored on my body somewhere.  My stomach lurches and makes an inhuman growl. I head for the exit but collapse onto the hard, cold granite floor. The last thing that I hear is my bowels letting loose one final time as the blackness encroaches.<!--ELF HAS DIED OF DYSENTERY-->...the moral of the story is never eat a turkey you found in the dungeon. You'll poop your pants.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												This game should not be what it is. The makers of Magicka, that ridiculous game of mages keying in button commands and blowing each other up and sometimes blowing enemies up ply their craft at Gauntlet, the age old and yawn-inducingly simple arcade game of throwing swords at hordes of monsters and hopefully not the food.This SHOULD be utter mindless drivel. Worthy of laughs when played with friends and not much else.But it simply is not. This Gauntlet has taken the concept of wading into a dungeon filled with thousands of enemies and honed it, tightened it into something beautiful. Hacking, slashing, charging, shooting, blasting, it all feels great, it feels tactical. All four (Plus one quite fun DLC character) characters have their own movesets and each of them play quite differently. Even when all you need to do is mash the attack button you always have a game of footsies to play with the enemies to avoid being surrounded, and you always have at least one or two brutally satisfying moves to whip out. The elf drops bombs and charges sniper shots. The warrior's heavy attack is best used sparingly, but his tazmanian devil spin does double duty to save him from tight spots and to just feel cool as you turn a bunch of enemies into red mist. The valkyrie's lance attack hits with brutally satisfying force. The elf tumbles, drops bombs, charges up power arrows, and can even fire bomb arrows. And the wizard... oh boy. He plays Magicka lite and, if you can memorize about a half dozen spell inputs, you can control the game. Freezing, fireballs, flaming dashes. He is not my thing, but it is always nice to have him.This is a real action game. Satisfying hits, enemies with windup attacks that must be dodged and dealt with. It's perfectly fun solo and even more fun with the game's breezy drop in drop out online coop. Just open your game to the world and you will pick up people signing up to play with you as you explore.The game itself is short, but replayable. Three difficulties, a colosseum mode for straight up combat. Each character has a perk tree that is only fed by grind, but beyond the easy early perks, very few provide a noticeable effect on gameplay. And the game itself is just fun to play. It invites just picking up every now and again and bashing some monsters, alone, with friends, or with random partners online.I wish I had not been so skeptical of Gauntlet when it released. Every preconception I had suggested that this game would never and could never be as good as it was. This one is truly a pleasant surprise.The DLC character is worth paying for too, if only as a backup to avoid joining a 3 man game with only your weakest character available to play.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												This is a modern take on Gauntlet from the Nintendo Entertainment System released in 1987, a game which was also very fun and if you have an NES, might be worth looking for.  You play as one of four classes (Valkyrie <3) , alone or with up to 3 friends, and make your way through difficult hordes of enemies in dungeons and fight massive bosses.  Dodge traps, discover secret rooms, gain new spells and armor through a shop at the main hub, and more.  This game definitely has some flaws.  The video settings are a bit lacking.  Also my computer has a hard time running it in certain areas, even though it doesn't look like a very demanding game.  However my enjoyment of the game has surpassed my annoyance of any problems it has, and I am hoping they are working hard to fix them.  It's definitely worth playing.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I have never played any Gauntlet game in my life but I knew what it was all about and when this one was announced it picked my interest immediately. It didn't disappoint.It carries that "arcade type of game" vibe with some modern concepts to spice things up. It won't generate random maps, which is a bummer for some, but others will find amusing to memorize all the choking points, barrel bomb positions, spawners, secret rooms... Just like an arcade game of the good old days. Gauntlet 2014 is an action game with some RPG elements. This is no Diablo. If you want to dodge an incoming attack you better get out of the way. If you want to block you better push the block button. There's no chance dictated by status here. You either do it or get hit and they hit hard. The game is quite a challenge.The four classes are well implemented and they are completely different from each other. The animations are good and the moves are consistent to the class. The way developers managed to make they work in sinergy during multiplayer, each playing its role, is commendable and it adds a lot to the fantasy setting and fun. This game solo is quite good. Play it online and you're going to have a blast. Gauntlet 2014 is a simple/deep kind of game. You pick the basics right away but it takes some time to trully master it.Graphically speaking its a nice game. It won't win any "best graphics of the year" prize but its not ugly at all. If you're like me, far from a high end PC, Gauntlet might be a good surprise. The same can be said about sound. The music is dynamic. Calm and enigmatc when no monster is around and tense for that moment you see a horde coming your way. Sound effects are also good. Clash of weapons, magic being cast, voices... They are all nice and add a lot to the overall experience. Talking about voice, some dialogs here are going to put a smile on your face.I see a lot of people complaining about lack of content and most of them have played the game for less than 15 hours and rushed to the final boss. Indeed, if you're looking for a huge amount of stages and all you do is push foward you're in for a disappointment but if you like games where you must trully learn a class to reach "suck my Yoda" type of mastery look no further. The game also offers some very lite RPG elements like relics that are basically skills you can use in battle, masteries that increase your character strenght and defense the more you play and some cosmetic equips beating the game on multiple difficulties. When you're done, master another class and have fun for more 20 or 30 hours.I'm having lotsa fun with this game but I do understand its not for everyone. If you exclusively like games that offer infinite ammount of random generated dungeons and/or deep and complex character development, stay away. This is not for you. If you're looking for a game with a gameplay thats simple and deep at the same time, addictive and most of all, fun, you can't go wrong with Gauntlet 2014.Uptade 10-dec-14:New content! Colosseum free!New class Necromancer!!! 5 bucks!!! (you know its cheap - you know you want it)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Don't let the rather drab, brown screenshots put you off; this is a game that is both dripping with personality and that is remarkably true to the original arcade experience while simultaneously bringing it bang up to date for a modern audience.It's not trying to be something it's not. It's not trying to be Diablo or any kind of RPG; it's trying to be a modern-day Gauntlet. And it's doing so remarkably well. The four characters all play in a distinctly unique fashion -- far more so than in the original game -- and in local co-op in particular it's just a joy to crawl some dungeons together, battling over the loot, the crown and the inevitable arguments over "who is the best" on the end-level summary screen.I couldn't say if it would be quite so fun in single-player as I haven't tried it as of the writing of this review, but if you have at least one friend willing to fight alongside you, I can happily give this a solid recommendation.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												As you can see, I recommend this game, but it comes with a few caveats.If you're wanting an experience similar to the classic Gauntlet games, or even like the newer 3D versions like Dark Legacy, this is probably not the game you're looking for. You want to go look at Hammerwatch instead. Trust me.That's not to say this is a bad game, but it has a lot of short comings, and many gameplay elements of Gauntlet have been dropped, some new ones added, and it just doesn't really feel like the Gauntlet I grew up with. Which to be fair, is one of my favorite games of all time. Both the classic versions and the 3D ones.Dungeon floors aren't randomized, and while I know this wasn't a feature in the other games in this series, in the current game market this just feels lazy. I'm already getting sick of running the same (very few) levels over and over with the only change being which character I play as. Secrets and the like are also mysteriously lacking.We might as well talk about those characters, actually. Each one plays differently, and not just in regard to how they attack or what skills they use. They fundamentally control different from each other. The Wizard, for instance, mixes two elements together to create one of a number of spells. The Elf plays similar to a twin stick shooter character, akin to Smash TV or Beat Hazard. The Warrior and Valkyrie are kind of similar, but the Valkyrie has the ability to tank, and defend the party with her shield.She's also very overpowered compared to the other characters (in my opinion at least) once you learn to use her effectively. A lot of people don't even play her as a tank, and instead spear rush nonstop, which does a lot of damage very quickly. This makes it easy to lead a game in points from having a really high kill score compared to the other players. This is especially true if they haven't learned how to use their character yet.Each character also has a set of challenges that come with them, which unlock little passive buffs when you complete them. Kill 2000 mummies, get +10% damage against them. Things like this. Progress is not shared across characters, so if you have been mainly playing as one class, then join a multiplayer game where that class is already taken, you'll be missing all the unlocked bonuses for that character, as well as any relics they have bought. There are a couple minor bugs and AI quirks (enemies can't walk under bridges that are on a higher level than them?), but nothing that is a huge issue. I've only had one instance of the game bugging out and putting me in a state where I could not progress because of a gate not opening as it should have.It's a co-op game, but not really. What I mean is that it is in your best interest (even if it's not the parties best interest) to hog everything for yourself, let other people die so you can steal the gold they drop, and generally act like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to people you don't know.  While I really don't have a problem with the game allowing that, it has never been how I played Gauntlet with my friends. You always do a lot better if you work as a damn team, even if your score won't be as high from being selfish. Joining online games is a real chore, and it usually takes me upwards of ten attempts before it finally joins a game without either giving me a timeout error or saying the game is already full.There's no way to communicate with the other players, outside of four nearly useless emotes that are mapped to the D-pad.  Maybe this was the intent, but when I can just shift+tab to talk to the people via Steam's built in chat, this just feels like an oversight and creates an extra step (and one that takes me out of the game) to offer advice. The biggest problem with not being able to communicate, to me at least, is that it is really bothersome to try to figure out which level everyone wants to do when starting a multiplayer game. Again, this isn't a bad game, but if you really want something like Gauntlet, go pick up Hammerwatch instead. Otherwise, I'd really wait for a sale for this one.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I do love the game.  While the fun hack and slash co-op feel of the original is wonderfully preserved, the new reboot adds new depth through diversifying the playstyles of the classes.  The in-game interaction between the 4 heroes who are old friends (since 1985) is endearing and nostalgic, the music and stages are beautiful.  Controls feel nice and fluid, and the difficulty levels are well balanced.  While many of the negative reviews are true (ie: short content, lack of communication features, need for better matchmaking), the developers of the game do monitor the forums for feedback. Bottom line is: it is great fun, and there's more to come.Edit (Dec 1, 2014): as of this edit, patch 1.04 had gone live, improving many features such as the matchmaking, in-game communication, and rebalancing the classes.  I recommend the game even more highly now.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												The nostalgia is strong with this one, I was ten years old in 1985 & my favourite game at the local Arcades was Gauntlet. I played this to death with my friends and this remake does the original justice. Another game from the same era was Smash TV, it involved kiting yourself around avoiding waves of incoming enemy's. There are many similarities between the two games, both involved avoiding zerging waves of enemies which created a high thrill "seat of your pants" gameplay. Gauntlet can be compared to many games including Diablo and other action RPG's though it is still very unique in its style. This was a genre defining game that has never been equalled and without doubt is a must play for all Action RPG fans. I give this remake a 9/10, it is very true to the original and that's what makes it great.WARNING: This is not a game for those who need Epic L00t as there is none. The gear you unlock by completing certain stages at different difficulty levels is purely cosmetic. Relics and Mastery levels add some abilities and increased power to your characters but these are the only none cosmetic customisations available.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												An excellent homage to the old school arcade game, this reiteration plays exactly like you would expect. You have four characters, each with their own skills and abilities, and you team up with friends to obliterate huge waves of enemies, all while splitting up (or fighting over) the spoils. The voice acting is very witty and entertaining for all the characters, and each character has "masteries" which you unlock by doing certain things in game, such as killing x amount of a certain monster, or even dying multiple times on a level. These masteries unlock subtle but useful passive abilities on that character, such as slightly increased damage, or a longer spawn protection. While rather linear, this is a great dungeon crawler game, especially with friends. And at a modest price of $20 (like Torchlight II), you can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I bought this game as a 4 pack thinking my friends would enjoy it (4 of us total).   However, we all found the game more tedious and annoying than enjoyable.   The reward system in the game makes you want to gouge your eyes out with a dull spoon.   They tie the relics to potions which don't drop frequently enough to make them useful.  You end up "saving" the few you do get to the point where they become useless.   A better system would be that the potions boost the effectiveness of your relics.  The relics if not boosted, would be on some timer.  This would give you the thrill of feeling like you had some nice power to use in tight situations, but not make the game seem too easy.   Having potions to boost the effectiveness would give you the option to save the power until a very tough fight or simply clean house when you had the boost active.  The other annoying detail is the destructibility of the healing and relic powering potions.  The tight quarters force you to use your powerful aoe spells to survive.  However, those same spells blow up your only means of a) powering your relics and b) healing yourself.  I found myself driven into a frenzy of madness.  You are slivers away from death, surrounded, and forced to use your only means of defense to blow up enemies and unintentionally, your salvation.   We all gave up before we could finish it since the joy was sucked out of the game with annoying mechanics and a terrible loot / reward system.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I was reasonably interested to hear that a new Gauntlet game was in the pipeline BUT at that stage I didn't know which pipeline it was in. I hoped it wouldn't be coming from the same one which has blurted forth the gaming equivalent of hot, liquid turds in the name of Gauntlet since the 1980's.It seems that instead of serving us up complete effluent they have instead managed some kind of plumbing tomfoolery which has resulted in the effluent being mixed with cool, pure water. The resulting fluid can fill a glass but it is possibly not a glass one would choose to drink from. Some of the benefits of the game...1) Graphics are nice and (vaguely) evocative of the original game. Nothing looks bad and the game runs well. Everything looks reasonable for an arpg, tbh. Fairly stereotypical but then Gauntlet was pretty much first on the block for this kind of thing. However, there is little to no variation within a dungeon "set", which isn't in line with the original, there are just themed "worlds" which are not unlike the crap we had to munch through with "Gauntlet: Dark Legacy"2) Multiplayer works well, netcode seems tight. Now that the "cannot connect to Gauntlet online" random messages have ceased thanks to a post release patch, the netcode works well. Compared to something like Magicka which is still, imo, in a broken "online" state, Gauntlet runs perfectly. No real problems to report, no lag issues as such. 3) It's a good game for a little while, especially for fans of the original BUT this only lasts a short time. One of the key factors of the original was that there were a lot of different dungeons pooled randomly from a larger set, many of which could be flipped and changed in ways by the game before they were presented to the player. No two playthroughs would be quite the same. This is not the case in the new version, with only a few levels being occasionally "flipped" but they're very familiar whatever way round you do them after a very few playthroughs.BAD POINTS1) Skill trees have been added but instead of making the game something one would return to in order to "level up" items etc we are presented with something that's nothing more than a skin buying interface (buying skins with ingame money does nothing to your character and they are barely visible) and the option to buy "spells" (more on these on point 2). You can collect more than enough money very quickly to buy all of these things. Also, each upgrade is NOT character specific, with only 2 skills being particular to each character. This is nonsense. It just means, basically, that you're endlessly playing the game to unlock more of the same stuff (unlocks do not migrate across characters)2) Spells are terrible. "Potions" in the original Gauntlet worked as "Smart bombs" which would destroy onscreen monsters, particularly "Death" (More on this explained in point 3) but instead of keeping them the same the developers saw fit to wangle them into some rubbish kind of "Special move" enabling fandango. Preposterous. So, basically, you have to have a potion in your possession to perform your Special move. This means players simply signpost points in levels, grind out enough potions then all just launch the same kind of devastating, battle winning special. This renders the game really boring and, as a direct result of how the game progresses coupled with this stupid idea, the "end of level" bosses actually get progressively easier as the players become more invincible (in chosen situations). It's a really stupid, crappy system. They should have based these Special abilities on kills or a rage meter or something like that and kept potions the same. In the original game, the wizard could clear a screen by firing off a potion, with the other characters doing progressively less damage with them (warrior being least proficient). Potions were more rare, usually, whereas I feel the new version gives too many, with everyone able to just blast out specials by the time you reach the end of a particular dungeon set.3) Death is rubbish in this game. People who play/played Gauntlet will know what I mean but for the benefit of those not familiar, Death in Gauntlet is a physical character. In the original he would chase the players and steal health unless someone used a potion. Using a potion "killed" him, for the time being. There could be multiple "deaths" on one level, though. They were quite fun and an interesting alternative to ploughing through loads of "nasties". Anyway, "Death" is nothing like that in the new version. Instead of being in the main levels, he gets his own set of levels which really DO NOT WORK. They're not much fun and get old very quick. He appears, chases you for a bit, then disappears. This happens as you're pushed through a linear set of rooms and, yeah, gets old. Death is not remotely troublesome, either, and you can simply run round and round him. He even smashes crates/pots by passing over them so you can use him to collect money. He's basically rubbish in this version of the game, pushed into a sidequest of sorts (which is short and lame YET counts as a "main level")4) GENERATORS. GENERATORS, FOR CHRISTS SAKES, NOT "SUMMONING STONES". JESUS ! WTF !? The summoning stones are a BAD idea. They even sound rubbish. "GENERATOR" sounds so much more malevolent and directionless. "Summoning stones" take the place of generators in this version of the game but they're a really lame replacement. In the original, Generators were in place in the level anyway. You could see them from far away. In this version you will usually walk into a room, the doors will shut, and a Summoning Stone will appear. From this, enemies will come and you smash them up then smash the stone. Doors open. Proceed. Pretty lame, tbh. There are no "levels" of summoning stone, either, whereas the original game had varying strengths of Generator that spewed various strengths of creature. Also, there were ghost generators in the original game. In this game, ghosts are confined to just appearing on the "death" mini-levels. They just appear in tiny groups, following him. Useless. Gone are the days of masses of monsters (including ghosts, see LEVEL ONE IN THE ORIGINAL GAME FFS) generating and pushing at the backs of doors, instead we get the occasional room that's been "set up" with standing monsters but nothing like the original dungeons, creaking with scum to be destroyed. It's like everything in this game is just waiting for you to turn up before it'll appear, which takes away from the "world of absolute violence" vibe that many so loved about the original. Then again, that might just have been me. I'm asian.5) This is a SHORT game. It's not got anywhere near the replayability of the original and in a couple of playthroughs (or less) you'll most likely have enough gold to max everything on your (not very unique) character. It's really hurt by not having random levels of the kind offered by stuff like Full Mojo Rampage (and many other such games). With no real need (or, perhaps, desire ?) to replay for more xp and to enjoy some different levels, there's little to return to this game for and we, once again, encounter the same problem that has plagued all of the more modern Gauntlet updates. NOT ENOUGH GAME. Why, when the original paved the way for randomising such a large amount of gameplay elements do we have to put up with this NONSENSE ? We were even promised such things in this version of the game but there is no such thing (99% of the time) here. 6) Price. It's too expensive for what it is and the new character should have been free DLC. The base game doesn't contain a fair few things that were promised and just feels, well, way too short and shallow. It's good fun and the engine is sweet, the characters "play" well and all the new moves are fine but there need to be many more levels to make this worthwhile.6/10. I recommend Full Mojo Rampage instead.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
GauntletRating: 5 / 10(Played this game as a single player so this small review has been based upon that.)The Gauntlet is an action-rpg primarily focused on co-op party, but going in as a solo player is no problem. The game is a dungeon crawler so that's basically the only environment you encounter which becomes very boring after a while. As this is controller friendly, you loot and pick up items just by walking over them, and don't have to worry about an inventory because there isn't any. Upgrades of your equipment you buy at your local shop for the money you collect while grinding through the levels. There is no story at all, so you don't have to make choices or encounter npc's. The game focuses 100% on combat and when you're solo in the game this feels a bit lonely. The graphics aren't that great, the rendering distance is a bit too far. What I like is that you can dodge missiles and make use of your class specific skills. Crossing a dangerous floor is easier as a ranger than a warrior, just because you are quicker. Sound logical but in ARPG that isn't always the case.Fighting is clicking the right buttons. Warrior is the easiest, mage the most difficult as you have to remember button sequences which sounds a bit dated to me. Press this, than this and finally this to cast a spell. Very arcade yes, but hardly modern.As a solo player I can't recommend this because it is too boring and bland. There are lots of better action rpg's in the world to devote your time to. As a party game I can imagine it can be fun to play. For a while that is as the variety seems a little low.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Did you expect Diablo III or Torchlight II when you bought this game? If so, you're not going to have a very good time, as this game most certainly does not have the same level of character development and depth that either of those titles have.Did you expect this to be like FORCED, a co-operative puzzle game masquerading as a top-down ARPG? Again, you're going to be disappointed. While there is some degree of puzzle-solving (especially with the bosses), this is most definitely not the kind of game you're going to require sober friends for.What this is, is an honest, faithful reinvention of the original Gauntlet game for the arcade, peppered with modern features and graphics. The fun is striking that intricate balance between teamwork and sabotage, trying to hinder your competitors while helping them enough to finish the mission.Pros:- Combat is fluid and requires some degree of attention to finer detail. This isn't simply a button masher, and with the Wizard especially, a fair bit of concentration is required to come out of things with your skin intact.- Balance is strong; you never feel so overwhelmed that failure is the only option, but you're rarely bored either.- Along with Hammerwatch, it probably serves as the top choice for controller-supported 4-player couch co-op in the fantasy genre.- Fantastic game intro, giving you all you need to know about how to play the game in under 5 minutes.Cons:- Maximum supported resolution is 1600x900, and the fullscreen settings are finnicky, often reverting to windowed mode with a simple alt+tab.- Scenery is a bit drab and could use some variety and an expanded color palette.- Dungeons seem a bit too repetitive; random generation might need a revision or two later on.All in all, the game is well worth having in your library if you've got friends over enough to warrant it. There are definitely better solo options in the world than this.7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												This 2014 edition of Gauntlet is a game I want to like, but that's simply impossible. It's a tedious, monotonous game with serious design problems. The game recently got polished into Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, but the problems remained.Conclusion: looks good, but not worth of any money. Maybe, if you get it for free, or as a part of humble bundle. Otherwise, no.Regrettably, this game is not fun to play at all.After 4 to 5 first levels the game starts to repeat itself. First levels are fairly enjoyable, but after that: nothing new. Controlling game characters (4 different + 1 dlc) is not rewarding, because most of the time your character is very hard to spot from the screen. That's because of three of the worst design flaws: walls obstruct your view, the viewpoint (camera) is zoomed out way too far away from your character AND the levels have very few light sources.Playing the game makes you wish you had binoculars and a flashlight pointed at the screen.How about multiplayer mode? You need a friend for that, because there is never anyone playing multiplayer otherwise. Once you get online with your friend, you will experience even more design flaws. You think you cannot get motion sickness from a game? I dare you to try this one on multiplayer mode. Have a bucket next to you when you try. I mean, what were the devs thinking? On single-player you have to strain your eyes to be able see your tiny character on a dim screen, and on multiplayer mode the screen jumps and jolts around making sure you'll vomit, or at least get a headache.Even if I pretend I can endure the flaws I mentioned, the boring map design and clearing a floor after a floor from the same enemies over and over again is just not worth the time. It is very sad to give this game thumbs down, because I really loved previous Gauntlet games, such as Gauntlet: Dark Legacy and the original Gauntlet and Gauntlet 2. Yes, even the original Gauntlet is less monotonous than this one. At least the original Gauntlet had proper level design and a feeling of progress in the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I have very mixed reviews about this game. First off, I have heard a lot of the Gauntlet series and the only one I've ever played was Dark Legacy on Gamecube. It had crappy graphics, lame gameplay, nothing complicated but it had something that this Gauntlet did not have..The charm to make me laugh.Gauntlet, a dungeon crawler I have not played for a long time is a fairly decent game. Comparing it with Diablo would be unfair, since Diablo was a very unbalanced game. Gauntlet is a very well balanced game with no over-powered character and completely very different play styles between the 4 classes with Wizard being the most complicated but most rewardingly exciting character to wield. Good graphics and pretty much zero story is normal for a game like this. It is straight-forward and simple to get used to.But Gauntlet's greatest strength for balanced gameplay and better graphics is its very own downfall. It kept the basic skeleton of what Gauntlet is, but it lacked the charm and uniqueness to stand apart from any other dungeon crawler game, let alone apart from Dark Legacy. It was straightforward, but that's all it is, straightforward with a spice of linear and a topping of repetitionWhat made Dark Legacy truly great is how wacky it was with stupid skills, range attacks for all classes and melee when your character was dealing face-to-face against an enemy. Of course, some excel in one thing while others excel in theirs. Death was also wacky as heck, chasing us like mad while leeching our lives. It had a load of flaws...but those flaws (like Halo1) was it's biggest asset and uniqueness that made me and my friends laugh through the night.This Gauntlet has stripped away all that charm and replaced it with standard issued factory produced games that can be found anywhere at their bare skeleton. Sure the game requires some skill to play, esspecially with the wizard, but it's not enough to compensate for the lack of fun factor. It's a serious dungeon crawler...and very little levels and character classes. Leveling should have been the better option to keep me playing since there are so few classes. But if there were a ton more kinds of classes, it's current balanced style would have complimented it. Much to experience and much to experiment.With so little dungeons, unworthy winnings barely worth gaining, very little items to buy...Gauntlet is a decent game, and that's all it is. Decent. I haven't even laughed once since I started playing this game online. It truly made me believe that Dark Legacy was truly better than this Gauntlet.5 out of 10 is all I can give it. It's a little fun and has it's moments of intensity which I enjoyed. But I'm not laughing and going gaga over this game. I'm already bored of it.The developers should have taken risks, and did something stupid yet playable rather than trying so hard to make this game perfect and flawless. It's flaws and improvements are both professionally unfun to endure compared to Dark Legacy. It's genericly fun for few hours. That's the most you'd get out of it.

Posted: November 9, 2014
												I saw this game as an HD reboot of the old 80s arcade classic.  Fortunately I was wrong.   The arcade classic is there - but its in spirit more than form.   There are still hordes of enemies, gates that need to be unlocked, and food to shoot - but they have taken the combat system to the next level, and introduce encounter and boss stages that bring the game onto a much higher level.   Every player has a learning curve - you need to learn how to be effective with them.  The wizard being the hardest.   Once you start to learn your character however, the game is a lot of fun.    I picked up the four-pack of gauntlet and sent it to all of my old gaming friends.  Multiplayer is a blast.   I only wish we could select the same character .. If I recall you could in the original ..  "Red Valkerie is about to die" ...Before buying this game I checked a few reviews and critic sites.   I would sum up the feedback of the game as "luke warm" ..   Many people cited glitches and crashes as the main problems.   I'm playing version 1.03 (Patch 3) and neither my friends nor myself have encountered any problems whatsoever thus far.   If you played the original, Gauntlet II ..  you should love the game and be pleasantly surprised by the additional features.   If you are new to the franchise, then remember that it is a remake of an 80s original - its not trying to emulate any other game but itself ..  be patient with the character learning curve and I'm sure you too will enjoy it!2012-12-13 UPDATE:  I play this game casually, a bit here and there.  I'm starting to get my character masteries filled out - where you unlock small incremental buffs that accumulate to make you more powerful.  I love the Necromancer update with the Colosseum.  I play this game mostly solo - but when my kids or friends play with me - the game takes on a whole other level.  It scales to the number of players and the boss fights are an absolute blast.  Still unable to select the same character - that sucks  "Blue Wizard is about to die..."

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												I've been seeing a lot of mixed reviews regarding the content of this game.  As a hardcore Gauntlet II (1989) NES fan, this game is meant to be casually played in a room full of friends, ideally with a few beers and pizzas.  It was not meant to be a multiplayer Skyrim.  As someone who has personally put many hours into this game with 4-players on local co-op, this game is now my "Hammerwatch party" replacement, and i love every minute of it.  If you want a game to play with friends when they come over, do yourself a favor and get a few usb controllers and it will be an absolute blast.  The repetition is not what i would call a downfall, for it is what always made this series.  It encourages cooperation and trial-and-error whenever a poorly-planned mob-filled LEEROY JENKINS room becomes a massacre.  And for me personally, it's pretty hilarious when your party gets mobbed like King Joffery in the streets of Flea Bottom, even if you and all your friends end up dying.TL:DR version: Red Warrior shot the food.  Buy the damn game.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I was really hype to try Gauntlet and play with a few friends...I had big expectations. I gotta say the first game session we had wasn't really that bad... But what's next?The game can be easily beaten within 3.5-4hours tops, and that is on your first playthrough where you haven't unlocked any passives/relics. After that, you could replay the same boring pretty much no story adventure on higher difficulty... But what is harder? Well, it seems that there is only more mobs. Oh and the mobs seems to have all the same AI in the whole game... Except a few that do different stuff, but it is so small it does not really make a difference.The game contains many glitches : you can see secret areas because of wall glitching, you can even clip through stuff sometimes, sometimes it's so terrible stuff dissapear! I have noticed after purchasing that it has been developed by Arrowhead Game Studios, the same team that did Magicka, this should explain the bugs. But the glitches in Magicka were kinda hilarious and felt tied with the story theme. Gauntlet shouldn't be bugged. Especially for 20$.The music also sucked : they give you this theme that is the same for the whole game and it only sounded like Diablo 3 but worse. The 4 classes are completely unbalanced and the game feel numb playing some of their moves. They should have delayed this game more than a year in order to put more content and rethink the way the classes fight.There were a few pros, but they couldn't match all the cons I have listed up there. There are also other reviews out there so if you want some pros go read them because I ain't naming a single one on a game I feel I got scammed 20$.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Gauntlet is back, kind of!  Some wizard wants to build a sword or something, but it's in pieces and scattered through The Gauntlet, and it's up to you to find them.  You have four* intrepid adventurers to choose from, with varying stats, moves, and strengths, but all sharing one major weakness.  The controls in this game are awful.  Movement is simple, but from your top-down view, you better see and plan all your moves way in advance, because characters will commit to sword swings, queue up commands, not actually get the invincibility frames the in-game help claims some moves have, and otherwise get you killed, a lot.  A hack-n-slash simply demands more responsive, maybe even twitchy controls, especially when every single room surrounds you with enemies.  If you want to play Dark Souls zoomed way out and surrounded by enemies, try Gauntlet.  If you want a game that has the frenetic, responsive, coherent feel of old-school Gauntlet...this game doesn't have that.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Arrowhead has adopted the franchise from Midway Games and has decided to reboot it. Not re-iterate the story, not make a sequel, but to reboot it. In order to do so, they decided to go back to the original arcade games from the 1980's and take a few pointer tips for their inspiration of level design.However, instead of endless dungeons that the originals produced, this game focuses on more of a linear storyline.Three worlds - One Boss per worldFour levels each -Three stages per level (Explore, Race, Challenge Arena)Four difficulties - Easy, Normal, Hard, UnfairFour characters to select, five with DLC - Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Elf, & Necromancer*Online and Local Co-op with up to three other players!Different Masteries per character to unlockGone are the days of treasure chests and a variety of potions to unleash upon the hordes.Nowadays we are prone to smashing pots and boxes for gold. You do collect a potion throughout the entire game, you use these to display your special ability in combat. Special abilties can be bought at the in-game store and you can have up to two at once.Different skins for your weapon and character are buyable as well, but they are just for looks.Many complain this game is bland, but it is really just inspired by the "bland-ness" of 1980's retro arcade games. The look and feel is all intentional. If you enjoy that nostalgia, then the price is worth it.It is a retro rpg - hack and slash - dungeon crawler. You either love it or you shame it. 8/10

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Honestly this game dissapointed at every turn. As a long time fan of Gauntlet I have loved the action, unique world, humor and challenge of many gauntlet games but non of those appear in this rehash of a beloveld fanchise. All humor has been removed (which is ok, Gauntlet doesn't need to be funny) but it's replaced with dry attempt at what I can only guess is "wit" written to be understood by a 5 year old. The gameplay is stale, it's your typical button mash dungeon crawler with each class having a "unique" set of attacks. Unfortunately this leads to the final issue of difficulty, there is none. You will have no problems clearing mobs with simple repetition even on the hardest difficulties.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												As a player of the original Gauntlet series, this game sucks. It sucks because the attacks are made to be annoying to use and not straight forward(like the previous ones) so that you have to always place your self specificaly or take some kind of time to think about it to actually hit the enemy. Some people may say that I just want a simple minded game, but again, I come from where the previous games had three attacks(melee: activated when you touch an enemy, light/fast: fast weak ranged attack, strong/slow: slow hard hits.) The only person that has some resemblance to the original formula is the sorcerer. Another MAJOR down side is that there is no level system like the previous three. Why would they think that you won't need levels in this? Just the same damage output and input the whole damn game? That turns the whole damn game into a Kiting play(Kiting is when you run away, shoot, and repeat), and kiting is not suited for this kind of game. To all who disagree, I emplore you to go play the originals(not seven sorrows, it sucks. Still better than this though). They replaced leveling with gold, which means that gold will eventually become useless. People could argue that xp eventually becomes useless BUT that takes a much longer time to cap(meaning max level) than to get enough gold for everything, plus experience doesn't have a constant spot on the screen to remind you of it. Again, Just go play Gauntlet Legends or Gauntlet Dark Legacy, and then play this, you will most likely see where I am coming from. This sequel just makes me sad to have seen, to know that they "ruined" it with the designs they chose to go with. Some may wonder why I have such a low play time, and it is because that is how long it took me to see that I hated this. They shouldn't have called it Gauntlet at all, honestly if they named it anything else, I might have been more lenient in my criticism. I honestly wonder what the developers thought they were doing when they were making these decisions, completely changing the layout of the game. Of course if you like the game, more power to you, I might even have been able to keep this game if there actually was a leveling system, because I can get past the combat because the combat isn't completely awful. It is only awful when your attacks do the SAME damage for THE WHOLE GAME. I never fought a boss, but I don't doubt that they were actually good. To be fair, previous bosses were kind of just "shoot and hope you kill them before they kill you" kind of things, except usually you would get the secret weapon that hurt them to get a leg up.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Challenges can be fun. And Gauntlet has the fundamentals of a great challenge: interesting tools for split-second decision making, and difficult encounters that demand you play your very best.Unfortunately, there are some awful design decisions and sloppy glitches that spoil what would otherwise have been a classic action game.First, the pacing: Gauntlet has historically been a very fast-paced game. But the obstacles in this Gauntlet are often extremely tedious. Monster spawners take ages to destroy, and you'll have to do it over and over again. Once you've found the right strategy, you'll just be repeating that approach every time, while hoping that one of the game's many glitches doesn't ruin your attempt.Among these bugs: Enemies will get stuck, invincibly, inside walls; the player character will get stuck in the world; collision detection screws up frequently; attacks will miss enemies directly in front of you; small elevation changes will render abilities useless (God help you if you try to fight on stairs); your defensive skills will sometimes fail to work; and relics can cause your character to lock up.Any of these glitches can lead to a cheap death, and that often means losing 20+ minutes worth of progress, since the game's rewards are gated behind challenges like "complete three levels in a row on the hardest difficulty without dying once," while your character dies in a split second if you screw up, or the game does.While Gauntlet seems suited for a quick jump-in, jump-out pace, the level structure actually requires completing several very lengthy levels in a row, which gets very tiring, especially when they consist of the same obstacles over and over. The level design itself is poor, with lots of boring, winding paths, thoughtless blob-shaped rooms, and cheap traps. In one of the randomly-selected sections, there's a room that can trap your character by requiring a key to exit yet not including a key anywhere in the room, or any way to backtrack, forcing a restart.There are fun elements here, but it's a sloppy product.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I have fond memories of the original Gauntlet. I remember playing the Amstrad CPC version for a whole day, only taking breaks for food. I also had the Gauntlet Legacy games which I thought were ok but too different from the original game. This latest incarnation of Gauntlet does not disappoint. It retains aspects of the original: 4p co-op, overwhelming numbers of enemies and a good dose of humour. It's a great homage to the original with many elements that have been updated to modern standards.This game surpasses the original in my opinion which is no mean feat. Each character plays very differently. My favourite is the wizard who is tricky to use at first but when mastered can be very powerful.I've seen some reviews which accuse the game of being repetitive. There is some truth in that, especially when you have to restart a level from the beginning. The action is so fun that I don't mind repeating the same level again and it also allows you to gain more gold and level up your character.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I have very mixed reviews about this game. First off, I have heard a lot of the Gauntlet series and the only one I've ever played was Dark Legacy on Gamecube. It had crappy graphics, lame gameplay, nothing complicated but it had something that this Gauntlet did not have..The charm to make me laugh.Gauntlet, a dungeon crawler I have not played for a long time is a fairly decent game. Comparing it with Diablo would be unfair, since Diablo was a very unbalanced game. Gauntlet is a very well balanced game with no over-powered character and completely very different play styles between the 4 classes with Wizard being the most complicated but most rewardingly exciting character to wield. Good graphics and pretty much zero story is normal for a game like this. It is straight-forward and simple to get used to.But Gauntlet's greatest strength for balanced gameplay and better graphics is its very own downfall. It kept the basic skeleton of what Gauntlet is, but it lacked the charm and uniqueness to stand apart from any other dungeon crawler game, let alone apart from Dark Legacy. It was straightforward, but that's all it is, straightforward with a spice of linear and a topping of repetitionWhat made Dark Legacy truly great is how wacky it was with stupid skills, range attacks for all classes and melee when your character was dealing face-to-face against an enemy. Of course, some excel in one thing while others excel in theirs. Death was also wacky as heck, chasing us like mad while leeching our lives. It had a load of flaws...but those flaws (like Halo1) was it's biggest asset and uniqueness that made me and my friends laugh through the night.This Gauntlet has stripped away all that charm and replaced it with standard issued factory produced games that can be found anywhere at their bare skeleton. Sure the game requires some skill to play, esspecially with the wizard, but it's not enough to compensate for the lack of fun factor. It's a serious dungeon crawler...and very little levels and character classes. Leveling should have been the better option to keep me playing since there are so few classes. But if there were a ton more kinds of classes, it's current balanced style would have complimented it. Much to experience and much to experiment.With so little dungeons, unworthy winnings barely worth gaining, very little items to buy...Gauntlet is a decent game, and that's all it is. Decent. I haven't even laughed once since I started playing this game online. It truly made me believe that Dark Legacy was truly better than this Gauntlet.5 out of 10 is all I can give it. It's a little fun and has it's moments of intensity which I enjoyed. But I'm not laughing and going gaga over this game. I'm already bored of it.The developers should have taken risks, and did something stupid yet playable rather than trying so hard to make this game perfect and flawless. It's flaws and improvements are both professionally unfun to endure compared to Dark Legacy. It's genericly fun for few hours. That's the most you'd get out of it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This game is the classic top-down hack-and-slash with a lot of great flow to it, and a pretty visual theme to boot! This will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off to no end, in the most fun way imaginable! The characters all have their own very unique playstyle and skillset, which makes mastering your own style of play very easy but not intimidating enough to make you soley stick to one character. (Haven't gotten the Necromancer yet, so I don't have any input on him.)The Warrior is very well done, and he can definitely deal a ton of damage while staying nimble enough to aovid huge mobs.The Valkyrie is fun to use and extremly useful in a pinch when you're playing with 2 or more characters. Though the shield is a bit a awkword to figure out at first. Balancing throwing and blocking takes time.The elf is just flawless. While he can't hurt the monster spawner with basic attacks, the bomb arrow more than makes up for that. His ability to roll around and laugh at enemy damage is hilarious.Saved my personal favourite for last. The mage is extremly fine tuned. With nine spells - including slows, freeze spell, an aoe explosive, a shield, and arcing lightning - The developers had a lot of fun making him. I'll say that trying to remember the element combination (any two combined of fire, lightning, and ice) takes a minute to get the hang of, after that he decimates waves and spawners. It's almost unfair, but he does have a bit of a health handicap. So it evens out.Would I buy it again? Hell yeah! And another! Maybe another, but that'd be it. I'd have four online friends, it'd be perfect!
