number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Gauntlet is a series of games consist of hack n' slash dungeon crawlers.  The games have been pretty straightforward and enjoyable, and this version of Gauntlet doesn't deviate too far from the formula.  Gauntlet isn't an HD remake of the first game.  It is a modernized retelling, keeping some things but adding in a few new things to change things up---with mixed results.Gauntlet is a decent looking game that plays pretty well.  The game's strongest point is how each character plays.  The four choices (Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf) have relatively unique playstyles.  You'll have to excuse my controller references coming up, but the Warrior and Valkyrie can be most closely associated with "button mashers," relying more on the face buttons to perform commands.  The Wizard and Elf, on the other hand, are "twin-stick" shooters, relying on heavy use of the right analog stick.  Each character also has special abilities to offer further variety, but the most diverse character is the Wizard.  While the other characters are easily accessible, the Wizard has a learning curve due to the number of abilities he has (in comparison to the others).The game still stays true to its hack n' slash, dungeon crawling roots.  The game tries to have some kind of story for why the characters are thrust into the Gauntlet, but it is paper-thin---almost unnecessary.  I know we're supposed to be collecting shards for a sword, but I really just wanted to kill some monsters with my friends.  Now, something that makes this game stand apart from other dungeon crawlers is the lack of a leveling system.  Your character doesn't gain levels (they do gain "masteries," but more on this shortly), and is just about fully equiped with every ability they will ever have.  I find this to be a welcome break, and it helps keep the game accessible to anyone.Unfortunately, I found there to be more negatives than positives to this game.  The game offers up "masteries," which are basically perks that require a lot of investment.  Most of the revolve around killing enemies, but having to continuously play through levels to kill enemies is rather annoying.  If, perhaps, the mastery requirements were lower or if they were shared across all characters (where applicable), I wouldn't be as annoyed with the mechanic.  However, the amount of work and time needed to entirely unlock them isn't worth it, in most cases.  The rewards are so incremental that it makes me wonder why they're there.Something that may also help is a stronger level variety.  There are 30 levels in the game.  27 of them are part of 9 "standard" levels and the other 3 are boss levels.  When selecting a non-boss level, you are committed to a three-level endurance run that, despite the aesthetic changes, all follow the same formula: 1st level is a "long, standard" level, 2nd level is a "short, environment hazard" level, and 3rd level is an "arena" fight.  Given that the levels are not procedurally generated (a "hot" item in more recent dungeon crawlers), the replayability falls short.  The bosses aren't incredibly fun to fight either, making them rather underwhelming.Another downfall about the level structure is the "hub" area.  After completing either the series of 3 levels or a boss level, all players are transported to the hub area to select a new level or purchase items.  The game offers the players items in the form of relics---which can only be used if potions are collected, or loadouts---which are only cosmetic permutations for the characters.  The relics offer a little more variety to the potions (instead of just "clear the screen of enemies") and the permutations don't hurt the game at all, but relics can never be used on bosses and the loadouts require us to beat the bosses and specific difficulties to unlock (and even then they cost gold to purchase).  This game also harkens back to the original Gauntlet by restricting the group to one unique character per player.  We cannot all play as Wizards or Warriors in a 4-player group.  I like the idea of having team variety, but forcing it typically leads to a lot of players quitting from a game since they can't play as a character they've invested time into.  However, as with most games, playing this game with more people is always a good time, and with a recent patch text chat has been made available.  On top of the other tweaks that have happened since the game's launch in September, it is apparent that the developer's aren't just letting this game settle.  They plan to keep improving it.SummaryPros:Graphics aren't terrible; very likely this game will run on anything.Controller supportEach character has a unique playstyleCo-op is fun; online and LAN.Developers still working out the kinks and making updates.Cons:Game is a bit on the short side.Not enough levels, and not enough level variety to keep things interesting.Can't have multiple people playing as the same character.Game wants you to grind, but not get the benefit of gaining levels.Relics and loadouts don't really offer much to the game.Poor, and at times laughable voice acting.Suggestions:Start using procedural level design.  While it isn't a perfect fix, having a structured level design when having to replay levels makes the experience too linear and predictable.Get crazier with the boss and level designs.  Maybe have something that requires more teamwork, or include some more variety with the environmental hazards.  Adding puzzles would definitely be a plus.Add an endurance mode.  All levels must be played in succession; no hub area breaks.  Even better: 100 levels, like the original game.Allow mutliple people to play as the same character.  The group may not be as varied this way, but I'd rather have another player in the group than have them drop out due to their character being taken already.Drop the relics, or make potions transfer from area to area.  Not having relics for boss fights is a poor design choice.Drop the loadouts for character creation.  Sure, the characters we play as are fully-voiced characters with small stories.  I'd rather see them not truly be characters but rather avatars for ourselves.  We can customize them, and unlocking these permutations actually unlocks them---no grinding for gold to buy them after unlocking them.Drop the masteries, or have them be cumulative across all characters when applicable.  Getting 50,000 kills for one character for a 25% damage output increase is a tall order.  Asking for that for all four characters is ridiculous.  Having shared masteries would also make the transition from playing as one character to another a bit easier on the player.Despite my lists of complaints, I am still recommending the game.  I do not think this game has earned my $20 just yet, but perhaps with additional updates down the road it will get even better.  Right now, I'd say the game is worth a $10 purchase.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I have very mixed reviews about this game. First off, I have heard a lot of the Gauntlet series and the only one I've ever played was Dark Legacy on Gamecube. It had crappy graphics, lame gameplay, nothing complicated but it had something that this Gauntlet did not have..The charm to make me laugh.Gauntlet, a dungeon crawler I have not played for a long time is a fairly decent game. Comparing it with Diablo would be unfair, since Diablo was a very unbalanced game. Gauntlet is a very well balanced game with no over-powered character and completely very different play styles between the 4 classes with Wizard being the most complicated but most rewardingly exciting character to wield. Good graphics and pretty much zero story is normal for a game like this. It is straight-forward and simple to get used to.But Gauntlet's greatest strength for balanced gameplay and better graphics is its very own downfall. It kept the basic skeleton of what Gauntlet is, but it lacked the charm and uniqueness to stand apart from any other dungeon crawler game, let alone apart from Dark Legacy. It was straightforward, but that's all it is, straightforward with a spice of linear and a topping of repetitionWhat made Dark Legacy truly great is how wacky it was with stupid skills, range attacks for all classes and melee when your character was dealing face-to-face against an enemy. Of course, some excel in one thing while others excel in theirs. Death was also wacky as heck, chasing us like mad while leeching our lives. It had a load of flaws...but those flaws (like Halo1) was it's biggest asset and uniqueness that made me and my friends laugh through the night.This Gauntlet has stripped away all that charm and replaced it with standard issued factory produced games that can be found anywhere at their bare skeleton. Sure the game requires some skill to play, esspecially with the wizard, but it's not enough to compensate for the lack of fun factor. It's a serious dungeon crawler...and very little levels and character classes. Leveling should have been the better option to keep me playing since there are so few classes. But if there were a ton more kinds of classes, it's current balanced style would have complimented it. Much to experience and much to experiment.With so little dungeons, unworthy winnings barely worth gaining, very little items to buy...Gauntlet is a decent game, and that's all it is. Decent. I haven't even laughed once since I started playing this game online. It truly made me believe that Dark Legacy was truly better than this Gauntlet.5 out of 10 is all I can give it. It's a little fun and has it's moments of intensity which I enjoyed. But I'm not laughing and going gaga over this game. I'm already bored of it.The developers should have taken risks, and did something stupid yet playable rather than trying so hard to make this game perfect and flawless. It's flaws and improvements are both professionally unfun to endure compared to Dark Legacy. It's genericly fun for few hours. That's the most you'd get out of it.

You gain Masteries by doing something in game. Kill 5000 skeletons bronze, 10000 skeletons silver and 15000 skeletons gold. While you still get the Masteries at those levels you got a 5%, 10% and 20% damage bonus against those types of enimies. This made so you clear faster, help others level faster and made the harder levels balanced with players.Now each charater has about 2 maybe 3 viable builds with what is avalible. The Masteries bonus damage/health made for more viable balanced builds with 6 or so relics that was in the game at the start.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This game is the classic top-down hack-and-slash with a lot of great flow to it, and a pretty visual theme to boot! This will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off to no end, in the most fun way imaginable! The characters all have their own very unique playstyle and skillset, which makes mastering your own style of play very easy but not intimidating enough to make you soley stick to one character. (Haven't gotten the Necromancer yet, so I don't have any input on him.)The Warrior is very well done, and he can definitely deal a ton of damage while staying nimble enough to aovid huge mobs.The Valkyrie is fun to use and extremly useful in a pinch when you're playing with 2 or more characters. Though the shield is a bit a awkword to figure out at first. Balancing throwing and blocking takes time.The elf is just flawless. While he can't hurt the monster spawner with basic attacks, the bomb arrow more than makes up for that. His ability to roll around and laugh at enemy damage is hilarious.Saved my personal favourite for last. The mage is extremly fine tuned. With nine spells - including slows, freeze spell, an aoe explosive, a shield, and arcing lightning - The developers had a lot of fun making him. I'll say that trying to remember the element combination (any two combined of fire, lightning, and ice) takes a minute to get the hang of, after that he decimates waves and spawners. It's almost unfair, but he does have a bit of a health handicap. So it evens out.Would I buy it again? Hell yeah! And another! Maybe another, but that'd be it. I'd have four online friends, it'd be perfect!

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Awesome if you like the style of gameplay from the original Gauntlet. If you like the preview videos of the gameplay, chances are you'll like the game. There is one annoying thing, though. Playing Merlin online. You compete for gold with the other players, and he has, by far, the longest cooldown on his dash ability. This means you're pretty much always getting the least gold. He also has more utility, but he has to use a lot more skills to be on equal ground to other characters. If you like challenges he'll be a great character. Seems to have a few OP abilities, but the cooldown on them is long enough to make him boring for me. But if you don't mind slightly longer cooldowns but a lot more options, maybe he'll be good for you. Just be sure to save that dash for getting gold, if possible (half the time it's not possible). Players are brutal on this game when it comes to gold, but it's all in good fun.10/10

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I really liked the old Gauntlet. This one requires teamwork and a lot of trial and error. You will die, very easily.The classes are varied and fun to play with. My favorite is the Elf. It runs really well with never a dip in frames or stutters when the mobs fill the screen.There isn't too much replay value. You do unlock different powers and cosmetic gear but thats about it. Playing with friends wether online, local or even both is where the meat of the game is. As of this writing I had no problem finding people to p[lay with. It's fun and worth the $20 price. Just don't expect the depth of Hammerwatch or Torchlight.If you like dungeon crawlers and co-op games this is a goodie. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I read a lot of these reviews and a lot are not taking in to account that this game was built to be played with your friends just like in the arcade if your not playing it co-op your not playing it right... HOWEVER Solo is still a great experience considering your can choose between your favorite class and level them all up individually and with VERY good difficulty options.Playing the game on Normal was great fun. Then bumping it up to hard I almost didn't notice a difference at first, until I all of a sudden realized I was not winning anymore. So I knew something about making it harder was working but I could not figure out what it was. The game does a really good job and making it hard without making it feel like its impossible.Then there was Unfair mode, still with that same feeling. I feel as if I can manage to get through the simplified dungeon layouts after learning them on normal mode but instantly get shutdown with in the 4th or 5th room. With time I'm sure I will become better at the game and pick up and make my own techniques for getting past dungeons on Unfair mode. I just LOVE how hard the game can get.A LOT more about this game is great. Despite having the same general dungeon layouts the game has GREAT replay value.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												When is Gauntlet not like Gauntlet?  When it's this version.This has more in common with a multi-player version of Diablo than it does with Gauntlet.I played Gauntlet in the arcades back in the day, when it was new, and eagerly awaited it's release for home computers, including Atari ST and zx spectrum and a few others that were around at the time.  My friends and I enjoyed the conversion and played it for many hours.Then came Gauntlet 2 and we were excited all over again, especially  when it was released for home enjoyment, and we all spent our waking hours wandering around with different coloured versions of each of the four characters, with Red elf and yellow wizard and blue wizard and green valkyrie, it was a good time had by all without the limitations of one character type availalbe, and often we'd play as four versions of the same character to see how it played.Now after a few other releases of gauntlet and it's clones over the years on consoles and home computers, we come to this version.While I wouldn't say it's a bad game at all, to expect it to be like either of the first two Gauntlet games is to meet with dissapointment, and it really does have a lot more in common with diablo 1 or 2, and Diablo's spawned children than the golden Gauntlet of happiness that I still remember clearly and dearly.There are certain things that tie this title loosely to the Gauntlet of it's title, like 4 characters named after the Gauntlet characters. Food that's fragile and can be destroyed accidentally, and the fact that it all takes place in a dungeon.  Certain sounds and phrases are very similar to the original too.  But that's it for similarity really. Anything else is from Diablo.  There aren't mazes filled with spawners of varying strengths 1-3 (though there are occassional spawners scattered here and there), and there are potions but they are needed to power artifacts which you buy with gold, outside of the levels you play through.  The speech is of course clear and everything, but it is missing the dramatic tone that the original sampled speech used to have, and doesn't fit so well.   The only characters that shoot anything off are the elf and wizard, with the rest needing to use secondary abilities to do anything beyond bashing/stabbing the monsters.  And on the subect of the wizard, I hope you like pressing combinations of buttons/keys to use an ability, out of all the ones he has hidden.Muti-player is very hit and miss, in that you might find good players that work together, and with due caution, or more usually find completely selfish players who get the party killed and have no other care but for their own selves and getting all the money and food for themselves.  Unfortunately there are far more of the second type than the first, which makes for a less than wonderful experience in multi-player, and has made it so that I am hesitant to even consider playing multi-player when (if) I play gauntlet.  Too many people playing it as though the other gamers are just tagging along, and then blaming them for being noobs when they die because the selfish individual has taken all the money/food/potions.All in all, I am not so willing to recommend this version as a Gauntlet game, but I am willing to recommend it as a diablo clone that's cheaper than the average game these days, and I'd not recommend it to any of my friends if they played Gauntlet and were looking for a modern version to have fun with, though hey.. it's a game to fill the quiet moments of the day with dungeons and monsters.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												I just bought a 4pack in a Bundle & we've been trying to figure out why the game is completely unplayable on 2 of our computers. It plays fine on my older PC & my oldest daughter's 4yr old laptop, but the camera jumps around on my other 2 kids brand new AMD & NVidia laptops.It literally jumps around constantly just after the game starts, so you can't see anything useful on the screens. And it does the exact same thing on 2 completely different machines with different video cards from different companies, which is why we ruled out hardware as the source of the problem. Of course the first thing we did on both systems was update to the latest drivers, make sure the systems were running clean, etc. But this game, at least visually, will not work on their computers.Then I started seeing comments around about the camera problems. Not sure why they won't fix this problem, but I bought the game for co-op family fun after reading all the good reviews, and now we can't play it. Time to find some other fun co-op games for 4 people to enjoy together. Suggestions are welcome.I may still play around with it in SP, but from what I'm reading, it may not be worth playing at all since the last update. Sounds like they should have just released new content, maps, etc, instead of re-writing the game and removing many things people actually enjoyed prior to the patch.

												Are you wishing to find something similar to good old Diablo 2, but with the ability to move with the WASD-keys, aim with the mouse and more or less wave-zombie-survival-like gameplay? Look no further.Gauntlet is a great game for both playing solo or in a party. Choose one of five classic characters: Barbarian (aka The Warrior)Valkyre (aka The Tank)Archer (-_-)Wizard (aka Invoker's little bro)or Necromancer (aka The DLC-chick)and get into the fight through the vast dungeons full of monsters, traps, TURKEY and GOLD! The more you play and the more you kill - the more powerful you get, opening new bonuses and abilities.Sharpen your axe and spear, stretch your bow or ....? your spellbook and dive into action!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Gauntlet may seem like the standard dungeon crawler at first but the gameplay is nothing short of glorious. As you tear through swarms of goons like a kid and christmas presents, the first glimpse you catch is the Warrior spinning his axe. Then you spot the Elf rapid-firing shots from a distance. Amidst the chaos you notice the Wizard blasting off spells and the Valkyie handing out slayings. What makes the game special is that four player unity. Together the players bring out the best of what a modern co-op game should, and in harmonious fashion. The evidence is in the legacy. The game isn't perfect. Then again the best things never are.Note: This is for Pre-Slayer Edition. RIP.

												This could be a fun little arcade co-op game with 3 of your pals.  There's just one issue, it's unplayable with M&K.  Sure they have some keys (the arrow keys for movement), but this game is fast paced and requires some twitch and precision aiming/dodging.  That just ain't happening by using the arrow keys to move.I don't need the wtf bro it's 2015 get a controller already, it's the future bro.  So save your vapid insipidity. I have purchased too many games before checking the efficacy of playing with a M&K.  It will damage my pride, but I think it's time get comfortable with a controller.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												"Stay a while and listen" (blizzy pls don't sue me, k, thx, bai!) ... or in this case, read a wall of text  :PWhat I first noticed about the game is its menu, it's simple, clear, all a menu should be.Then the game started with the tutorial, forcing me to play it. I did not see a "skip tutorial" button (my bad if there was but pretty sure there wasn't).Not nice forcing people to do something they don't want to, give them the option to choose.And if you are going to argue that they had to do that the way they did so people would learn about the characters and their mechanics then i say to you: "I'm sorry but I do not agree!"There are better ways to introduce important stuff then forcing it on people, hide it like Portal and Portal 2 did - almost the whole game is a tutorial preparing the player for what is to come, but we are not here to talk about Portal, Gauntlet time.The tutorial on its own was put together nicely, introducing the characters and their mechanics through gameplay rather then through text, which is always nice.The characters are ok-ish defined.The Warrior being a warrior can take damage as well as dish out damage of his own.The Elf uses range attacks to defeat his enemies, although his range isn't that great. I expected more from an elf ranger.The Valkyrie is a nice mix of the two (i particularly liked the Captain America like shield throw).These three characters are pretty straightforward, but the Wizard is a bit more complicated.Having 9 spells to choose from, the Wizard can access his spells with a certain button combination. The desired spell is then ready to use, assuming its not on cooldown.Not too intuitive, and a bit confusing at first but fiddle around with the spell combinations and you will get the hang of it.I must point out that the ice spells were not as useful to me as the other two types of spells (fire and lightning) and i ended up playing mostly with fire and lightning spells, and even here with not all of them.The Fire Bomb is useless if you are near a doorway or a low ceiling-ish area it will hit the ceiling and explode dealing no damage to the monsters below it or it won't end up exploding where you expected it to cause it ended up hitting something you did not thought possible (could be a bug or just bad design).Also Lightning Discharge was of no use to me, if i wanted to knock someone back I can use my Storm Barrier, so I ended up using it only when I incorrectly combined buttons to get a spell.The RPG elements are kind of wierd in concept and implementation.If you buy armour and weapons you only get a cosmetic change. But you can also buy relics to give you buffs to your speed, damage, attack speed or the ability to summon illusions or a demonic gargoyle to fight by your side.However you can only have 2 relics and can not use any without potions. These potions you can not buy, they can only be found throughout the levels, as well as food which restores hit points.Instead of gaining traditional levels for each character, you can only improve your stats by performing achievement-like actions called Masteries. For example killing 10,000 monsters grants a 10 % damage bonus.First time around, the structure of the game is interesting and the level design is a mix of pre-made and randomly generated environment.Some levels are more complex than others, tasking you or the group to push blocks, insert statues into spots, or fill a lava pool to raise a bridge and then finally an okay-ish boss battle.The campaign is broken up into three acts, with four stages, four repetitive stages.Each set of those stages unfolds in the same way:First you start with a standard level, then you move on to a shorter level with a frustrating twist like being chased by death which btw is bad at its job and its not so hard to outrun (just frustrating) or a dark cave eating away at your nerves as you try to hold back the urge to pluck out your hair and then (as i already mentioned) a boss fight.Higher difficulty only makes enemies more resistant to damage and drop more gold.Once the campaign is finished there’s not much incentive to revisit and replay the game.The A.I. is not to bright either. Getting stuck frequently on each other, corners, doorways and other stuff lying around the level.After some time you notice how they move and can kite them around the level making them easy targets. Easier than they would have been on their own.And a one last thing, the camera, oh boy ... The view is zoomed out far enough to cover an area, but not far enough for a four player co-op play through. The camera does not follow any player controlled characters but hovers above an area of the level and its easy to lose sight of your character.Additionally if any teammate goes idle you can't move on without them cause the camera will stand still in an area and try to cover all players.I am sure that Arrowhead did their best but they neither went full retro nor did they break from the past.As i see this game, its like they tried to stay close to the original (Gauntlet from 1985) but not to close cause people my not like it today and tried to make it an appealing 2014 role-play, dungeon crawl, hack and slash game but actually got stuck in the middle of it all resulting in a not so good game.In short its repetitive and overly simplistic, awkward camera, an uninteresting upgrade system and too little substance or variety to satisfy players.However, with four committed players the co-op works well, and it’s certainly not the worst Gauntlet revamp there’s ever been.All in all IMHO this game is a 5.5 / 10, nice try but u failed, sry and i do not recommend this game.

												Jacko Rating 8/10The latest in Gauntlet remakes but definately the most loyal to the original which I played hours and hours of on the Commodore 64 back in the day. number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												Score: 5 / 10Price/Value: $5 or lessTime: 3 HoursDifficulty: HardThis particular version of Gauntlet just leaves you wishing you were playing the original. While it is a solid effort to update the game and add new mechanics, they end up not functioning properly or are designed to be useless. Gauntlet, for those of you not familiar with the series, has you playing as either a warrior, elf, wizard or valkyrie fighting your way through a randomly generated dungeon for loot. Being an arcade game originally, health used to deteriorate over time, needing to be replenished through food - this is no longer the case even on the highest difficulty. Dungeons are also no longer randomly generated; it seems to be the same maps & paths for every character.The visuals and audio are nothing to write home about, so I'm just going to move onto the game mechanics.One of the most important things for any game, especially one focused on crowd control, is the controls themselves. Shift-key abilities such as the Elf's 'dodge' don't often trigger when pressed or have a starting and ending delay for the animation which causes instant death on higher difficulties. As you might imagine, this can make a character useless when main abilities are broken in this manner. Throwing potions is also another ability broken by animation delays causing death. This makes two out of three skills for your character worthless. The wizard is crippled by a Magicka-like system of magic where clicks and the shift key are used to combine elements for spells. If you are going to play the wizard, make sure you have a printout of the various spell combinations or memorize them. In my opinion, this makes the wizard another broken class. I can't comment on the Valkyrie, having given up on this particular title before even testing the class.  UPDATE: Having played the Valkyrie I can safely say it's as broken as all the other classes, your space-bar ability is all you will spam over and over.All in all, unless you -really- enjoy Gauntlet and want to see some modern mechanics that detract from the experience then pass this by and fire up the original.

It featured 100 levels and a level designer - good times!Also, I am puzzled as to why this game is poorly optimized. It runs very HOT whereas games like Kingdoms of Amalur - admittedly not a Cry Engine GPU killer - barely cause a blip in GPU temps.I am hopeful that either level randomization and/or a leve editor will be added to Gauntelt 2014 to give it some legs. As it stands now, it is fun for VERY short bursts of time. Come on devs, please flesh ut the skeleton?

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Alright, this game is AWESOME. It's THAT type of couch co-op where you actually have to cooperate.While single-player seems to be quite well - though a little bit harder for some classes - multi-player is the bomb. Not only it allows local coop, but online works wonderful. And let me tell you - multiplayer is a blast. You get a couple of friends on skype - and you will have hours of non-stop fun.And itself it's a pretty good game, though some classes seem to be harder to play/master. Levels are nicely decorated, announcer doesn't annoy you, classes are useful in their own way and generally it's enjoyable. Keyboard works fine, though I yet have to try the controller.While it seems that "Getting 3 shards of whatever" will be pretty quick (the first chapter took 3 of us 2 hours), the replay value is in different classes, because they differ A LOT. Warrior deals massive damage to tours and fat monsters while elf thins out small crowds of weaklings and mage supports with slowdowns and ignitions. And because of this variety everybody plays differently.I would say it is DEFINITELY worth the money if you have a couple of friends who'll join you.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												No voice or text chat means there is no way to strategize or interact with other players other than running around in circles. The developers said they want to make the game as close as an experience to the original arcade as possible, but are actually using that as an excuse to avoid programming more. If you are standing at an arcade machine with three of your other friends there's nothing preventing you from using your voice. The game is also unforgiving. Even on easy difficulty you should have at least three people in your party or it will be tough to proceed. Getting more people to join you should be simple, but the developers opted for the archaic "quick join" feature for multiplayer instead of giving players a list of lobbies. This means that you could click quick join and wait for minutes to join a game not knowing whether anyone is actually playing a public game at the difficulty you selected. All of this equals an unsatisfying multiplayer experience unless you know well three other people that all want to play and have the game. $80 for you and three of your friends to play a game where you can't communicate is a bad deal.

												I'd give Gauntlet a "meh" rating and a don't buy unless it is cheap. I have used it with the keyboard/mouse as well as with a XBOX 360 controller and find that neither seems to work great. I find the keyboard/mouse combo to be more precise in aiming by a significant margin. The xbox 360 controller only gives you so fine of an angual adjustment and I find myself being one tick off from where I really mean to be aiming a lot of the time. Neither control scheme works particularly well at the end of the day.Gameplay is repetitive and uninspiring and I find that my group of friends doesn't use the potions to great effect. Overall we have some fun but the controls aren't good and the game is too repititious which I guess works in favor with the game being short.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												20$ for this piece of shhh.- 3 worlds- 4 classes; can't have two of the same class in one game- Equipment pieces offer no bonuses whatsoever and have barely any cosmetic value- Unfunny characters trying to be witty and failing miserably- Previous Gauntlet games had stories that nobody cared about, but never as forgettable, asinine and all around laughably pointless- There are like 10 purchasable skills total but you'll be using only 2 or 3 for the duration of your entire "adventure"- By the end of the game, you will neither know nor care about the skills that you haven't tested yet- Harder game difficulties don't make the game any better- Literally nothing worthwhile postgame- Like many multiplayer games, this one was meant to be played with friends, and even then, it's still not all that. To play in Single Player mode is to condemn yourself to the torments that are boredom and regretGauntlet™ like the biggest cashgrab of 2014. It just feels like Arrowhead Game Studios (and WB Games of course) rushed an half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bargain bin shovelware type of game and slapped the GAUNTLET name on it for that sweet, sweet fanboy dosh. This game is worse than a good many indie games that are produced on a much lower budget and that cost  considerably less than a whopping, arrogant 20$. I'm sorry if I might've hurt Arrowhead's hard-working employees' feelings, but that's how it is. Maybe they had no say in the creative process. Maybe they were forced to make a game they knew the fans would feel insulted and disgusted by. I hope that's the case.Keep your money. Man, I still cannot believe how mediocre Gauntlet™ turned out to be.

I've played all of the gauntlet games from gauntlet 1 to seven sorrows, and this gauntlet is the best of the series. I love that I can play gauntlet as a pure hack-n-slash (warrior), twin stick shooter (elf & wiz) or as captain america (valkyire). Don't expect a diablo or a mouse driven action rpg, this game is arcade action with lite rpg elements. Must buy for people who enjoyed any of the gauntlet games.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												This game is everything I was praying it would be. The four characters available have differences in their playing styles which makes the game worth playing multiple times. The enemies are difficult at times but this forces the player to get creative rather than fall into the same murderous trance over and over again. Each floor contains something different from bosses, to death incarnate, to just flat out treasure troves. To make things better, the game contains many upgrades in the form of relics and you can even customize your hero with new armor and weapons in the shop in the hub room. This game is made even more fun when you play with your friends, the teamwork element makes strategies more fun and gathering more loot than your friend is always a fun contest. I cannot wait to see how this game progresses. It is a fantastic reboot and is more fun than most games I've played this year. So yea 10/10 :)

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Now some people may think "co-op" is about strategy dependent on the strength of a team working together. However, these people are idiots who don't understand that the true path to victory lies in thinking only of one's own needs, and the one class that currently embodies this most Gauntlet of all ideals is the Elf. Long range attacks with little to no effort in aiming them at food or potions the lesser classes may require, and most importantly, the broken ability to dodge roll or otherwise go faster than the slower fools and gain all of the treasure and E-sports glory for one's self.  Remember, the intelligent player runs towards the elf and silently mocks whoever picks the other classes; even if the Wizard is some sort of Magika trained savant and easily input spell combos on the fly, the key is to keep the meat shields around so that you can profit from their mistake of not picking the right class. Make them believe you care about them, but out do them in all things as the most broken of all characters.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Gauntlet is an incredibly enjoyable co-op hack-and-slash dungeon crawler that is highly reminiscent of the original, while offering Arrowhead’s own spin on the foundations previously set. The game plays well and is a lot of fun with friends, co-op definitely being the recommended way to go, although is still viable as single player. It’s certainly a little lacking in places, especially when it can occasionally feel a little repetitive, but overall this doesn’t hinder it too much. The game looks and feels great, and is something I would not hesitate recommending to fans of the hack-and-slash dungeon crawler genre. Summary:+ Fantastic class revamp and disparity.+ Enjoyable combat and gameplay.+ Nicely stylised visuals.+ Good difficulty variety.+ Decent boss battles for the most-part.- Some level mechanics feel too gimmicky.- Levels can feel a little repetitive.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Definitely a faithful representation of the original, and even better. One of the best top-down action games I have ever played. All of the classes are fun to play, especially the wizard. The way you double tap two-button combinations on the controller (XX, YB, etc.) is really smart and is the only real way you could possibly get to each spell quick enough while fighting, because you do need to be able to switch to the right spells at the right time to survive, especially on unfair mode. However it can still get confusing trying to navigate all of his spells (9 total) while being swarmed in combat, especially in unfair mode. One thing that I dislike is that bosses themselves serve no challenge. The difficulty from boss fights comes from being swarmed by other enemies while fighting the bosses. The sounds and music are very memorable, the graphics and art direction are superb, and the effects are also very well done. Probably the only complaint I have is that sometimes in 4 player games there is so much♥♥♥♥♥♥going on at once that it is very easy to get lost in the action or take hits when you otherwise would not have. Multiplayer is a blast and is one of the most fun games to play online. The more people there are, the harder the difficulty is. So in unfair mode with 4 players get ready for some pain.Also, the fact that beating tougher levels on hard/unfair unlocks new gear for looks, not stats, is a joke. It's a top-down game, nobody is going to notice but you. There should be more purposeful rewards for playing through the campaign more than once. Or at least make the gear look better.I got this when it first came out on Nuuvem (Steam is blocking Nuu vem, are you ♥♥♥♥ing serious) for $13.50 and that was a steal. It has plenty of content to justify its $20 price tag, but don't expect it to be any longer than the average length of a $20 game. If anything, I cannot wait for its inevitable expansions. I mean I hope.8/10 after 50+ hours it is getting extremely repetitive. It needs a dlc badly.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Was tempted to give it a thumbs up - Really solid game with some solid points. I do  however have far too many gripes to warrant thisThe Good:- Great sound track - Musics great!- New meets old styled gameplay - I like the varied moves, big cooldown styled attacks and the way they did the Wizard and Elf. Feels like Diablo 3 gave some inspiration to this game and it's very much welcomed.- Local Multiplayer mixed with online- Can you say awesome? Because more games need more local multiplayer ESPECIALLY on the PC. The Bad:- Progression is non existant - The relics are neat, but im a bit disapointed with the gear. Getting more gold? Meh. It wont give me a bigger axe or make me hit any harder or put me in some shiney new armor that does something neat for me. I was hoping for deeper rpg elements.- Incredibly short - Games far too short. Can be cleared too quickly.- Dejavu with dungeon elements - Playing through a few specific dungeons I felt they "dragon aged" it. By that I mean they copy and pasted parts of other dungeons into it.- Weak multiplayer elements - Game encourages you to take items and food from other players.- Few minor bugs - I got a crown knocked off my head and it landed on a part of the map I couldn't get at. Thanks game.- No colour palette swapping - "Red Wizard needs food badly" "Blue Warrior is about to die" - I miss the colours.. Having four warriors or four wizards would have made this better, why not? :(All in all I'd say pass on this unless it's on a 50%+ sale. For 5-10 bucks you'll get a decent ammount of fun for a day with a couple of your friends for local multiplayer, but the lack of replay-ability, non-existant RPG elements really make this a tough one to purchase at the now asking price of CDN$ 21.99

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												A well made take on the old classic Atari game Gauntlet, that i can recommend to anyone who wants to enjoy a simple yet deep hack n' slash experience. The game features fun mechanics, an interesting aesthetic style, as well as having a badass soundtrack, that harkens back to the old preceding Gauntlet games.Besides the obvious traits of each character (the elf has a bow and the warrior a melee weapon, etc). Each of the characters feature different skills and mechanics that you have to adapt to, in order to maximise your effectiveness. And you can also customize your character with artifacts to suit your style of play.However when i played this game i didn't do it for the character customization. This game just makes killing feel good. Especially when you get yourself into a trance where everything just clicks and you eviscerate 20 opponents in a matter or seconds.My only beef with this game is, that compared to the older gauntlet games, the "puzzles" in this game are too easy. It often feels like the game is taking your hand and leading you to where you need to place the dynamite or throwing you an extra key to open one of the locked doors. In the older Gauntlet games, the game would force you to think about managing your keys, and solving the puzzles in the correct order. However in this version this is not the case and takes some of the more cognitive aspects of the game away. I can't say much about the multiplayer experience, since i've yet to play it with another friend  ( :c ).  But other than that Gauntlet has been a fun experience and i would definately play more of this in the future.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Luckily, I had the day off from work today, and got to spend pretty much the entire day playing the remake of one of my favorite classic games, Gauntlet. Arrowhead did a superb job from what I've seen so far. The graphics aren't anything phenomenal, nonetheless, the game looks pretty good and runs smooth. The gameplay is fast paced and well fleshed out. Playing online with random players is just as brutal as you would expect from a new age remake of Gauntlet. You don't always feel like your party members are your friends. If feels like you and 3 other heroes are just trying to survive the death trap you've been thrown into, and you can either help each other, or take what you can for yourself. This can be frustrating but also extremely fun. It adds an element to the game that is Gauntlets signiature and they did a great job resurrecting this classic, adding modern features without subtracting from the old school arcade feel. They added masteries and relics, which is the closest thing to "leveling up"the game has. So over time your characters will get a bit stronger. But still, DO NOT get this game if you want just like to grind. You won't be building an immortal barbarian with super l33t gear in this game.  If you aren't bringing some effort and skill to the game, you will die. It's best played with at least 2 or more people, but solo can be fun as well.   I do think theres some balancing that needs to be done, and I'd like to see more levels added in the near future, but as of now it is totally worth 20$.

												Despite some issues at launch including choppy sound and an issue getting a non-xbox360 gamepad to work (i must have gotten luck), this game is an absolute nostalgic blast. It's simple to understand and challenging. Would put more down, but haven't had the chance to really play through the entire game. It does seem fairly short, however the masteries make it interesting and help add to the replayablity of it on a higher difficulty. Definitely worth the 20 bucks, also got to mention that there as of now is no in-game chat which can make it difficult to communicate when playing a quick match, but if your playing with friends just open steam voice chat. Also, the game has huge amounts of promise in that there seems no reason for the devs to release more dungeons and content or possibly even a sequel.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This plays similar to the NES/Arcade original, which brings back great memories of playing with my old man back when I was just a kid.  This game is plain fun.  I started with the warrior, but have found that the wizard's spell casting system is an excellent cerebral addition that makes Gauntlet really shine for me.I'm running this on a 2012 Macbook Pro with bootcamp running Windows 7.  I have to turn the resolution down to half and play in a (fairly large) window to keep the fps up.  It hiccups from time to time, but it's overall playable in a window.  Not so much in fullscreen.  However, the Intel HD 4000 integrated graphics don't even close to meet the minimum requirements, so I'm happy to be able to play this game, which is fantastic by the way.  Turning the VSync on keeps the framerate locked at 60, which is just fine by me.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I've always loved the Gauntlet series(especially the N64 game), but this newest version of "gauntlet" was a truely horrible disaster. Not only is this game incredibly short but it was very cheaply made with alot of "copy and paste" in the measely 12 levels they give you. The game has literally no storyline, other than some mysterious voice that captured you in the beginning and forces you to fight these levels for him. In the end, it appears he used you to get shards for some sword (that he never explained anything about) and then says "This must be the final test. My final test." and then proceeds to attack you. The battle is easier than the levels and is very short. You get a little bit of dialogue with a total of three pictures ( literal non-moving pictures) for your ending. All in all, I'd say if you really wanna play this pathetic game then wait til it goes on sale for $0.50 or it's free for a weekend(as you can prolly beat it in two hours). Also, there is only one character that is worth playing as (Valkryie) and is incredibly unbalanced with the other players. So, the creators of this game NEVER need to make another game and I would like my money back. Also, I would like to kick them in the balls for ruining one of my favorite games.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												This is nothing like any gauntlet game I've ever played.It's like those Marvel top down beat 'em up games from the ps2/gamecube era.Lots of button mashing, lots of grunts to kill, lots of different ways to do it.I love the game but I think that the classes are poorly balanced, but since it's a co-op that doesn't matter too much.I like how "achievements" unlock skills and abilities, probably the only time I care about achievements haha.I highly reccomend this game if you like top down beat 'em ups with SOLID controls. They're flawless.Warrior:Plays like he should, press the X X X and the Y Y Y. His B spin attack is invincible and gives you some extra range. I dislike how you have to charge his charge, but the charge jump attack is good even if it takes a bit of practice to get the range right. His heavy attack deals a LOT of damage, very useful.Valkyrie:I like her dash attack more than warrior's bull run (although I like the warrior's bull run) her shield doesn't seem that useful since hordes are usually how you die, but she does a good job of being different than the warrior so kudos.Archer:Easily the most broken of the classes, his bombs, rolls, and power shots are incredible. It doesn't take long to learn how to massacre monsters with archer, but there is a bit of a skill cap so he's not entirely braindead (just monstly brain dead)Wizard:I hope you liked magika because this guy is magika as ♥♥♥♥. Good luck using him. He's easily my favourite to play as but he is by far the hardest class to play. He has a TON of spells and they all have individual cool downs so poppin' off damage can be easy, but you're going to need to memorize all the spell inputs before you can even be mediocre at wizard.All in all the game is really fun and I hope you guys check it out and enjoy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												A well made take on the old classic Atari game Gauntlet, that i can recommend to anyone who wants to enjoy a simple yet deep hack n' slash experience. The game features fun mechanics, an interesting aesthetic style, as well as having a badass soundtrack, that harkens back to the old preceding Gauntlet games.Besides the obvious traits of each character (the elf has a bow and the warrior a melee weapon, etc). Each of the characters feature different skills and mechanics that you have to adapt to, in order to maximise your effectiveness. And you can also customize your character with artifacts to suit your style of play.However when i played this game i didn't do it for the character customization. This game just makes killing feel good. Especially when you get yourself into a trance where everything just clicks and you eviscerate 20 opponents in a matter or seconds.My only beef with this game is, that compared to the older gauntlet games, the "puzzles" in this game are too easy. It often feels like the game is taking your hand and leading you to where you need to place the dynamite or throwing you an extra key to open one of the locked doors. In the older Gauntlet games, the game would force you to think about managing your keys, and solving the puzzles in the correct order. However in this version this is not the case and takes some of the more cognitive aspects of the game away. I can't say much about the multiplayer experience, since i've yet to play it with another friend  ( :c ).  But other than that Gauntlet has been a fun experience and i would definately play more of this in the future.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Though lacking the grand scale found in Legends and Dark Legacy as well as the simple yet engaging combat system found in those iterations of the gauntlet series, this game ranks head and shoulders above its predecessors, and ARPGs in general.The classes are complex and a blast to play, each class with a unique playstyle that brings the characters to life, giving them a unique role in multiplayer and replayability in single player.Personal favorite is the wizard, who uses a magic system not dissimilar to Magicka's system of magic, though simplified and  streamlined. Honestly, all the classes are a blast to play, but the wizard stands out to me as how wizards in ARPGs should be implemented in ARPG's: mental acuity combined with skill.As mentioned above, it doesn't have that grand scale of Dark Legacy or Legends, opting for the classic dungeon crawler vibe it helped to create. The humor lightens up the atmosphere and creates a jovial atmosphere that makes multiplayer great, and with a good complement of friends, you could be looting with the best of them.Speaking of which, the game allows you to use gold to purchase gear and loot, as opposed to items and levels in previous iterations, giving it immeasurable depth.Chances are, you'll find something you'll like here, and 20 dollars is a great price for a game of this caliber. Don't pass it up!

Turning the VSync on keeps the framerate locked at 60, which is just fine by me.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I went into this game hoping to experience the fun of the original or at least some small part of nostalgia for an arcade classic.  It didn't happen.  I played this with my brother for some 2 player co-op.  My brother played the warrior character and found it to be just a boring spam-fest of pressing the attack button.  No thrills to be had there.  So, on to the wizard I go. This character is the complete opposite of the warrior in terms of difficulty.  It has an interesting mechanic similar to that found in the Magicka games where you can combine elements of Fire, Ice and Lightning to make different spells.  The problem is I found that the normal fireball spell was sufficient for most encounters. The other spells just end up prolonging battles.  Swapping spells on the fly is a little cumbersome and was another reason why I spent the majority of the time in fireball mode.The gameplay and tactics can be a bit unforgiving.  If you don't perform perfectly than it can be hard to recover.  Worst of all is there is no checkpoint system.  If you die, then that's it, back to the beginning of the level you go.  For those seeking a challenge, this is a good point.  For just trying to play through the game on a normal difficulty, this is just frustrating.Overall I wasn't as impressed with this game as I was with a very similar game, Hammerwatch.  Hammerwatch has the same top down Gauntlet-esque adventure and battles and even sports the pixlated 8-bit graphics.My personal opinion, I'd say give Gauntlet a pass unless you pick it up on the cheap when it's on sale or really want a challenging top down adventure to play co-op with your family and/or friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												I have been a huge fan of Gauntlet for a very long time, and when this game came out I was very excited to try it, after warner took Mortal Kombat under it's wing and it's done so well I had high expectations for this game, and unfortunately NONE of them were met.The game tossed out every previous good idea in the last couple installments so things like 3way shot thunder hammer those no longer seem to exist.The Classes you can choose are severely lacking with only a selection of 5 [4 from the start]The customization is nearly non existant and what little you do have is set "on the top shelf" so you're quite aware the game is going to be exactly the same it is when you start it and nothing really amazing is going to happen.The Potions have been changed into something else, now they are solely for using your items you can buy which you're only able to carry 2, not only that you can no longer stock pile them so if you don't use them the level you find them, you lose them. You can also only carry so many of them as if they're really all that great anymore.The level design is extremely stale and as soon as you start the game you get the notion "I'm going to see a lot of the same S***" through this game"In conclusion when I got this game I was pumped after all the years I'd been trying to get a better computer to run it properly and in all the years I've played video games I've NEVER played a game I completely hated and felt cheated, for buying it and I've enjoyed some games people really cannot stand. If you're a fan of the older games, especially the last couple releases like "Dark Legacy" and "Legends" this is not the game for you, you will be SEVERELY disappointed. If you're a fan of the orginal you're SLIGHTLY better off, but I STILL do not recommend it, What makes games like Mortal Kombat so good is they kept what made the games great initially while adding content to the games that improved it, what makes this game bad is they tried to dumb it down all the way until it was simple like the originals, and then tried to make it more "real" which is dumb for such a game that was built for the kind of "cheesie goodness" kind of feelMy comment: Why doesn't Warner Brothers just put funding into a "Gauntlet Dark Legacy HD" that plays online and add content to that? That would have been MUCH better.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Easy = NormalNormal = Decently HardHard = Memorize the area and events to win, lose half the time to one stupid enemy managing to get a last hit.Unfair = ImpossibleColliseum seasons will have you breaking your head into your keyboard; they are ridiculously hard for the only reward being pointless clothing for your character/bragging rights. The only other way to get cool items is beating the regular campaign levels on harder difficulties, but the only actually cool items require Unfair difficulty which is legitimately UNFAIR.So what do you have left for this game? Oh the actual regular gameplay... well.  Its sort of boring, and I only go through it to complete challenges, get new♥♥♥♥♥♥ progress in the game, etc. The replay value? None. Game mechanics are intentionally simple, which is fine, but when the challenge in this game is the stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ "setups" they have for you to die in this game (inclosed area, ridiculous spam amount of enemies, Death, etc.) and not interesting or creative ways to help challenge the player, all it does it♥♥♥♥♥♥me the ♥♥♥♥ off when I die and if I don't die, its so repetitive It makes me not want to play the game for longer than an hour. I can't do this game any justice, besides the different realms (set of levels, whatever its called) the variety of different scenarios is very limitied, and ♥♥♥♥ there are only 3 realms in the whole game. Yeah, this game is short as♥♥♥♥♥♥ You think I haven't played enough hours in the game to be able to write a review? Ive sped through most of the game, like 55% in what... two hours? Again, semi-understandable given this is like a coin-op styled game, but guess what kiddoes.... ITS STILL SHORT AND REPETIVE AND OVERLY DIFFICULT DUE TO POOR GAME MECHANICS AND SETUPS. Highest graphics look like blended♥♥♥♥♥textures as if it was on a medium graphics setting for a normal game.Reviews for this game are even dumb, im sorry but if you even watch IGN reviews in general you are apart of the 13 year old minecraft, CoD, PewDiePie fan club conformists, because IGN is completely bias and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in their reviews. The people who gave this game an accurate rating was Gamespot's Justin Clark who wrote in the FIRST SENTENCE..."In some sense, the world already has a series that carries on the Gauntlet legacy; it's called Diablo"Go buy Diablo, Go buy Torchlight, ♥♥♥♥ even get any clones of the sort because Gauntlet just feels like a cocktease Diablo, to be completely honest. Diablo 1 was released on December 31, 1996 and provides more variety than this game.You know what this game is? 1. "omg a new Gauntlet game" hype  2. Obviously rushed production of game for release around Christmas time 3. Game feels like a demo 4. Price is way too ♥♥♥♥ing high 5. Mostly boring gameplay and♥♥♥♥♥♥graphics for its time 6. This isnt 1985 anymore so there's no excuse for this lack in varietyThis game is a pile of garbage with "Gauntlet" slapped on the front.5/10; my head hurts from banging it ten times after trying to beat the season 1 unfair difficulty for the millioneth time (Im not even joking)

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												If you're looking to play a Gauntlet Legends, or a Gauntlet Dark Legacy remake, you've come to the wrong place. If you're looking for a Gauntlet Seven Sorrows type game, go jump off a cliff. If however, you're looking for a fast paced, old style Gauntlet game with a new twist to it, this is for you. Being a kid in the 90's, one of my favorite games for N64 was Gauntlet Legends. I must've put in 300+ hours. Then I had Gauntlet Dark Legacy, and played it for years. I was so excited for Gauntlet Seven Sorrows, and it was one of the biggest let downs in my video gaming playing ( Diablo 3 was #1). This is so different from those 3, but not for the bad. I love this game. Every class plays so different, making it so replayable. I know I'll be putting in quite a few hours into this one.    Pros.-Great music-Good atmosphere-Ton of Replability-Classes aren't copy and pasted-Not too RPGish    Cons.-Game is pretty short-No hidden characters ( Just my inner Gauntlet Dark Legacy side talking)Overall a great game. Highly recommend!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												First off, if you are on the fence about buying this, i beg you not to look at the forums first. Most of it is people screaming "OMG RIP OFF GIVE ME REFUND BAD GAME -1/10" Its simply not true and ill explain why in a moment.Secondly, i will say right off the bat that im not a Gauntlet veteran. I played the game at the age of 6 for a few years, totalling probably about only 10 hours at most in my life. Since i was about 9-10, i havent touched the franchise since. I bring this up because i just want to make it clear that although i do have a nostalgia for the game, seeing as it was a game i was brought up on, i was never a huge fan on the franchise as a whole like i am in series such as the Elder Scrolls. I just dont want people to look at this review and neglect everything i say because i dont have a feeling of what the classic game brought, but i also dont want people to think that im a die hard fan and will defend it no matter what.*NOTE* Im sorry if i leave false comparisons and miss out features that the original had. Its been so long since ive played it i forget what mechanics it had. Comment if i get anything wrongWith that out of the way, ill start off with saying that i think this game is a great tribute to the 80's classic. The reboot comes with updated graphics, new powers and relics, yet keeps the feel to the original within the base of the game. You continue with your four classic characters: Warrior, Valkyrie, Elf and Wizard, each wielding unique attacks and mechanics. The one hope i had this game would have is that they would not only keep true to the original, but add onto it; constructing new methods to the way we fight and loot. And they did this superbly. One thing that i was extremley impressed with was the development they have made with the Wizard class. As stated before, i dont know how the Wizard worked past Gauntlet II, but the way combat is used in this title is Magicka esque, and i found the combat in Magicka to be incredibly satisfying. Combat on all the other characters has been enchanced too, adding several new moves for each character. The game also is no longer limited to 8 directions, which as whole makes the game feel much smoother and more enjoyable. Collecting gold, potions and keys is still within the basics of the game. Gold is now not only used for score purposes, but acts as a currency (Gold being used as a currency in a fantasy game?! Never!). You are able to purchase new apparel and relics from a store between levels. The relic system has been implemented very nicely. Now you use collected potions to to use the powers your relics give you. From a gust of wind that send your foes flying back or summoning a creature to fight alongside you, the game makes you feel like you are a true champion fighting through the tests of a dungeon.I cant comment on the multiplayer as ive only played just over an hour of the single player to see what its like, but from 2 friends of mine, theyve said theyve had no issues with it, so expect a fun, action packed quest with people around the world. Traps, unlockable doors, secrets and variations on foes are all back from the classic and they are stronger than everBut with all the praise does come negatives, and i couldnt write a review without explaining them.A major issue that people have had with the game comes technically, and it is all linked with your method of playing the game. Many people on the forums have shown disappointment in the lack of both controller support and key rebindings. I have found messages from the game's devs stating that they will fix this asap, but at launch in 2014, you shouldnt expect a game to lack a rebinding feature. Until this gets fixed, fixes have sprouted up for the controller support side. Currently, it seems that only Xbox controllers are properly supported, but many have resorted to programs such as XPadder to get their pads to work.Even though there is a fix, games shouldnt be being released with lack of basic features. Another thing that i found not to my liking is the skill shot aiming system for a few characters' skills, Valkerie's Y move expecially. You notice it in the tutorial when using a controller, and you just dont seem to have as much precision as you should. Its the same problem for some of the wizards skills also.The final gripe i have with the game is the way it handles  boss-like enemy, Death. In the previous games, Death was this powerful creature that could inflict immese amounts of damage and also held a high HP count. This take of Death i found to be more than anything, annoying. Some stages are Death stages, as in Death is present throughout the whole level. You may just think that im just bad at the game and cant kill him, but his attributes have no changed. He is now invinsible and his attacks are instant death. No special attack or relic can save you from him, you are left with just running. And this forces you to rush through levels at an absurd pace. I want challenge, but i dont think this is what i wanted. With challenge i wanted collosal hordes of enemies swarming me, not a big floating ghost shuffeling me along the level. As a whole, this game is fantastic. I want to try and compare this game to Diablo; a dungeon crawler with lots of enemies and tons of death. But without the in depth character inventory and skill trees, it kinda misses out on being like that. It instead is an action adventure hack n slash. And boy does it perfect it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Gauntlet is not a terrible game to kill some time with, especially if you play with friends but if you choose to pick it up I suggest that you only get it on sale.  It has too many flaws for me to recommend it at full price.It strays a bit from the classic titles but is still a pretty simple arcade-style game and does not get too bogged down with overly complex additions.  There are some light gear grinds in the game, you have a few different weapons and other items which you can purchase with gold and some cosmetic cloaks you can unlock through arenas, but that is about it.  It is pretty easy to get gold in the game although it can be a bit monotonous to grind enough to buy everything.  There is a campaign mode with three difficulties but no real story to speak of, not that this type of game needs one.  There is also an endless floor mode which starts extremely easy but ramps up to be quite difficult in a hurry.    Endless mode should be where the game shines, unfortunately the levels are terribly unbalanced and you can go through several floors in a row that are easy enough to be boring only to have a floor with a very small room so packed with enemies that it is nearly impossible to kite, making it extremely tedious to proceed.  Also the camera in this game is absolutely horrible so if you are playing with friends and you end up kiting in opposite directions it will attempt to keep  all of you on screen rather than focusing on your character.  This can lead to you being stuck at the very edge of your screen not able to see what is happening around you.  I would say the camera was responsible for more of my cooperative play deaths than anything else.The Death mob is present but works differently than in Gauntlet 2.  He takes up quite a bit of screen real estate and has a huge aura which can sometimes make it hard to see other enemies and projectiles.  If he touches you it is an instant kill, at least on the classes I have played.  This could actually be somewhat fun on long corridors when you are constantly running and killing  what you can as you go, but when you get locked into a room with a large number of mobs, spawners and bullet-sponge minibosses and also have death and his giant blob of color to deal with, it stops feeling challenging and just feels cheap.  The old Gauntlet games threw ridiculous hordes at you but the gameplay was just more enjoyable than it is here.   If Death was not quite as obnoxious and the camera did not continually cause problems I would find it easier to recommend.  If you want an okay coop game that you can get ten or twenty hours out of, pick it up on sale but do not expect too much out of it.  If you want to scratch the Gauntlet itch, just go fire up one of the old arcade titles because this game misses that mark.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Why it doesn't suck: It looks pretty good for a co-op dungeon crawler at this price point, it plays allright and feels fair and balanced.Why it sucks: It is not Gauntlet. Level themes are fairly mundane compared to the old school Midway versions that I was hoping this game would be. It seems there is nothing in terms of character progression other than movesets that really don't feel unique from playthrough to playthrough. Short.Rating: a box of Cracker Jacks /10: its definitely not as good as what you remember (or even resemble it) but its filling and the multiplayer is the prize in the box. Nothing beats shaming someone for shooting food even though it seems like this is the only connection to the original Gauntlets. But the value is all gone once you realize that the campaign is drawing to an end and the achievments left to unlock are just grindfests to kill monsters and collect pointless loot.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												This is not the Gauntlet you used to know.  It is not Gauntlet Legends.  Nor is it Gauntlet for the arcade.It's something... else entirely.  It isn't enjoyable and is no longer an RPG.It isn't even worth your time unless you're willing to sink hundreds of hours into the Call-of-Duty esque perk system that is based on achievements rather than experience.Your character doesn't grow more powerful unless you unlock these achievements, and you don't get the 3-tiered special ability system that Gauntlet Legends had.Not to mention that Potions now act as AMMUNITION for the "relics" that you have to buy throughout the game.  The potions that originally IN THE ARCADE VERSION that this game so egotistically proclaims that it is a callback to, no longer do a full-screen wipe of all enemies, or the awesome AoE effect of Gauntlet Legends.Gold isn't used to buy items or stats between stages.  No, it's used to unlock Relics that are REQUIRED to progress.  Which makes gold IMMEDIATELY POINTLESS.  There is no reason other than to collect it to gain Relics.  So instead of grabbing gold to stock up for something like the Super Shot, or Phoenix Familiar.  You only get Relics, that don't even work without potions.Also, DEATH IS NOW A MINIGAME.  Instead of the Grim Reaper being a constant threat in every level, he is stuck to certain points where you play what accounts to little more than a game of over-the-head TEMPLE RUN.  Not to mention he is UNKILLABLE.  Due to the moronic idea to make Potions ammo, you no longer have the ability to use a potion and LITTERALLY WARD OFF DEATH.Worst of all; you know how you had a purpose in the old Gauntlet Legends.  Yeah, remember that final boss and mastermind behind locking the four realms?  Who was it?  Oh yeah...SKORNE. The ALL POWERFUL BADASS DEMON.  He's not there.  So your purpose in the gauntlet is what?  To play around in some dumbass mage's toy.  Not very interesting.- Gold is little more than a hinderance factor to keep you playing this game, as Relics are Required to progress in any way shape or form.- Instead of levels you have petty achievements that barely do anything, which means no meaningful character progression,- Instead of special abilities you have relics that don't function without potions.- Instead of badass AoE nuke potions, you have ammunition for relics.- No epic final boss against a world-dominating demon.In all honesty, if you want to play a game like the true gauntlet classic, I would reccomend Hammerwatch, instead of this sad excuse for a gauntlet game.

If there is more Level content going to be added to the game (PLEASE!!!) there is a lot mroe room in the main dungeon before entering the doors to add more areas to branch off of and add more doors or even portals to new realms that have tons more doors and chapters to play. Just please consider this in the near future.

content:
