content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Sadly, the original version of this game didn’t get a full year before it got its upgrade, but it’s not without its charm. Essentially it is the same game as when it was released but a few tweaks and minor issues fixed, as well as a few added.The original HUB where you chose levels is now fixed so the Host is the one who picks instead of everyone running around trying to play their favorite level over and over.There’s now a mode called Endless where bad guys come in large waves and each level gets harder. I made it to level 30 before we got overrun and ran out of tokens. This mode is kind of cool because your gold outside the mode isn’t used for purchases, instead the gold you collect as you go is the only gold you get so fighting over the crown becomes crucial. You can also buy skull tokens for lives, potions, and food at the start of each floor. My advice, buy skull tokens any time you can – you will need them and they aren’t offered on every floor.By far the biggest overhaul to the gameplay at least that I saw was the reconstruction of Relic items; they don’t use potions anymore and instead use a cooldown mechanic. Talisman items are what old Relics were and require potions to use and they still have the same flaw in that if people don’t have a Talisman and pick up a potion the potion is used up and forfeit. I guess it’s a fair deal considering we have cooldown abilities now. Characters now have abilities unique to their weapon choice. The Warrior’s hammer can do the spin attack it was known for or can create a powerful shockwave. The Valkyrie can call down lightning or throw her shield like Captain America. And the Wizard has invisibility and hellfire abilities. The Necromancer can choose skeleton warrior, archer, or ghosts as her minions. Best addition so far.Enemies got an overhaul too and aside from different models here’s what I’ve seen so far:-Zombie giants have a bit more health and can pop up at random, so look for coffins.-Zombie champions come in shield and archer variant and have faster rush abilities and can call down ice arrows. A nice addition for some challenge.-Necromancers can now come in two-stage fights, kind of like a mini boss. One fight will be their mortal form and the other in their ghost form which changed very little.The first boss didn’t change at all, but now you can fight zombie giants during his fight.-Grunts look different and can be empowered by the Shaman.-Shaman look different and now shoot bolts of green that break off and turn into more bolts rather than the skull that follows you around like in the original version.-Giant Orcs can break their hammers and charge. Watch out.-New Minions: Spider soldiers. They are smaller version of Spider queens but can’t do much damage and can be stun-locked.-Spider queens look different and seem to have a little more health but no real change.-The second boss had more lighting added to the level. Thank you.-Cultist that turned into demon in the original version now explode when they die, sending purple bolts in a four-way patter. Watch out.-The cult leader got a new look and his sparkly bolt thing seems to be pretty inaccurate. Okay.-Basic demons gave the lion share of the update and can now stun lock enemies, and look different. Really watch out.That’s what I got so far. I haven’t gotten too far yet.Unfair mode is gone now and I say good riddance. It was nice unlocking certain masteries quicker but I hated being reminded I needed food when there was no food in the level. Stay dead and buried, unfair mode.Armor and weapons don’t need to be unlocked by beating certain levels in higher difficulties, now they can just be bought, which is okay I guess.All and all I like it and still recommend it. I play both single player and multiplayer.Pros- Cooldown abilities give the game a nice customization tool and good feel to gameplay.- Endless Mode for those brave enough to venture into the deep of the game.- Connection issues seemed to get a big fix. Big plus in my book.Meh- Some level layouts remain the same – some good, some still needing work.- During the Lobby scene people can put the Ready screen in an endless lobby hitting Ready/Not Ready and resetting the 30 second timer.- You can just buy the armor now instead of having to unlock it.Cons- Masters redone – abilities like less damage from the Valkyrie, coming back to life as Necromancer, and Warrior Regeneration are gone. No damage bonuses for killing so many of one foe.- Some items are still pretty worthless.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I would definitely recommend this game to anybody looking for a more simplified and more skill based ARPG experience. While it may be tempting at first glance to compare this game to other ARPGs like Torchlight, for most part the only similarities are the top view action. While I would recommend this to hardcore and softcore players alike, I think the best element of this game is the challenge. While there are some RPG elements, they are somewhat limited in scope and some are purely esthetic. I believe softcore players would not get their money's worth at the moment, so for $20 I can only recommend this to hardcore gamers who are looking to challenge themselves by using teamwork to conquer the game on its hardest difficulties.The game also rewards players who play a lot, as there are many achievements which grant permanent passive perks such as increased damage, moving speed and decreased cooldown for certain skills, which is very nice and gives the player an incentive to play a lot and perform well. This however is probably only more necessary on harder difficulties, as this is one of those games that relies more on the player's skill rather than gear, equipment, skill tree, etc... You will find none of these elements in this game as this is a remake of an arcade classic.While you can play this game solo for a while, you will need teammates who know what they're doing on latter difficulties. You can also play up to 4 players locally, so as long as there are enough controllers plugged in the USBs. There is also no in-game chat, which can be a double edged blade in my opinion. On one hand, it prevents needless distraction and conversations (mostly complaining), which helps to keep the focus on the actual game as it's fairly easy to die when not paying attention to the right elements on screen.There are four playable classes, each of them having their own style, which all feel very unique and contribute in different ways. Only one of these characters may be used at a time, so it may be important to learn how to use every class.- The Warrior, having high armor and hit points is the natural meatshield of the bunch, deals medium damage in an area of effect or an arc and can bum rush through hordes. However outside of using his skills he can be pretty slow moving. His whirlwind special attack will devastate any enemies standing in his path.- The Valkyrie, is a hybrid DPS-Tank class with high maneuverability. His main attack pierces through enemy lines and is very effective in taking out cannon fodder units, but may leave him momentarily vulnerable to stronger units. He can also take quite a beating, but not as much as the warrior. However, the ability to block incoming missles gives the Valkyrie a huge advantage in combat, which can be a great for protecting the Elf while he deals ranged damage. Quite an effective combination in my opinion. The Valkyrie's special attack is a devastating chain-damage shield throw that is very effective against hordes, but leaves him unable to block until the shield returns.- The Elf, is a basic ranged character that can effectively evade anything it comes across, as well as delivering precisie sniper shots to often elusive elite enemies with special abilities that can wreak havoc onto your party. In addition the dealing massive damage to enemies, the Elf is able to drop or attach a bomb onto one of his arrows to deal even bigger damage to radius. The Elf's evade ability can also be key when used offensively in order to reach spawn towers to drop bombs when the action becomes so heavy that no teammates have access to destroy the key units.- The Wizard, with a staggering 9 spells from which to choose from, is easily one of the most important characters due to his abilities. Each element has 3 spells (fire, ice, lightning) that are all very unique and renders the Wizard one of the most versitile character that can adapt to deal with almost any situation. From shotgun-style ice shards to your face, to mighty exploding orbs that deliver the highest DPS in an area of effect in the game, to chain-lightning and slow aura, the Wizard can quickly dispatch of hordes of enemies while supporting the rest of the party. However, this is the class with the highest learning curve due to his versitality and is by far the most complex character to play in the game.In the end, this is a great game with a lot of challenge and no drama what's so ever when playing online. I'd recommend to this game to anybody who enjoys and misses the old school arcade-type games.PROS:+ Four unique classes, each with their own roles+ Four player local or online co-op+ Challenging team-based gameplay+ No in-game chat, no drama!+ Pick up and play - Simple interface allows for quickly setting up and starting gamesCONS:- Game balance issues depending on party member play styles and preferences- Nature of gameplay may sometimes encourage players to be greedy, however this only affects post-game rankings- A little pricey at $20VERDICT: 7.2/10 - Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The Good:-Keep it simple: A touch of Titan Quest/Diablo series with less storyline and more mindless bashing.  Woo hoo! -Works great single player or 4 player co-op, local or via Steam.-A game that can get hard (but this is good!).  Coordination is key to survival.-Love the graphics, some of the sound (effects and voice-overs) reminicent of the original game leaves you with a warm and fuzzy feeling inside.-Characters can grow with experience, have multiple attack types/abilities.-Great game value for the money!The Bad:-Some may not like the idea of sharing 'badly needed' resources like food or lives.  I think it's great, however...-Some may not like the idea that some resources can be destroyed by shooting them - whoops!-(Truly the only -real- gripe I have) Keyboard bindings are not changeable.  This is a PC game too, right?  What year is this?  This is not one of the quaint memories from the past...-Players may not initially warm up to the Wizard as attacks seem more complex to play, It just takes more time to understand how he switches spells is all...

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Gauntlet is a remake of an old arcade / nintendo game I played a lot as a kid.   This version of it stays true to the original setting while improving on game play and game mechanics.  I've played it for 3 hours so far and I'm dying to get back in and play some more.Game mechanics are fair, intuitive, and fun.  I've yet to encounter a bug while playing which is always a plus.  Character dialogue is entertaining and helps to set the mood.  I like that there is a story here, but it's not being forced on you through extensive cut scenes.Multi-player is fair, making sure that people can't grief loot (all treasure is split among players).  Having people in your group really helps, but is not necessary.  I've already played through the first dozen levels solo.   I've also spent an hour in multiplayer.  It's really fun to play with friends if you have a voice chat server running.Just a heads up if you use the quick join function:  Depending on who is hosting, you may experience lag or some severe latency, if you hit that, you can always jump out and try a different game or start your own.  I do question the leader board scores, just seems....unlikely that someone earned THAT many kills/gold without an exploit...but that's just my opinion.Overall, I'd say it's definitely worth the 20 dollars to buy it.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Amazing, Simply amazing.All 4 characters feel unique and have their own play styles. (Wizard and Elf both use "Dual Analog" for aiming/moving)Graphics are pretty damn swanky.Great to see an old classic get revived without stomping all over the classics graveBrilliantly unforgiving on harder difficulties, prepare to die, especially when solo.Masteries system is an amazing way to give progression into a game, without turning it into "Who has the bigger number?" game. Simply great to earn bonuses to gameplay simply by playing!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Takes me back several years.  Still feels very much like the original with a slight twist. The relics are nice, even if I am hesitant to buy any as I don't know which are best.  But The armor is also nice, nothing is givne to you and it all must be earned within the gauntlet.  The perk system is nice too.  You can gain perks from death and just about everything else.  These perks are minor but for sure make for a easier gameplay the more you get.The competitive feel of this game is top notch.  I find myself scrambling for gold, potions, and crowns before my teammates so that I can be rewards well and be able to buy upgraded relics, armor, etc...  It makes me consider if I should steal/destroy that food or let the teammate who is 5% health have it, knowing he's been grabbing a lot of the gold in a level.  By letting a teammate die they drop a small portion of the gold they have collected and you are allowed to pick it up.  Down side is if you do this to often your teammate will catch on and begin stealing food from you as well.  The over all game play feels nice, and mouse and keyboard are adopted to the game very well.  As far as classes go Valky, Wizard, and Ranger are all about equal with their own strengths and weaknesses.  The warrior however seems very lack luster.  With a charge that has to charge up for about .75 seconds and low durabilty (from what is seems), he can't really take a beating though he is required to be in the fray of fighting. Valky, brings a melee style play to the game with a bit more durability and even some range.  She can shield to block attacks and with her shield throw can handle 2 halves of a room at once.  The archer, though limited range is very adept at staying just out of range of enemies while still staying relevant in the fight. The wizard is a more technical class and casts spells depending on what button combos you press to ready his next spell with.  But is very strong range damage.I have just scratched the surface of this game and I look forward to diving deeper into the game in the following days and weeks.  4 out of 5 stars, due to the grindy feel and warrior being a lack luster choice in comparison to the other classes.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Gauntlet is a revered classic IMO.   I've spent countless quarters playing Gauntlet in endless frustration.  This adapatation stays true to the classic while adding a modern spin on the game.  The controls are fluid and easy to pick up on for the Barbarian, Valkrie, and Elf.  However the Wizard is IMO difficult to control and play with due to the change in spells and targeting.  However it is not a limitation that others can not over come.  I'd highly reccomend this game if you are a fan of the old Gauntlet.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												The game got a lot better with the slayer variation. If the you played the old version, you might have felt like it left something to be desired. This update changed a lot of that for me, and It made me want to give this game a recommendation to you guys. This is a really good local or online co-op game with up to four players, you explore the depths of dungeons, unlock powerful abilities and have a great time doing it. Honestly if you played Gauntlets earlier games and enjoyed them, I'd highly suggest picking this one up.I think 20 dollars is honestly a decent price, but if you're unsure, get it on sale and you'll have a good time. Even moreso if you have someone to play with online or locally.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												So there's this dude named Morak. He's got all kinds of Wiz-biz, smack talk, and spare time. So he thinks to himself 'Hey, I've got a great idea: Why don't I summon a mad evil dungeon that's laid dormant for tens of thousands of years, and get a bunch of lackeys to go through them for me?'So he does, and that's where Gauntlet begins. You're Morak's lacky, just like you're the lackey for your overbearing manager at your 9-5 every day job. There are mad zombies that need to be told to ♥♥♥♥ off, There's skeletons that look like Tara Reid, and they need to eat something. And lastly, there are fire demons that don't suck the sperm out of your balls, they just suck the soul out of your bod. Morak taunts you all the way through these dungeons like an impatient child wanting that new video game or your undivided attention. I’m not going to spoil the game for you. If you have half of a brain, I’m sure your incompetent self can figure out the rest. This isn’t Gauntlet Legends, so I wouldn’t be doing backflips over it. But it’s a great hack and slash, and everyone that writes negative reviews on it are either unskilled p*u*s*s*i*e*s*, or they don’t really know how to have fun. It’s a game worth its value, and if you disagree with me: you’re an idiot and you’re wrong.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KCaHM2FZ3Tk&list=PLcbACK_uiNo6tJkIjTRifrjGSYW94VZJr&index=7That is a full LP of us doing this game on Youtube. And we're pretty damn disappointed with it. If it wasn't for the sake of the LP, we probably wouldn't even have bothered finishing it. This game is so sloppy, so lazy, so repetitive, so boring, that I just don't know why it was even made. It comes off as a cash grab, but seems to have gotten more effort put into it than those kind of games generally get. But it still feels like it was made by a computer, "game developer bot v2.1", as opposed to any kind of relatable or passionate Human being that likes video games.I was bored to death for most the game because of how repetitive it is. Levels are painfully short, sometimes not more than a few minutes, and it's the same thing over and over again. Enter room, kill enemies, proceed to next room, repeat. There's no story, quests, choices, or exploration once so ever. Other than a few character options, there's no choices to make with this game once so ever. The most they could be bothered to do was put destructable walls in a few areas. Hey, how about making each level a labyrinth where we have to explore to find the exit? No? You're just going to give us a 100% linear path? 1 way in, 1 way out, level after level? Yawn. And the "puzzles" in this game amount to little more than pulling levers that are awkwardly placed right before the doors they open, as I point out in frustration a few times in the LP. When there is only 1 path, and 1 possible lever to pull, why even bother? The lava stage was a great chance to do a real puzzle where we had to run around and pull the correct levers to get the bridge up, but nope... just go forward and there's no way you can "not" get it right. Everything in the game feels pointless like this.Almost every enemy in the game is the same, with the game recycling enemies and just changing their model to pretend it's different. The game could have benefited from around 10x as many unique bosses, but no, they are far and few between... yawn. Is that all you could come up with? How about longer non linear levels? If this was the best you could do, there should have been like 100 levels...The LP was so depressing that at the end we started talking about better games you could have spent your 20$ on instead of this crap, and our host literally raged at the game, because as an original Gauntlet player, he expected so much more. My recommendation is to not buy this. I don't care if you were an original fan or not. This is just pitiful. There's so many better more fun games you could get for 10-20$, really. We uninstalled right after the LP, and you won't be seeing us ever putting in more hours again. This game was disappointing enough for me to come review it, and we feel ripped off for the 20$ we wasted into this. We could have been playing Torchlight 2 instead.

content:
Posted: January 12
												While I actually find this game reasonably fun in spite of performance issues, what has lead to me not recommending this title was based on pre-order promises by the devs that Gauntlet™ [pre-Slayer Edition] would be coming to Linux/SteamOS - which is even still mentioned under accolades!As you can tell, they decided to change their minds about that one later on and added stuff to the as-of-now Windows-only version. Mind you, I bought the game under the impression that it was always Windows-only, but discovering this fact has soured my opinion of Arrowhead somewhat.Lesson to take home here is to NEVER PRE-ORDER GAMES IN [CURRENT YEAR].

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I wouldn't call this a Gauntlet game.Perhaps that's because my understanding of Gauntlet came from Gauntlet Legends and Gauntlet: Dark Legacy. Both excellent games with hours and hours of gameplay and tons of playable characters with alternate costumes (so you and a friend could both be warriors but look entirely different) and discoverable characters, leveling up, familiars, and a vast array of locations with interesting themes for each.Maybe it was too much to hope this game would return to styles of those forementioned, but instead fell just as flat as Gauntlet: Seven Sorrows. I even had to Google that title up because I had forgotten what it was called. Anyway, if you're wanting a game like Legends or Dark Legacy, this is not the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												It didn't occur to me right away that this was made by the Magicka team, because the game actually runs, and works. It occurred to me that this was made by the Magicka team after playing as the Wizard, and noticing how horribly optimized the game is. I can run Killing Floor 2 on full detail with no issue, I should not be getting massive slowdown from this.All in all, a fairly short, simple top-down hack 'n slash. Varies between regular dungeon levels, fleeing from Death, and arena levels, with a few bossfights to cap it off. 9 stages not counting the bosses, but each one has at least 3 parts to it. Combat feels pretty responsive and doesn't screw around in terms of difficulty. It's definitely built for co-op, and entertaining as such, although the classes are a bit imbalanced. Most specifically the Wizard is hilariously OP if you can remember your button combos, he's like 3 classes in one. Each class has a set of equippable relics to buy with your amassed gold, and grindy not-achievements to achieve for marginal passive effects... although they're all identical between classes, but still must be earned separately for each. Questionable.It doesn't hold a candle to Gauntlet Legends, no, but in the absence of a native PC version of that with netplay, it's worth getting on sale to go through once or twice with friends.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Pros: -Nice and fun, light-hearted game with friends. The more the better, honestly. If you have 4 people playing together you will definitely be having a blast.       ---- LOCAL CO-OP IS ALWAYS A PLUS YARGH. PARTY GAAAAAME.-Good music, helps a lot to make the game immersive.-Funny voice acting, always commenting on the freakin TURKEYS.-The challenge is definitely there. You can clear the whole game on normal, then go back to the very first stage, and still feel the struggle. - CROWN. CROWN. CROWN. CROWN. MINE.-Controller controls (for Thor, at least) are really nice surprisingly. I was a keyboard/mouse only person and this is the first game really that I have had zero issues with the controls. Flipside is that the controls are not re-mappable and if you're playing Merlin, it might be hard to remember the key combos.-Tons, literally TONS of monster density. It actually IS amazing and satisfying to clear cannon fodder, despite what a certain big game company whose name starts with B and ends with D seems to despise in their game.Cons:-May get repetitive if you aren't playing with friends and fighting over the crown. May even get repetitive then. But the promise that this game made is to provide tons of monsters for you to kill, and in that regard, it does not disappoint.-Keys are not re-mappable, as many others have pointed out, and may become an inconvenience for some people if they do not like current bindings. Would advise not getting the game until they get that patched up if that is the case.-There isn't really much randomness to the game. The concern with this is that after playing through it once, it might seem pointless to go through it again a second time. Some people will argue that higher difficulty makes it into a completely different game, however the lack of randomization might become the death of this game. I have not reached the end of the game yet, so I do not know as of now whether there will be infinite dungeons or whatever later (I HOPE THERE ARE, HINT HINT DEVS).- Merlin's combos are kind of hard to understand since he has 9 spells to cast and every time you wish to cast a different spell, you need to stand still (I think, maybe you don't) and think about what combination of 3 keys to press in order to change your spell. But when learned, Merlin proves to be the most powerful and versatile character in the game, in my opinion.All in all, I would definitely recommend this game. You can most definitely get at least 10 good hours of quality gameplay out of this title. 9/10 in my book.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												The Slayer Edition has made some great changes that increase the replayability, some so-so changes that let you change your characters look for a price, difficulty changes that will prevent less-skilled players from ever playing this game without friends and some dog-dumb interface changes that make me wonder if they even ran this through a usability study.You now need controller 1 for EVERYTHING. Oh, you can still play by yourself with any controller, but as soon as you want to choose the next level or anything in the main hub you have to grab controller 1 again. Even logging into your WB account will require a keyboard to type username and password and, you guessed it, controller 1 to cycle through the fields and even click the submit button!I enjoyed Gauntlet when I bought it and hope to do so again, but for now the Slayer Edition feels like an alpha version in desperate need of some further testing an updates.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Great game, nostalgic as all hell but has a disturbing subtle twist: Thor is the only actual character and the rest are his imaginary friends. "... but if I'm playing <class> solo, then where is Thor?" That's where Thor, losing his sanity, begins to dress up as said imaginary friend to become them, giving them voice and bring them alive in his own little world. "... but he/she looks nothing like Thor!" Because he percieves them as different than himself because, you know, imaginary friends.And then he's thrown in the world of Gauntlet. What a sad tale, but great party game to play with friends.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This is how a reboot should be done. Taking the general mechanics of the old Gauntlet games, tarting them up a bit and then rebuilding just about everything else from the ground up.I will stress, however, that the game is best played co op, especially local co op. If by yourself, the hordes can be a little difficult to deal with and the fights can quickly get repetitive. But the combat is really nice and visceral and exploring the levels with a friend can be fun and interesting.Buy it if you plan on playing it with friends. If you're a solo gamer, I'd probably give it a miss.

												9 times out of 10 these "remakes" are a total money grab, full of bugs or pay walls. I am thrilled to say this is not one of them.Gauntlet is really a great remake of the classic game I enjoyed as a kid. The classic gameplay is there with some additional features that modernize the game play so you won't get bored right away.  Online play, equipment upgrades, and additional abilities make this just enough of an upgrade to make this a worthy successor.Online worked great, my friend and I connected instantly and enjoyed 2 hours of fast paced challanging game play.5 starrs *****

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Though there's a few things wrong with it (character selection, lobbies, and sometimes the map breaks) Gauntlet (2014) is a decidedly fun romp with tight, well-balanced gameplay ("hard" is, indeed, hard).  It's pretty short, you could easily finish all the maps in a day, but there is a bit of replayability because each of the characters plays differently and you need to beat higher difficulties to unlock everything.  The $20 release-day price tag is pretty reasonable, and it will be a shoe-in on a half-off sale a few months from now.  Here's hoping for a Gauntlet 2 that's even better.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Completed first run through normal co-op.  I had Valkyrie, friend had Elf.  Great fun and can't wait to get into the higher levels.  Wish there was a bit more enemy variety.I played around with Elf a little bit, and he's really fun.  Nice mechanical and gameplay style change from Valkyrie.  I messed around with Wizard, and he's really Magicka-y, which is great, but I didn't get into him enough to really have an opinion yet.  Then I started a game with Warrior...The Warrior class is weak compared to the others and just isn't fun to play after doing a run with Valkyrie and messing around with Elf for a bit.  Warrior could use a massive buff and/or re-design.  Valkyrie's power attack (Y on 360 controllers) is basically a combination of Warrior's charge and power attack except it's instant whereas the Warrior abilities take forever to charge.  Valkyrie's special move, the shield toss, functions and feels amazing to use.  Warrior's spin attack is cool-looking, but feels weak as it doesn't actually do much damage.  It feels like Warrior is missing an ability because his charge is so stupid and weak and requires a ton of space and time to use, and his power attack is single-target and has a horrible wind-up.  Warrior also has a terrible voice.Aside from the Warrior, my only other beefs are lack of enemy variety, heavy use/reliance on summoning portals, only 3 boss fights, and I feel there could be more variety with character customization.The game really shines in co-op as the classes are designed to synergize.  My friend and I had an amazing time running through the game with Thyra and Questor.  Questor is really funny, and it's fun to hear the characters interract with each other.  We'll be playing through the harder difficulties this weekend and I'm looking forward to any DLC or expansions that come out for this one because it definitely leaves you wanting more when you finish it.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Just finished this game with some friends,all i gotta say, it was fun. First thing to talk about is gameplay, it's pretty tough, especially doing it on solo. You are able to use relics to do more destruction to enemies. Though it took me and my friends 6 hours to beat it, I'm hoping there would be DLCs, maybe new characters, maybe from Dark Legacy? Maybe more areas? now for some problems, theres some bugs that occur, sometimes the boxes that you have to move, randomly stops moving until you restart the area. Another thing, yes it's short, and could use more areas. This one thing that bothers me the most, is the classic setting in the graphics tab, it was like I was blind or something. Sad thing about this game, is that there can't be a same class in the same team, and plus needs more colors, more like the older games please. One thing to recommend to the developers, is that the Elf is very OP, they might wanna fix the Elf class so it can be balanced a bit. Pros: +Cool gameplay against hordes of monsters +4 player coop, even online +UpgradesCons: -Too short-Classic setting in graphics tab is very dumb-Needs more areas (and Dark Legacy characters please?)-Needs freedom to use same classes in the same team-Semi Buggy-Elf is very OP 6 / 10 It was fun, yet not very satisfied with it, if you like slaughtering a horde of monsters, this is a game for you.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Ok heres my review after playing a bit.The Game is Short it seems to have only 5 Chapters.When you start the Game youre at the Portal,there is a Item Dealer too.From there you can go trough 1 Door,Chapter 1.After finishing it the 2nd Door Unlocks and there 5 Doors at all.I finished 3 Chapters by now,and their was little to no variation in Design of the Levels,all the Same Dungeon.There also no Item Drops or Loot.new Items must be bought and there some expensive for each Charackter.I also only saw 1 Type of Boss Enemy till now,the Necromant.Now to the good things,the Controlls are very good and optimized for Gamepad,even i prefer Mouse normaly i like Gamepad here cause it works so well.As Elf you shoot your Bow with the right Analog stick and you walk with the left one that works very nice.The Mage has 3 basic Spell Buttons and must combine 2 of them to select a Spell,so at all he has 9 Spells.The Gold you find is not shared.Thats alot of negative Stuff i mentioned but ITS STILL FUN TO PLAY and i think its worth its Price (you can get it for 11,99 outside Steam)Just dont expect something with the Epic Background of Diablo,its still a remake of a C64 Game ;)A Chapter takes around 20-30 Minutes to play,but there 4 different Difficulties.To unlock all Skills and Stuff for a Charackter you have to play longer,i dont think that finishing the Game once would unlock more than like 20% of a Charackters Skill,rather less like 15 %Its designed and thought that you replay the Leves.After finishing a Level there is a list of the current "World Champion",and then off the current best "Speedrunner" too.So if you like to compete in such things,its there.In the End,for the 11,99 you can buy the Game in several Stores,i would say its worth the Money.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I'll start with the negatives - So far I've had it crash once and fully close itself twice, all on the first boss. Sometimes my attacks have been flying in the wrong directions (I'm playing Wizard so this is.... troubling to say the least. I feel I should add this may be the controller). I think that's about it (Atleast all I've encountered so far).I've found besides the slight issue above, it handles great, I'm really enjoying it, I'm playing on 'Hard' I think unfair sums it up with "Why can't I eat this gold food?!" but yeah. So far I've been playing with my friends (separate times) usually as Wizard/Valkyrie combo, it's a rather over powered class combination, you have the Valkyrie blocking whilst the Wizard nukes the crap out of everything. I mean it's still challenging, it's not an insta-win combo, there have been rages and there have been times where I'm just sat there, staring at the "GAME OVER" screen just wondering why I got death by shoe, but all in all, it's me failing to get my timings right and landing in the middle of a group of mobs without my shield available.The tutorial will get you accustomed to each character and you'll be, I suppose, forced to try them all. But this is in no way a bad thing, This will help you decide which class is best for you.On the note of the DLC, being armour or weapons, they aren't OP or in any way game changers, all 'equipment' is cosmetic, you do have Relics which are new and now require the potions to use (Also Potions don't get rid of Death now?! T_T) All in all, I'd give this a solid 9.9/10 (Nothing's perfect, get used to it). I hope you enjoy your gaming experience :D

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Gauntlet is what old games used to be. That feeling when you are being overwhelmed by almost unbeatable odds in a classic  dungeon comes back to haunt you in ways you haven't felt in a long time. long ago games used to have lives, yes I know that sounds odd but most games are just respawn till you win. This game is not that. your team will earn lives by killing hordes of enemies as fast and as effectively as you can. some might say why do you say "Effectively" well this is because if you run into a huge horde of monsters thinking you can just attack blindly and win you ...cannot.  this may result in destroyed food (this is what is used for health) you may hit a potion that is used for special attack runes that you get by using your gold at the start of the match making presses.Overall the comparison is that of Diablo but the issue here is that Gauntlet came first in 1985. This new version of the game goes back to the 1985 arcade feel, over the N64 Gauntlet that felt more Bolders gate for ps2. This is a good thing! It brings that odd feeling where you hate and love your teammates from one second to the next. you will discover really fast how amazing the wizard is but also how greedy he is for food. This is just one example of things that may happen. Many times you will need food (Health) badly and some team mate will shoot the food by accident or eat it when they are almost full. This feeling is reminiscent to Turtles in time(snes), and the great "Pizzatime!" health steals of yonder year. Overall this game is really good. Each chapter has 4 stages. each stage has 4 levels. So overall you are looking at 48 individual stages of fun. Each with a difficulty level that changes the entity of battle. that's 183 stage variations. *( -9 levels because the last stage of each chapter is a boss battle arena. )*This is a recommended buy for sure if you are looking for some fun hack and slash play with strategic battles and overwhelming odds. Side notes of interest: Level design is great			Voice acting is great ( well written banter between the classes) 		Graphics are nice classic feel to it not too distracting.  (We can  only hope in the future they may add some DLC for new classes and more armor and such.

												Great fun game, especially when played with Gamepad and 2 player co op.  I never played the arcade version so this was new to me. content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Gauntlet is infamous to many old-school gamers. A four-player co-operative/competitive adventure in the dungeons, it's seen it's fair share of versions, from the original on the NES, to Gauntlet Legends on the Dreamcast and even further to Seven Sorrows on PS3 and Xbox 360.  But out of all of them, I respect this version the most. One rule that's vital to adhere to is a half-begrudging friend system. Share your food with your allies to keep them alive (or destroy it when they need it if you REALLY don't like them), but under no circumstances can you share your gold. Trust me, they wouldn't for you. It's a system that even best friends stick to, you CAN'T share gold, so while you're working together with your friends, you may be surprised to realise you're also planning for their demise or the next way you can steal gold from them.This is a fantastic revamp of a legendary game, Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												My review of gauntlet so far.... The game brings something new to the franchise while still keeping the formula that I grew up loving from Gauntlet Legends, and Gauntlet Dark Legacy. Each of the four classes plays different in a dynamic way, along with no option to play the same class when playing multi-player, while some consider it a negative thing, I believe it helps keep the team you have balanced in the dungeons, no redundancy.** Warning Spoilers Ahead.**Each level is divided into three Acts.Act I - Standard, fun mobs, get loot, solve puzzles, the puzzle piece of this is the nice part, it keeps you thinking when you're fighting through hordes of enemies, rather than mindlessly pressing buttons.Act II - It is a race to the finish, whether it be an erupting volcano, encroaching darkness, or even Death himself. You are forced to keep on your toes.Act III - It's a hold out. Wave after wave of monsters swarm at you in a varied arena.Relics - Powerful items that allow you to use pretty sweet abilities. Ranging from super increased attack speed to summoning mirror images of your hero for increased damage and crowd control.Overall I would give the latest Gauntlet an 8.3/10. The only gripes I have with it, is it was no where near as lengthy that Dark Legacy or Legends. If there is ever any DLC for this game, I'd highly recommend they rebuild Gauntlet Dark Legacy Levels/story.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												4 classic classes, 3 classic chapters with a central hub at the start of each game. Abilities are Shift, Space, and Right Click plus the ability to get 2 items bound to Q and E for extra powers. The game is fanastastic and very polished. I don't regret hyping myself up for this indie title. The art style is reminiscent of Magicka (same devs), but this has it's own zombie horde feel that really requires a good mindset and strategic positioning plus a good grasp of the class you're playing at the time. Overall I'd rate this a 7 or 8 out of 10 with a high replayability value. I'd like to try out survival mode soon and see how the random generated content comes into play. I am on Chapter 3 and then will start a Hard campaign and then eventually Unfair difficulty. Fun stuff!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Great game, nostalgic as all hell but has a disturbing subtle twist: Thor is the only actual character and the rest are his imaginary friends. "... but if I'm playing <class> solo, then where is Thor?" That's where Thor, losing his sanity, begins to dress up as said imaginary friend to become them, giving them voice and bring them alive in his own little world. "... but he/she looks nothing like Thor!" Because he percieves them as different than himself because, you know, imaginary friends.And then he's thrown in the world of Gauntlet. What a sad tale, but great party game to play with friends.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												It reminds me a bit of "Gauntlet: Dark Legacy" for the PS2, albeit a simpler version.  "G:DL" sported more than four characters and the ability to level up your character's attributes.  While you can purchase items at a vendor here, you're limited to relics (passive buffs) and cosmetic upgrades.  This is a shame, as "G:DL" was (and still is) my favorite Gauntlet game to date.With that said, this version of "Gauntlet" still has a lot to offer.  Each character has its own way of playing (the wizard is the hardest in my opinion due to his number of spells) and local multiplayer is available via KB/M and Controller.  It's still worth the $20.00, I feel, but I can't help but be a bit disappointed by the step down it takes when compared to "G:DL".

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Never written a review on steam before, but here it goes. Simply pros/cons first.Pros - No bugs, at least none that I found. - Game play has been improved in flexability - Classes have distinctly different abilities and strategies - Still feels arcady - Local Co-op as well as online, missing from too many games today - Partially randomized mapsCons- Only three major areas - Only three bosss- Only clocked in 7 hours, maybe less- Enemies left something to be desired. I haven't played too much of the original gauntlet, but I have played several hours, and probably clocked in a couple hundred hours on Dark Legacy over a long period of time. Since I heard about this game I was hyped and pre-ordered it pretty quickly. When I first started playing it, I was both stoked and let down at the same time, but honestly probably still more satisfied than anything. One of the biggest problems I had with the other games, more so Dark Legacy since that is what I played more, was that all the characters seemed to play pretty similarly. This game has eradicated that completely. I feel that the game is lacking in some areas, such as could have done the level system like Dark Legacy or perhaps added actual equipment instead of just cosmetic items. This game cannot be enjoyed if you're purely focused on modern styles of games or you're too focused on the other games in the series. What this game is designed as is an arcade dungeon crawler hack and slash. And it does that rather well. Yeah, there's going to be some grinding and some of the enemies are going to be repetative, but that's kind of what this genre is. I think back to Dark Legacy and I remember that throughout all the areas all of the enemies were so painfully similar in mechanics. Looked differently sure, but only the bosses in that game were actually different, there was no real strategy in the game play. This game adds a bit of strategy and different types of game play with the classes. The enemies may all seem similar, but there's more variety in the actual combat from the enemies than in the past games. I found myself trying out the different classes and found each one to be rather balances in the area it focused in and I had to change my mindset when I changed characters. There's not much for puzzle solving and the maps aren't exactly designed like mazes, but they are decent sized levels with a little bit of exploring. One of the biggest problems I have found is that the level design is rather similar in structural layout with each series of stages. Only a few bosses, though they are intersting, at least the first and last one are. Requiring a bit of thinking and paying attention, figuring out what to do rather than just spam the attack. I spent most of my time doing this on solo, and I enjoyed it very much. Multiplayer is even better, this game is designed to play with a friend. I fully plan on having fun with this game and trying out the harder difficultings and mastering the usage of the different characters. I felt that the 20 dollars I spend on this game has been well worth it already. It's not a story game, it's an arcade style game. If you're looking for some rpg with a great story and long campaign, you probably won't find it here. There's much more that they could have done with this game, but in the end, it is just an arcade-style game. I hope that more levels will be added in the future, because it was much, much shorter than I had thought it would be, but it has replay value with the masteries, the four different characters, and of course, the multiplayer option.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												A series revived and overall a fantastically fun game; however it's not without it's faults. One, the class selction is limited and because of it you rarely get to play the role you want to play and you'll often see people leave if they don't get the class they want. They should have made two versions of each class like Dark Legacy so people would have more choice and variety for gameplay as the 4 classes get tiring. Two, the items you purchase are merely cosmetic and do nothing, invest your hard earned cash in actives. Three, there is a desperate lack of of levels and variety in the game. This game would thrive off of more unique stages and level creator would be amazing here.  Four, the final and most pressing issue, there's a huge lack of communication. In a cooperative game like this it is very difficult to function properly without proper communication; voice chat, a more fleshed out command system, or even a simple chatbox would makes a world difference in improving the game. The thing Gauntlet does right though is gameplay itself. The actives are brilliant, the gameplay is fantastic, coop is fantastic, and the style is gorgeous. In total I think this game is a step in the right direction for the Gauntlet series and I hope it gets expanded upon in the future or gets a sequel that get's it right. $20 is a steep price for such a simple game, wait until it's about $10 to get your money's worth.TL:DRPros- Gameplay- Style- Actives- Coop- LANCons- Lack of Communication- Lack of Characters- Too Short- Overpriced7/10

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												A great co-op dungeon crawler experience.  Fans of the classic arcade games (or the re-release of Dark Legacy for the GCN) may find themselves a bit lost, however.  Gone are the days of defending the realms from the demon Skorn, hunting down the traitorous Garm, and the great wizard Summner no longer is even a part of the game.  Instead, players meet Morak, an underdeveloped character with no story whose only purpose is to "summon the gauntlet", be a disembodied voice, and inevitably turn evil for the last boss fight.  A bit underwhelming compared to the expansive and varied play, along with the great non-linear explorable maps, that existed in this game's 1998 arcade counterpart.  Boss fights have also undergone huge changes, some for the better and others for worse, compared to the 1998 classic that everyone playing this game knew and loved.  As mentioned above, levels are extremely linear, with no alternate paths to explore or depth to plunge into using extra keys (stages now have EXACTLY the correct amount for each locked door).  However, this also means that all the puzzles that existed in the first 2 iterations of this game are gone, making levels very repetitive, and more importantly also removing the ability to hunt down items of power to use against bosses.  Instead, boss fights are now broken up by phases, not unlike bosses in WoW or Diablo 3.  While this makes boss fights interesting (and often times very hectic) it doesn't come across as a change that the game needed to undergo, and pulls away even more from the nostalgic value of the game, one of the biggest traits this title had going for it.  Couple this with the fact that not a single boss from the classic Gauntlet titles makes it over to this game, and players will find themselves feeling very confused as to why the developers made so many unnecessary (and sometimes just plain bad) changes to a loved game franchise.Players will still get to enter into the depths of the "Gauntlet" as one of the four classic characters they remember: The warrior, the valkyrie, the archer (he is NOT the "Elf", he's the damn ARCHER, talk about a fantasy stereotype sellout move), and the wizard.  All of these characters have undergone a number of drastic changes, but the developers did a fantastic job of keeping the core aspects of each class intact while simultaneously removing the outdated (and oftentimes unwieldy) inventory and character statistics (hp, str, def, etc).  The warrior has retained his might cleaving spin, the valkyrie's high defense has carried over into the acquisition of a shield toss and shield block, and the archer is still an archer (and still not an "Elf).  The greatest changes came to the wizard, who now can transmute combinations of 3 different elements in order to access a wide variety of skills (those who enjoy playing Invoker in DotA/Dota2 will recognize these mechanics).The game is plagued, however, by a very prominent lack of communication and lacks even the most basic of chat features.  While this was also true for the classic 1998 game, all 4 players were at a single machine during those times and could simply speak to each other.  Now, with no form of voice or text chat, you'll find yourself quickly kicking players mid game who don't follow your unspoken, incommunicable  plans so that the group can continue pressing forward.  With players now ALL playing together through online connectivity, this is nothing more than a simple "dropping the ball" moment on the part of the developer, and is hopefully something that will get fixed soon either in a patch or (if they like to scam people as much as EA) in a DLC.Speaking of DLC, it can't come fast enough.  With only 3 "realms", and each realm only having 3 stages and a boss fight, the game is CONSIDERABLY shorter than the previous games in the gauntlet series.  With the lack of runestones to collect, lack of realms to explore (and lack of depth to the stages), lack of stained glass shards to grab from the bosses, no battlefield at the tower (hiding that last elusive runestone), and no final trip into hell to purge the ultimate evil the only thing we can wonder is... why the hell did our characters even bother coming to this dungeon in the first place?  Hopefully in the near future, this will all be addressed in the form of DLC.  All we can do is hope that the developers truly love the Gauntlet franchise enough to bring back the large, iconic realms and bosses that we all remember and love... even if that means having to pay another $5-$10 for the 4-8 realms (depending on the version of the game you previously played) that were inexplicably left out.Even with all the awkward changes made, and content that was left out, this is still a GOOD hack & slash co-op experience.  It's not winning any awards in its current state however.  All we as fans of the true Gauntlet can do is hope that WB and Arrowhead love this franchise enough to bring back everything fans remember and loved about the classic games in DLC, changing this into a GREAT hack & slash co-op experience.  Otherwise, this game could likely match Diablo 3 in disappointment as a "finished" product.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I've been enjoying this game tremendously. It's a nice break from some of the heavier RPGs I spend a lot of time playing. I've played through 2/3 of the game with the wizard on normal, and 1/3 with the elf on normal by myself. Last night, I had a couple friends over, and we played some three-player local on hard mode. I ran with the wizard. One friend ran with the elf. The other started with the warrior, but that didn't last long. He switched to the valkyrie after 45 minutes and had a MUCH better time. We found the warrior to be an extreme liability. In any given map, for each Skull Token the wizard and elf used, the warrior would use 3-4. Most of the food went to the warrior as well. I was curious if perhaps it was just my friend being new at this, so I tried a few levels this morning with the warrior...I found the same thing. Here were some thoughts:1) The warrior's basic attack moves him forward a tiny bit if you aren't careful...this is not good - it leaves him vulnerable after 2-3 swings to enemy hordes which overlap around his attack arc.2) The warrior's strong attack has a little too much of a delay/wind-up...in the time it takes him to position and wind-up next to a spell caster, the caster can hit him with a bolt and interrupt him.3) Whirlwind Attack is the saving grace...it's great.4) Bull rush, again, has timing problems...it takes a bit too long to charge it up. The other three classes "escape" ability is basically instant use - elf press a button, valkyrie hold the stick, and the wizard has TWO-  to press a quick button combo for flame serpents (this does some damage to make up for it,) or protective sphere (which has a persistent knockback and a great duration.) The warrior's takes a charge-up time, and doesn't really do damage...not good. 5) Leaping attack looks great, but isn't terribly effective. It requires good aim, a bull rush (which takes time to charge,) and a timed button press, and does limited damage in terms of multiple targets...not good. I grant that my experience is limited, but these are my impressions of the warrior. The other three classes - SO MUCH FUN. Love love love the wizard's mechanics. The elf's agility is fantastic - dodges like no one's business. The valkyrie FEELS like a tank, and I love the art design on her - she looks like someone you would NOT want to tangle with. Overall, I love the game. Red warrior needs rebalance badly.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This is an ARCADE game being true to its old school roots. Be aware of this if you buy this game. As expected the game needs some more polish and bug fixes, but the devs are working on that. And don't think that this game is an ARPG, like Torchlight or Grim Dawn, it's not. It's an action packed dungeon crawler.I didn't know what to expect when I bought this game and initially I got a little put off, but after having played it for a while and especially after playing it in multiplayer, I'm having a great time playing Gauntlet. Play this game with some friends and you'll have this  blast from the past, keeping you on the edge of your seat while you're hacking and slashing your way through hordes of monsters, frantically searching for delicious food.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I have two different aproaches to this game.  Is it "Fun"?  Yes    Is the content enough?  No.   I find this to be a casual game and nothing more, but to really get the good stuff, you have to grind out the chapters.   Furthermore, you can have four chapters completed, and then the game will crash and you loose pretty much everything since the start of the story.  The classes seem rather unbalanced, with the Archer being the FOTM,  The Wizard is a conveluted button push combo system which gets in the way of the immersion.    It's fun, for a while, then you have to play something else, then come back.  Long sessions tend to get very repetative.  Don't think it's worth the price, but should be $14.99 at most.

												Great game, nostalgic as all hell but has a disturbing subtle twist: Thor is the only actual character and the rest are his imaginary friends. "... but if I'm playing <class> solo, then where is Thor?" That's where Thor, losing his sanity, begins to dress up as said imaginary friend to become them, giving them voice and bring them alive in his own little world. "... but he/she looks nothing like Thor!" Because he percieves them as different than himself because, you know, imaginary friends.And then he's thrown in the world of Gauntlet. What a sad tale, but great party game to play with friends.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												This is a very fun game! Every class feel exactly how I would want to play them; the warrior a berserking massive damage dealing invincible monster, valkyrie an agile defensive fighter with good damage and interesing tools that aren't so obvious at first, the mage a variety of tools at his disposal to deal with any situation, the archer kite kite kite and destroy spawners/enemies, the necromancer rising armies from the dead stealing souls and breaking everything! I've enjoyed learning each class to the best of my ability so far, it's fun to play solo or in a group, and most fun with friends. Once you get the hang of the game you can breeze through hard mode campaign mode (it's fun trying to complete these levels as quickly as possible imo) endless mode is always going to be difficult pretty much, and you've got plenty of stuff to do through achievements, which may not give you anything as a bonus to your character, but still bragging rights are always a thing.This game is actually quite difficult at first and it is a blast learning the best way to deal with any situation handed to you, you'll find yourself cornered, overwhelmed, challenged, and dieing a lot. But it's part of the learning curve, it's fun to go back and see how well you perform compared to when you first started and you can try and challenge yourself  to use weapons you're not used to. Overall i've spent 140 hours just about in 1-2 months just playing this game (slayer edition) and it has been a blast!The main reason this game has so many negative reviews is mainly because of an update (slayer edition) that change a fairly large portion of the game, classes, and overall appearance. I haven't felt like I am missing out on anything with this purchase. In my opinion if you like difficult games, give this game a go, even if your new or old to the gauntlet series this should be quite the blast!

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Very action packed old-school in new-school style of top down view fighting.  Having played Gauntlet II many many years ago, this seems to really put it into a modern skin, and they have done it quite well.  If anything, it still feels very linear and the feel of mobs coming at you in a pressure for you to find the exit has diminished (at least in normal difficulty, this may be entirely different in Hard and/or Unfair modes).   The maze-like style of the dungeon is gone, it's more of a linear path, which is somewhat disappointing.  None the less, it still is well worth the $20.8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I can;t recommend this game. Despite it being really fun to begin with and with some great-feeling intense combat, at the end of the day, this is NOT Gauntlet. The main problems with the game are as follows:1) The game is VERY short. 30-odd levels, most of which are VERY small and very similar - it will take you a mere 4 hours to see the entire game2) The levels are 100% linear - you move from one rectangular area to next, and you are stuck in each till you clear it; additionally, the keys you need are pretty much lying right beside the locked door :/ There is zero exploration here3) There is almost zero replay value once you complete the game4) Horrible class balance....the Warrior stinks, Wizard is OP noob mode etc etc - maybe deliberate?At the end of the day this should be a 5 or 10 dollar game, as you don't get very much for your buck. Really fun, but only for 4 hours.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Gauntlet is a very fun co-op game. It has a good mix of characters with a nice assortment of abilities and combat is fun, but can be bit overwhelming at times. In my opinion the overwhelming hordes of enemies make the combat really fun and furious. The game lacks any chat functionality. It is also very easy to lose track of your character on the screen. I have also had a few games where it ended abruptly, citing simply Connection Lost. In total the game is very fun and worth a purchase, despite a few issues and lacking chat features.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												From the makers of Magicka, Gauntlet is developed by Arrowhead Game Studios and published by WB games.  A reboot based on the previous eight entries since 1985.Straight off the bat the game thrusts you into the amazing tutorial as it offers you a simple yet effective taste of the setting, the character classes and a few enemy types.CHARACTERS:Warrior is slow, strong, has a handy (but situational) rush attack and his Spin attack makes him immune to all damage while it's in effect.  Yes, it's called "Spin Attack"...freaking stupid.Part Captain America, part wonder woman, part bond villain.  The Valkyrie can throw her shield, dash through enemies and use her shield to block everything that's not an area attack.  Cry me a river, Cyclops.Oh look it's an archer.  Shoot, snipe, lay bombs, shoot bombs, roll.  That's it.  Overpowered little ♥♥♥♥er.If the tutorial didn't make you hate the Wizard completely, then you're in for a treat.  Obviously the most complicated character to play and the hardest to master (if you haven't played Magicka), the wizard uses ice, fire and lightning as a primary element, then a secondary element's as an implement to create different spells.  Sounds complicated? it's not.  There's only 9 different combinations you can make.  Memorize them and you will become the most indispensible player in your team.  Well, besides the damn elf.The game sells for 20 dollars on steam and is rather short, difficult, you can't pick the same character, has a couple of hard to replicate glitches and is frustrating to play solo.  The fun factor in this game comes from playing with friends, finding combos with the different characters, and dying as it rewards you by giving you abilities, achievements and experience as a player.  With the promise of DLC in the future, and the fact we've already invested more than 20 hours in the game, I can safely say we've gotten our money's worth.Unless you don't have any friends.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Though the game is completely fantastic it's also quite horrible.!!!NOTICE!!! this is essentially a first impression based off the first 5 levels !!!NOTICE!!!Unfortunately i can't bring myself to giving this game an unbiased opinion upon comparing it to the older ones. i'm sorry, but i was misinformed about the game by people saying that it's just like the classics. though yes the description says "completely new experience!" i did question it, but was told that that was nothing to worry about and part of what made the game better, which ended up making the game more interesting rather than "better".-so you can change how your characters look and with said changes your abilities change with them but i wish you could be able to buy an item, and individually select which item and skill you wanted to use-Turbo bar has been removed and replaced with skills. though this brings newer ways to play the game i do miss being to use up the entire turbo bar to do a badass ultimate like skill-A lot of the exploration seems to be missing and replaced with jump pad like platforms and cracked walls which can only be broken by putting and explosive barrel in front of it, which can be blown up beforehand so you miss out on exploration because you made a stupid mistake rather than failing to do some secret stuff in a specific way-Death is no longer killable with skills and potions, instead you now have to run away from it until it temporarily disappears-any explosion, whether it be from barrels, skills, or potions all seem to do diddly squat-Monster Generators stay the same and always send out the same enemies through its entire lifespan + instead of being big, medium, small, dust they have a health bar and if you're melee (read below) you're pretty much guaranteed to lose some HP trying to take it down unless you sit back and let the ranged classes do the work-keys, potions, and food are no longer randomly findable items as well as there being enough keys for you in every level to open all locks, and only one type of potion-characters now have full lines when talking and they interact with what's going on and what they do such as eating food when on super low health, or another character dieing-has that hack and slash gameplay but that beat-em-up feel to itThe single most cancer mechanic of the game that caused multiple problems: (if you read this and decide to tell me to just not use a controller, you're a ♥♥♥♥ing heretic)-Valkyrie and Warrior are now melee: they try to make for the loss by giving them more health but that doesn't matter because you still have to keep your distance from the swarming amounts of enemies. not just that but i feel like i'm being forced to use a keyboard + mouse or get a trickshot controller because the claw method forces you to miss things completely. for instance, the valkyrie starts with a shield that can be thrown but guess what, the right thumbstick is to aim and the left thumbstick is to move, SO if i want to throw my shield at enemies meanwhile running away i have to take my right thumb off the thumbstick to press B, BUT since my character is running in the opposite direction and i'm no longer aiming the game just naturally makes the character turn in the direction that i'm running and throws the shield in said direction instead. but don't worry Archers and Wizards are excluded from such a thing, BECAUSE they automatically do their basic attack in the direction that they're aiming which the Valkyrie, dunno bout the Warrior, DOES NOT HAVE.Now why would you do this? D:-Archer is no longer femaleNo matter what you gotta give em credit for this-food can still be destroyed + the game calls out the person who did it XD

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews. But I can safely say. I DO NOT LIKE THIS GAME. It gets so ungodly repetitive after the first few missions and if you play by yourself (like I did) the game is so very unbalanced. Enemies will surround you and no matter what class you're playing there is no dodging that. Your health drops faster than a led balloon by even the weakest enemies. Lets not also mention that the coloseum is basically impossible after the third round, also no matter what your character is. In order to even get some what good you need good equipment and equipment takes quite a bit to get. If you have friends over a lot and you need to play something, This could be a good time waster. Maybe find some enjoyment out of it for a good hour or two. But after that it just gets too boring. To sum it all up, if you are planning on playing this game by yourself. You will find it stupidly hard. (if you play on normal atleast, as did I, which could also contribute to its difficulty but none the less. Normal shouldnt be Hard, you know?) If you have friends, this might be a fun game for a while. For its price I suppose its not all bad. However I did get a load of DLC from lootcrate for this game. Which is why I got it in the first place. I, personally. Do not really find this game enjoyable

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This game is a fantastic update for the old Gauntlet style games. It is NOT, repeat NOT, supposed to be like Legends, Dark Legacy, or Seven Sorrows. This is a reboot of the FIRST Gauntlet! The dungeon crawler one that was actually hard. They did a Phenominal job at recreating this game. It reminds me of the Classic like no other. From the arcade style music to the hack and slash style gameplay (except for Merlin cause he's a BAMF). The only problem I have with the game is it cannot be put into larger screen resolutions, such as 1920x1080. Look past that and you've got yourself a quality dungeon crawler to be enjoyed with friends.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Highly recommended.Gauntlet is back !!!.One of my favourite games of all times. If the original one was excellent, this new one respects the soul of the original one and goes beyond it. You even have the possibility to select the classic view (graphics) but, to be honest, I love the new ones!.It seems to me that this new retake is harder than the original one, at least, in single player mode.This is the classic game that will make you addict to. Hack & Slash at its best.What confusses me a bit is that every character has different controls but, at then end, there aren't so complicate that you cannot quickly learn them.Still not played the multiplayer side but, that was the most interesting and funny thing of this game: cooperation!. Probably, one of the first (and best) cooperative games ever.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Highly recommended.Gauntlet is back !!!.One of my favourite games of all times. If the original one was excellent, this new one respects the soul of the original one and goes beyond it. You even have the possibility to select the classic view (graphics) but, to be honest, I love the new ones!.It seems to me that this new retake is harder than the original one, at least, in single player mode.This is the classic game that will make you addict to. Hack & Slash at its best.What confusses me a bit is that every character has different controls but, at then end, there aren't so complicate that you cannot quickly learn them.Still not played the multiplayer side but, that was the most interesting and funny thing of this game: cooperation!. Probably, one of the first (and best) cooperative games ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A quick run through and I have to say this is a fantastic piece of classic dungeon crawling. Simple yet effective controls that are quite varied and different for each character means that you get a totally different perspective with each character.A decent challenge level requiring you to utilise all your skills and relics effectively to come out unscathed. The failure states and death penalties are not overly punishing or frustrating but they force you to adhere to the game rather than just button mash.It is a plesant change of pace to have a dungeon crawling experience that is nearly purely built on skill rather than loot power or selecting an overpower skill combo. I played as the Valkyrie so far although the introduction teaching you each character is a nice touch. I can see the Wizard clearly having the highest skill cap with a great variety of spells. The actual visual customisation that alot of your gold can be spent on seems quite pointless to me in many respects. The top down representation of your character is small enough that you wouldn't really care what they looked like. Score and time leader boards clearly give this alot of longevity and the low price tag means you're not paying through the nose like many games require you to at release.At the end of the day this game knows that it is an arcade reimagining and markets and prices itself as such so I don't think you can really go wrong. When this gets a discount in the winter steam sale it will be a damn near mandatory purchase for any gamer even for just a few hours of fun.For modern gamers that never experienced an incarnation of Gauntlet before (either the classic versions or the ps2 Dark Legacy) the combat can be described as very similar to Bastion especially the special ability system powered by potions you pick up.This is nostalgia done right, sure it's not perfect, the limited voice acting detracts somewhat, but the few lines that are delivered match up with the classic style and humour of the game. This is certainly not your Diablo click and loot fest so don't even try to compare as it's a different genre entirely. This is pure dungeon crawling and monster killing with none of the fluff but all the intensity.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Not really a Gauntlet game at all. Feels beat em' up ish, like Dungeon Seige 3. I wanted it to be like Gauntlet Legends, but i guess there's really no contest. Leveling isn't by experience, it seems to be only in rewarding failure like shooting food or taking damage. There's no pick a color, and there are only 4 classes with very strick/unflexible abilities. I wanted the casual Robotron controls and flying axes everywhere, and instead we got a pretty streets of rage. You get very little health, on normal like 3 hits, instead of massive number counts. The graphics went very cartoonish. The Monster spawners work completely different, they summon 5+ in waves at a time and take a ton of powered shots to destroy, and are found in fewer numbers. The introduction to Death was irritating to say the least. They game doesn't feel fast paced at all, the character's move slowly, and the whole thing just feels sluggish. Very upset with my money spent. You can't just have an announcer say "Elf needs food badly" and call it a gauntlet game.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												This game is indeed true to it's arcade roots and represents a great way to have up to 4 players in a local co-op match.Each of the 4 characters (and a 5th if you pay to unlock it) has a unique method of play, meaning that even in a single-player setting, there should be a degree of replayability.But the killer negative aspect is that the game does not play very well using the Steam Controller.  The Steam Controller's right track pad acts as the "right joystick" which is used for power-attacks and it works in combination with the A, B, X, Y buttons.  However the buttons are very difficult to press in conjuction with trackpad, making essential attacks difficult during basic action scenes and essentially impossible when the game gets hectic.If you are using a controller that has an actual physical right-joystick, and not just a trackpad emulating one, this game would probably be worth the minimal cost.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												If you think you're going to have fun, then prepare to be dissapointed. Most of the newcomers who read this review will probably think that I'm full of it, and shrug it off. Want to know what happens to them? They will start playing the game, but not have any fun at the beginning. What happens next? They keep playing because they  anticipate the fun to eventually come to them as the game plays out.  But it never comes. They will keep sinking more hours into the game and expecting to eventually have fun. At the end of the day, they will find themselves finishing the game without ever truly being entertained, and will realize the game went by in a flash, not because it is fun, but  because they instinctively turned off their brain the entire time they were droning through the game, as if they were in a coma. But the fun doesn't end there (although technically it never started). They will be targeted by the  hatred of their three other friends whom were victimized into playing the game. They will then fall into a deep spiral of guilt-ridden depression and alcoholism as they lose their closest friends one by one because of the magnitude of this mistake. Finally, after years of unemployment and failed marriages, they will be found in one of the top posts in the subreddit /watchpeopledie as they kick the bucket in some spectacular way.
