number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I was really excited for this game when I first heard about it - my friend and I were playing Hammerwatch together awhile back but were left wanting something a bit more polished and dynamic. So why not just go right to the source, right? I downloaded and played it as soon as it was available... only to find that it's a bit of a glitchy mess. The sound skips when in the actual dungeon areas (everything runs fine on the title screen and in the shop), the frame rate is pretty bad overall (even at the lowest settings), and I've already had the game crash on me after just a few minutes playing through the first area. Furthermore, not only can you not re-map your keys on your keyboard (there are no control options whatsoever), but the game doesn't recognize my controller - forcing me to use an emulator to make it think it's an X-Box controller (though admittedly not that big a deal, it's still kind of annoying. And then I found out my controller is aparently broken. Great.)Speaking of which, the game is pretty hard - but it feels even harder playing with keyboard controls. I can't get used to using Shift for important skills like Dodge Rolling and Wizard Spells... I'd much rather be able to use my number keys or, well, anything else.Another annoyance is accidentally unlocking closed off areas that I didn't mean to all because I was trying to kite enemies on the Elf. Pressing F to open doors would have been nice. Just sayin'.Of what I've played of the game, despite all the rough edges, it seems fun. It's an unforgiving game as well - which is good! I like a bit of difficulty (though I wish the controls didn't factor into it).Overall, you might want to wait for them to patch this game... which I hope they do soon! As it stands it's really, REALLY hard for me to stand playing it for more than 30 minutes. With the sound off, of course.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												My wife and I played 2 hours of Gauntlet. We spent most of the time trying to beat the 2nd level... SECOND LEVEL!! ON EASY!! It sucks that games difficulty wasn't balanced well. There were a few other things that weren't very intuitive about how it was setup. Controls and gameplay were very simple but things aren't explained very well (or sometimes at all)We co-oped this and couldn't get past the second level. The first level was a breeze and we played a few times just to collect money so we could buy upgrades. But the upgrades cost between 25k up to 80k or so. Most of the upgrades are between 40 and 75 it seemed like. With each run, you would get between 2k-10k if you were lucky.  If you died, you got nothing. In the second level, you had to run from Death who would pop in and out and chase you into a locked room with a bunch of guys. If death touched you, you died immediately. Sometimes you could come back to life, sometimes not. We didn't know what determined it. Then sometimes you didn't come back to life right away but somehow did a few minutes later. Within the locked rooms were a flood of baddies all coming after you...while death chased you in circles around the room till death disappeared for a little and you could kill guys...until death came back again.All the characters were very simple controls except for the wizard who had confusing spells. Like if you had the fire spell on, you pressed space space for one spell, or space then left click for another, or space then left shift for another... but then the ice spell was shift shift or shift click of shift space. Everyone else was left click or right click, space bar or left shift. One button controls.

content:
Posted: January 29
												I really like this game. Here's why:Coop:Local coop works great, if you have friend coming over.Online coop also works well, most people I've played with were solid gamers and knew their way around hack&slash games.Challenges:Enemies have been patched and offer a better challenge now. New abilities keep you on your toes, so keep moving and be aware of your surrounding.3 difficulies let you scale and play just how you like/can/feel like.Modes:There is a campagne mode with an excuse of a story. You progress through the levels, can do some bonus levels, grinding/farming gold is also possible, if you are into that.There is an endless mode i haven't tried yet.The arena mode is fun. It's like one of the bonus "kill" rooms in the campagne and you have to endure wave after wave.Sadly, the only reward is cosmetic.Rpg-Elements:Sadly very few. You kill badies and get no extra reward. You must collect gold to buy new items. Some are purely cosmetic and some alter playstyle and abilities of your hero. It can be rather tidious to grind and farm only to buy that new trinket.All in all it's a hack&slash game that offers exactly that. Lot's of hack and more slash.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												When it works the way it should, Gauntlet is a great update to a classic game. The different characters offer different play styles, and when combined in co-op complement each other. Each section of levels has a certain style, with different types of enemies and a variety of challenges to keep things interesting. The formula is simple: Kill monsters to progress through dungeons and grab as much gold as you can on the way. Your score for each level goes toward unlocking and upgrading bonus abilities for your character, and you can spend gold to purchase new armor and items to use. The game is a bit short, but has high replay value and is a great way to kill a couple hours with friends. Unfortunately, the game can be buggy as hell. Many people can't get it to run at all, and others have experienced constant crashes and glitches. Keep that in mind before you purchase. You may have to do a little work to get the game to run smoothly, but once you do, there is a lot of fun to be had.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												It's obvious that the developers of this game both understood the source material and cared greatly about making a quality modern take on the classic arcade Gauntlet experience.  While the dev team could have phoned it in and the game still would have sold pretty well on nostalgia alone, they've actually made the effort to make a polished product that's fun to play either solo or in a group.  In essence, the premise of the game is simple -- descend through a variety of dungeon levels with one (if playing solo) or up to four of the characters, attacking endless streams of monsters (and destroying food, if you're not careful), finding keys, avoiding Death, and using relics that you can buy (and level up) from a shop at the level hub, using gold you gather from your adventures.  The ultimate goal is to collect a gem from each dungeon, but the story is secondary to the smashing and bashing action itself.  Combat is fluid, enemies are plentiful, and enemy generators pop up frequently, adding ever more enemies to the mix.  There are also a lot of achievements tracked by the game (including number of objects broken in the world, food eaten, and so on), and achieving different tiers of these achievements impart additional passive, related bonuses to your character.  While the game evokes memories of playing the arcade classic, the game avoids bringing in some of the more archaic mechanics of the original (like continually decreasing health), much to the game's benefit.The only glaring negative I've seen so far is that the Valkyrie is somewhat underpowered relative to the other classes - she ends up being 'Warrior-lite', with less mobility, less damage output, and fewer HP, and her cool shield tossing move isn't enough to make up for it.  Each of the other classes offer quite varied (and interesting) ways to play -- the Warrior is a decent 'stand around and smash stuff' character, the Elf plays a lot like a traditional twin-stick shooter, and the Wizard has a very Magicka-like spell selection and casting system that adds a little bit of extra challenge to picking spells to cast in the heat of battle. There's very little not to like about this game, and the game is priced well to boot.  You won't be blown away by the story, but you'll be having too much fun smashing stuff (and stealing food and treasure from your friends) to care.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Fun game which delivers on its aims. An easy to learn, challenging to master, co-op game which you can pick up at pretty much any time, with pretty much anyone and simply enjoy. The classes are fairly simple (with Merlin, the wizard, being somewhat harder) yet the difference in evironment gives them depth and force you to approach situations differently. The levels are challenging enough to require proper cooperation, and not as linear as to quickly become dull, exactly what I expected (or hoped for) from this kind of game. Best enjoyed with 3 friends, although it can be fun as 2 or 3 if you just set out to have some easy, straightforward, fun. Has a decent replay value in my opinion, each level having to be handled differently with the differing classes, as well as the colosseum feature which offers new seasons every few months. Overall a game I highly recommend considering the pricetag.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												End result is too much grinding in an extremely short game for not enough reward. Pros: ▲ Couch Co-Op is possible▲ Nostalgia▲ On higher difficulties, game is legitimately difficult▲ Colosseum mode is a neat conceptCons:▼ Game is incredibly short (1 sitting)▼ Even in Online play, you do not get seperate cameras over your own character.▼ Most of the game levels feel like copy and paste work▼ Characters are not fun to play~ Valkrye is obviously the best and a solid character~ Archer is barely acceptable~ Necromancer is sub-par and creates excessive screen clutter~ Wizard is over-complicated and weak~ Barbarian is not even worth playing (Underpowered, no defense, long cooldown on only useful ability)▼ Gear unlocks give no actual bonus to character power▼ Leaderboards are constantly hacked and, thus, pointless▼ Relics are barely useful, and UNusable in colosseum▼ Colosseum level layouts are NOT fun▼ Masteries are not even worth having and require excessive grind - ~3% Damage bonus after GOLD tier (3rd tier) of unlock. Something like 25,000 kills. (Roughly 15 hours of constant grind)~3% Damage is not even enough to affect the power level of the only attack that it affects (basic attacks)This last thing is what finally inspired me to write a negative review. My friends and I picked up the game again recently after a long time on the shelf (since 5 hours after release), and quit playing again after 2 hours. The masteries we were working towards were simply discouraging to look at. It was hours and hours of the EXACT same (unfun) levels, for insignificant gain. 1% damage per mastery point? WHY EVEN BOTHER???

Posted: December 6, 2015
												To say I don't reccomend this game is a bit of a stretch.  If rating were an option I'd rate it 3/5.  First of all, a year since the game's launch, there's the multiplayer activity is pretty slim which means you're probably going to have to recruit 3 other people yourself (and get them to buy the game).  On top of that, there's no player AI which means if you can't find three other humans, then you're stuck playing a game meant for four players all by yourself.It's also tagged as an RPG but most certainly isn't.  It's simply an action game.   There's in-game gold you can use to buy various weapons and accessorieis but your character's physical abilities is directly tied to yours.  Even buying accessories requires a relatively large amount of time invested in collecting gold so you've got to go back and replay levels over and over again to overcome the difficultly curve due to lack of multiple players.If you've got a group of people you know you can schedule playing time with, it'd probably be signfianctly more enjoyable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I adore this game. It is simple but far from mindless.What I love is that it makes 4 different classes with different skills that play differently. Modern games in the likeness of diablo 3 have many classes with dozens of skills but many are useless. Gauntlet keeps things simple but yet each class is unique and fun in its own way. Playing with 4 friends is a blast and there is a skill curve that the origional titles lacked.The problems with the game are a lack of content, enemy variety, and overall shortness of the experience. There's only a few bosses, there is very limited gear, and while the relic and talisman system is interesting, generally there is a flat out "best" build for a class that makes the other options a moot point.Still, Gauntlet isn't great because of it's gear selection or character customization. It's great because it is simple, striped down, and doesn't need any of that stuff to be fun to play with your friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												I bought this game for the sole purpose of Co-op with friends. And here's what we collectively thought about it. There are no pros, only cons.1. Progression is slow and repetitive. The game is so grindy and so boring that you will eventually fall asleep trying to get past their long and unoriginal gameplay.2. Slow reward system. The rewards of this game are not introduced quick enough for you to be constantly captivated by the game. You're stuck with the same two skills for an extended period of time, until you grind the money for other stuff.3. Even if you manage to grind the gold required to unlock the final tiers of equipment, they're completely boring as well. I got so bored with the game that I used a CheatEngine to get infinite gold, and EVEN THEN the most expensive items weren't fun enough to keep me motivated.4. This is nothing but Hack n Slash. There's no special puzzles to solve like Forced, no special OP loot like Diablo, no special boss fights that require skills to kill like Lara Croft.5. Boring enemies, boring music, boring dialogue, boring combat. Boooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooring everything.6. No skill trees, stats, mana system, etc. In short, this game doesn't have any complex systems in place to give it more depth.7. You never feel powerful. Games like Diablo allow your characters to always feel powerful even at all stages of the game. But in this game, you always feel like your characters just don't do enough damage fast enough no matter what equipment you buy. You also don't actually get stronger as you progress, something that needs 2 hits to kill, will always need 2 hits to kill with the same skill no matter how long you play. YOU NEVER LEVEL UP OR GROW STRONGER.8. Limited Options. There perhaps 3 main weapons per character, 3ish potion options, several relics. And that's it. Not much difference among them other than the skill you wanna use.If you like spending hours doing repetitive♥♥♥♥♥♥to get money to get boring♥♥♥♥♥♥ get an office job. You'll at least feel like you accomplished something at the end of the day.Score: 3/10 (Go play Diablo 3, Forced, Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light instead)

Posted: March 16
												(This review is my opinion so it might be biased)Personally, I prefer Gauntlet Dark Legacy. It's more colourful and the music is just legendary. There were more characters to play as, realms were memorable and the difficulty was fair despite boss battles being a lil tricky.Gauntlet Slayer Edition appealed to me because I loved Dark Legacy. However, given what I just said, I was disappointed with this game. I know that the original had 4 classes but come on, they could've easily included the NEW characters from Dark Legacy. The graphics are better then Dark Legacy but the lack of colour and darkness just sickens me. The music is also ok but not as good as Dark Legacy. The controls (Mouse & Keyboard) are not my favourite. Having to point in the direction of attacking bugs me so much that I can’t get past the 2nd level, even though I was playing on EASY.Despite the game disappointing me, I recommend this game to those who like a challenge and are fans of Gauntlet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Gauntlet is a 4-player arcade dungeon crawler. It's a remake from the 1985 version. In the game, you can select to be as either a maniac who swings his sword a lot and dies, some woman who seems to have a fascination for throwing equipment rather than using it and an elf who swings quickly around the map, sweeping and killing enemies. So yeah, the game does have lots of balance issues. Thor is unusable, even with other people helping you. Thyra, the Valkyrie is simply unusable because she's a melee character, leading to complications in actually doing something and not just being a deposit for lost money due to deaths. Questor or the Elf is the only useful character. He plays like a duel stick shooter and does have a balance between strategic gameplay and fun and intuitive attacks. Did I forget a character? Oh, yes, I did. Merlin, the Wizard...he's almost next to unusable. The controls dull the expirience as now you get the fun task of crafting all your spells as you play. It's like taking your SAT while being chased by zombies. Now that you've successfully opened your notes, answered all 15 questions and submitted your blood type, you have a spell. The spell, also has a cooldown...great. So either you sit there like an idiot waiting 0.5 seconds before you're even allowed to attack an enemy (0.5 seconds is a significant amount in literally any videogame) or take your re-test and submit your blood type, passport and answer another 15 questions to get another spell.The gameply though, is addictive and does offer a wide span of challenges in only a few levels. While the variety of levels is small (only a few levels) it is quite fun for the amount of time you'll play. The difficulty levels will either have you cruising through levels, or screaming in agony and adds more gameplay to the game.There is a cooperative mode but either you'll get stuck with the character you never want (usually the case) or get stuck with people who hoard potions. "Why not play with friends?" you ask? Well, I would, if the game actually worked on their PCs. This game was a gift I got from a friend who was gonna play with me, but his game doesn't even work. Not many people I know play this game, and those who did didn't exactly play everytime I booted up the game. So if you bought a four-pack for some buddies and you to get online and kick♥♥♥♥♥just roll some dice and cut your losses because you'll have no idea if your friends can even boot up the game.The game does feature a nice "Mastery" system that rewards you for mundane things you should be doing anyways. There are leaderboards in this game but have fun even ranking. Some people play this game like it's their job. I would say "Though the best expirience is beating your friend's scores!" but it's not...mostly because you won't have any friends to score a highscore against. Like I said, major problem is the game not even booting up.It is a fun arcade expirience, but the gamble your game will even launch is definitely a problem. I expirienced problems too, like a "Gauntlet.exe is not responding" which, great for it. This'd happen when I tried to quit, so luckily it didn't ruin gameplay. It did add a more thrilling aspect to the expirience of quiting the game with Ctrl-Alt-Del to complete the task the game was trying to do anyways. Oh, and yes, we are patiently awaiting a patch, but it wouldn't change my score. I'd have to say that when I purchase a game, I should be able to play it.Edit: It was finally patched, and my friend can join. However, now there's crippling (as well as just plain annoying bugs) that ruin the game. Don't buy this.

Single player, while challenging, quickly becomes a slog, and nigh impossible depending which class you're going with.  Like w/ Magicka, a good group and suddenly this game is loads of fun.  - A lot of the in game purchases are vanity (of which there isn't much choice), and where there is variability, it just doesn't feel like there's much of it.  At the same time, this IS Gauntlet, not NWN.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												It may be important to note that I did not play this game before the Slayer Edition update so I can't compare the changes to what the earlier release was like.I have always been a fan of Gauntlet games since playing a ton of the original 4-player co-op arcade game.  My favorites along the way were Gauntlet IV for the Sega Genesis and Gauntlet: Dark Legacy for the PS2.  I feel that this game is a pretty good entry in the franchise.I have completed about 10 hours of play so far and I'm enjoying the game quite a bit.  My system struggled a little with some of the graphics settings but, once I turned some things down, it has played very smoothly while still looking quite good.  I believe that Arrowhead did a good job of recreating the spirit of the original in a modernized version of the game.It's pretty easy to jump right in and start playing because gameplay is quite basic.  The weapon and potion abilities are a nice touch to aid in combat.  Some people have complained about the repetition in environments and enemies but that's been the case with every Gauntlet game - I see that as being true to the franchise.As for negatives, I find that the system for buying new weapons and stuff is lacking.  It's not immediately apparent what benefits, if any, there are to buying upgrades.  Some things seem to do nothing more than change the character's appearance.  Different weapons have different abilities but there's no indication that the weapons are more powerful.  Relics seem interesting but their use is not totally intuitive.  I plan to experiment more to see how useful they might be.Another problem I have is Death.  In previous Gauntlet games, you could use potions to kill Death.  However, in this game it appears that potions simply drive Death away for a short time.  Potions are fairly uncommon and you can only carry a few at a time so you really just have to try to avoid Death, which can be really frustrating.Overall, I find this game to be a lot of fun to play.  I would prefer a better system for buying upgrades and I would like a better way to deal with Death like earlier Gauntlet games but these negatives don't stop the game from being fun.  The $20 full price isn't terrible but I would recommend waiting for a sale if you can.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Gauntlet is a 4-player arcade dungeon crawler. It's a remake from the 1985 version. In the game, you can select to be as either a maniac who swings his sword a lot and dies, some woman who seems to have a fascination for throwing equipment rather than using it and an elf who swings quickly around the map, sweeping and killing enemies. So yeah, the game does have lots of balance issues. Thor is unusable, even with other people helping you. Thyra, the Valkyrie is simply unusable because she's a melee character, leading to complications in actually doing something and not just being a deposit for lost money due to deaths. Questor or the Elf is the only useful character. He plays like a duel stick shooter and does have a balance between strategic gameplay and fun and intuitive attacks. Did I forget a character? Oh, yes, I did. Merlin, the Wizard...he's almost next to unusable. The controls dull the expirience as now you get the fun task of crafting all your spells as you play. It's like taking your SAT while being chased by zombies. Now that you've successfully opened your notes, answered all 15 questions and submitted your blood type, you have a spell. The spell, also has a cooldown...great. So either you sit there like an idiot waiting 0.5 seconds before you're even allowed to attack an enemy (0.5 seconds is a significant amount in literally any videogame) or take your re-test and submit your blood type, passport and answer another 15 questions to get another spell.The gameply though, is addictive and does offer a wide span of challenges in only a few levels. While the variety of levels is small (only a few levels) it is quite fun for the amount of time you'll play. The difficulty levels will either have you cruising through levels, or screaming in agony and adds more gameplay to the game.There is a cooperative mode but either you'll get stuck with the character you never want (usually the case) or get stuck with people who hoard potions. "Why not play with friends?" you ask? Well, I would, if the game actually worked on their PCs. This game was a gift I got from a friend who was gonna play with me, but his game doesn't even work. Not many people I know play this game, and those who did didn't exactly play everytime I booted up the game. So if you bought a four-pack for some buddies and you to get online and kick♥♥♥♥♥just roll some dice and cut your losses because you'll have no idea if your friends can even boot up the game.The game does feature a nice "Mastery" system that rewards you for mundane things you should be doing anyways. There are leaderboards in this game but have fun even ranking. Some people play this game like it's their job. I would say "Though the best expirience is beating your friend's scores!" but it's not...mostly because you won't have any friends to score a highscore against. Like I said, major problem is the game not even booting up.It is a fun arcade expirience, but the gamble your game will even launch is definitely a problem. I expirienced problems too, like a "Gauntlet.exe is not responding" which, great for it. This'd happen when I tried to quit, so luckily it didn't ruin gameplay. It did add a more thrilling aspect to the expirience of quiting the game with Ctrl-Alt-Del to complete the task the game was trying to do anyways. Oh, and yes, we are patiently awaiting a patch, but it wouldn't change my score. I'd have to say that when I purchase a game, I should be able to play it.Edit: It was finally patched, and my friend can join. However, now there's crippling (as well as just plain annoying bugs) that ruin the game. Don't buy this.
